description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on the knowledge required for the 98-366: MTA Networking Fundamentals Exam.  This exam tests your knowledge about networking basics and the configuration of network settings and also covers the basic hardware one will find as network technicians in the field, terminology one is likely to encounter, and about the OSI model and different internet protocols which are foundational to all of networking. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Networking Fundamentals - 98-366
subtitle: Networking Fundamentals

58

60

64

65

66

67

68
00:03:44.770 --> 00:03:48.810
The very fact that you and
I can be able to connect to the Internet,

69

70

71

72

73

74

83

110

112

And, we also talk about

113

114

And of course, well,

115

117

118

119

120

121

122

123

124

For those of you that are actually

126
00:06:58.957 --> 00:07:01.624

127
00:07:01.624 --> 00:07:03.599
that Microsoft Technology Associate, and

128
00:07:03.599 --> 00:07:06.080
that shows an incredible

129
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:10.010
That you really wanna get into the IT

130
00:07:10.010 --> 00:07:11.590
so take the time.

131
00:07:11.590 --> 00:07:15.140
Take a look at this series of shows

132

133
00:07:18.880 --> 00:07:21.919
So make sure you take a few moments,

134
00:07:21.919 --> 00:07:25.404
you actually end up seeing that you may

135
00:07:25.404 --> 00:07:27.082

136
00:07:27.082 --> 00:07:30.140
And that will also help guide
your career into the future

137
00:07:30.140 --> 00:07:31.574

138

140
00:07:37.124 --> 00:07:41.086
And hopefully we'll see you

141
00:07:41.086 --> 00:07:47.069
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the basics of computer networks utilizing the OSI and TCP/IP reference models. They teach you about the differences between the two models, how they are used to standardize networks, and the layers that comprise them.
episodes.title: OSI Model

15

Now you need to understand, if you are
going to get into the world of Microsoft

servers and of course, networking, and so
that is what we are beginning with today.

17
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:57.360

really the fundamental itself, right?

18

This is the building blocks of networking.

19

20

How does all this stuff work?

21

Is it voodoo?

22
00:01:03.970 --> 00:01:04.630
Is it witchcraft?

23
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:05.220
We don't know.

24
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:06.165
No, actually we do know.

25
00:01:06.165 --> 00:01:09.210
[LAUGH] We have a pretty good
understanding of how computer

26
00:01:09.210 --> 00:01:10.120
networks work.

27
00:01:10.120 --> 00:01:14.000
Hopefully by the end of this episode you
as well will have a better understanding

28
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:18.390
so that you can figure out, oh, now I see
how computers connect to each other, how

29

how they deliver messages to each other.

30
00:01:23.150 --> 00:01:25.350
And that's basically
the structure of a network.

31
00:01:25.350 --> 00:01:28.970
Now Ronnie, you're gonna start us off
with probably the most fundamental thing

32
00:01:28.970 --> 00:01:30.160
when it comes to networking right?

33
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:33.370
>> Right and we're gonna take a look
at how in the world two computers

34
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:36.440
really begin the process of communication,
is what we're taking a look at.

35
00:01:36.440 --> 00:01:38.000
And you've gotta remember something.

36
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:42.000
Unlike humans, which learn how to
communicate by simply observing and

37
00:01:42.000 --> 00:01:45.300
then mimicking sound and then begin
to try and make words out of it.

38
00:01:45.300 --> 00:01:47.500
Well, computers can't do that.

39
00:01:47.500 --> 00:01:48.320
I know that sounds strange.

40
00:01:48.320 --> 00:01:53.310
But they really cannot take that time and
communication becomes intuitive to them.

41
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:56.120
So we need to teach it to
them is what we need to do.

42
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:58.150
Now the problem that we
had in early computing,

43
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:01.100
and when we started talking about
networking, was fairly simple.

44
00:02:01.100 --> 00:02:04.180
Everybody and their mother thought it
should actually be done differently.

45
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:06.500
Now when I say that, everybody and
their mother, who am I talking about?

46
00:02:06.500 --> 00:02:08.020
Well, hardware vendors, right?

47
00:02:08.020 --> 00:02:12.010
People that wanted to be able to have
the communication process go on between

48
00:02:12.010 --> 00:02:13.000

49
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:14.990
Well, if they were hardware vendors,

50
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:17.590
they would come up with their
own model and networking.

51
00:02:17.590 --> 00:02:19.060
And that did work.

52
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:22.410
As long as your computers were
actually based in the same hardware,

53
00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:25.490
they would follow the same rules and
the same protocols and

54
00:02:25.490 --> 00:02:29.860
the same language to be able to
communicate and do what they needed to.

55
00:02:29.860 --> 00:02:33.940
But then if you needed to add in
additional equipment, let's say from

56
00:02:33.940 --> 00:02:37.540
another vendor instead, well then
you started running into problems.

57
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:39.860
And when we talk about running
into problems at that point,

58
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:44.340
now it's like saying okay, hey, I need my
network, my stuff, to communicate with

59
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:50.770
this other vendor stuff, and now they're
like, I don't think that we can do that.

60
00:02:50.770 --> 00:02:53.600
And the customer doesn't understand,
and what he says is, why?

61
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:56.445
Why can't you just make this device
communicate with that device?

62
00:02:56.445 --> 00:02:59.875
And it comes down to the very fact,
well, they use a different protocol.

63
00:02:59.875 --> 00:03:01.145
Now, what is that about?

64
00:03:01.145 --> 00:03:03.765
That's like a different language,
is what it's about.

65
00:03:03.765 --> 00:03:06.455
So what started to happen,
then, in networking and

66
00:03:06.455 --> 00:03:09.655
in the world of hardware
networking was simple.

67
00:03:09.655 --> 00:03:11.025
They started realizing something.

68
00:03:11.025 --> 00:03:14.685
As long as they keep these their own
proprietary way of doing networking,

69
00:03:14.685 --> 00:03:16.780
in other words,
of establishing communication,

70
00:03:16.780 --> 00:03:21.450
between two devices, they could grow
the industry as long as they, you know,

71
00:03:21.450 --> 00:03:23.280
everybody needed only their equipment.

72
00:03:23.280 --> 00:03:26.090
But just like everybody else, just like
all the other hardware vendors, there

73
00:03:26.090 --> 00:03:29.110

certain things that they weren't good at.

74
00:03:29.110 --> 00:03:32.490
Certain things that other companies
were really good at, but not, you know,

75
00:03:32.490 --> 00:03:36.020
good at what they were doing, and so
then you start having specialization and

76
00:03:36.020 --> 00:03:40.630
the problem is they couldn't meld together
and make the communication process happen.

77
00:03:40.630 --> 00:03:45.000
So, of course, then, we're only in the
early 80s and probably even before that,

78
00:03:45.000 --> 00:03:48.910
and they started saying we need
a unified networking model.

79
00:03:48.910 --> 00:03:53.300
In other words, we need everybody to agree
on how the process of communication is to

80
00:03:53.300 --> 00:03:57.110
happen between machines that
are gonna be networked together.

81
00:03:57.110 --> 00:04:01.510
And when they started to think about that,
they need to actually understand how this

82
00:04:01.510 --> 00:04:06.120
would work, and then they needed everybody
to agree on how this would work here.

83
00:04:06.120 --> 00:04:08.060
And so it started to happen.

84
00:04:08.060 --> 00:04:12.100
Companies started following what they
called an open system model, and

85
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:15.130
that meant that look, nobody's actually
going to claim responsibility for

86
00:04:15.130 --> 00:04:16.690
this, but here it is.

87
00:04:16.690 --> 00:04:18.670
What's going to happen are people
are actually going to say, look,

88
00:04:18.670 --> 00:04:19.970
here's what we want to do.

89
00:04:19.970 --> 00:04:22.320
We want everybody to design
their equipment around this.

90
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:25.410
And when they did it was
an incredible financial benefit.

91
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:27.980
It was an incredible
communication benefit.

92
00:04:27.980 --> 00:04:31.275
Because now, vendors could actually talk,
or different vendors, excuse me,

93
00:04:31.275 --> 00:04:34.424
could actually have their equipment
talk with other people's equipment and

94
00:04:34.424 --> 00:04:37.280
not sacrifice the capabilities
that they were looking for.

95
00:04:37.280 --> 00:04:40.290
So it is a great beginning
to that process, right?

96
00:04:40.290 --> 00:04:43.310
Establishing common ground for
all the equipment.

97
00:04:43.310 --> 00:04:47.080
And the reason why it's actually so
great is that even now,

98
00:04:47.080 --> 00:04:50.360
even 30 years later,
a little bit longer than that and

99
00:04:50.360 --> 00:04:53.290
even longer than that, when they realized
that that's what they needed to happen,

100
00:04:53.290 --> 00:04:56.990
is still kind of the foundation of
all the networking that we do today.

101
00:04:56.990 --> 00:05:00.730
So it's very important to them if we
are to understand networking then we

102
00:05:00.730 --> 00:05:03.380
have to understand that model.

103
00:05:03.380 --> 00:05:07.090
And that model is what is
called the OSI model or

104
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:09.440
the Open Systems Interconnection model.

105
00:05:09.440 --> 00:05:12.670
Let me show you a diagram of
what I'm talking about here.

106
00:05:12.670 --> 00:05:17.510
So, I went ahead and made a simple diagram
and this particular diagram, here it is.

107
00:05:17.510 --> 00:05:20.100
You generally here about it
called the OSI Model, and

108
00:05:20.100 --> 00:05:24.270
this is the model, this is the one that
all those vendors and everybody agreed to,

109
00:05:24.270 --> 00:05:28.000
that when they build networking equipment,
it's gonna follow this model.

110
00:05:28.000 --> 00:05:31.680
So that regardless of who the vendor is,
they're going to go ahead and

111
00:05:31.680 --> 00:05:33.570
this is what they're gonna use.

112
00:05:33.570 --> 00:05:38.320
Now, when we start talking about the basic
communication and what happens, right?

113
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:40.080
When the computers are networked together,

114
00:05:40.080 --> 00:05:42.670
they have to be able
to do a lot of things.

115
00:05:42.670 --> 00:05:47.310
One, the data actually has to be able to
get ready to be sent on the network and

116
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:49.670
then of course, processed and
sent on the network.

117
00:05:49.670 --> 00:05:53.380
And then actually understand where it's
going and then also processed again.

118
00:05:53.380 --> 00:05:58.370
So, this Open System Interconnection
model then, they broke it

119
00:05:58.370 --> 00:06:03.900
down into seven layers, so every computer
that sends data out on the network.

120
00:06:03.900 --> 00:06:07.830
But when they do so, the data is
processed through these seven layers.

121
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:10.260
And it actually happens when
they're sending outbound.

122
00:06:10.260 --> 00:06:15.700
It processes it from the top down through
the bottom, is what ends up going on here.

123
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:19.010
Now, you actually end up
memorizing this in networking.

124
00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:19.600
You really do.

125
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:24.280
After using and even starting to
network computers together, when

126
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:26.830
you start troubleshooting, when you start
actually understanding what happens on

127
00:06:26.830 --> 00:06:31.790
each of these layers, it begins to make a
little bit more sense of what's going on.

128
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:33.210
So, this is what we want to understand.

129
00:06:33.210 --> 00:06:38.550
Now, if I were you as well, in getting
ready for the MTA exam too, I would

130
00:06:38.550 --> 00:06:42.500
make sure that I memorize these seven
models too and so that we understand it.

131
00:06:42.500 --> 00:06:47.150
Now sometimes, you also hear them called
by different layer numbers, as well.

00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:51.750
So you may hear the term Layer 1 and Layer

00:06:53.710 --> 00:06:58.110
Let's see, Layer 1, and then we can

So you may also hear the term layer.

00:06:59.900 --> 00:07:04.190
Now that's actually not Layer 1, that's

Now I'm just going to repeat

00:07:07.360 --> 00:07:08.805
And so this one would be Layer 6.

And then,
we can actually go down here to Layer 5.

Oops.

Well, maybe.

That's what I get for

00:07:21.960 --> 00:07:25.460
So fasten layer five, and Layer 4.

00:07:25.460 --> 00:07:28.270
So you might hear both

00:07:28.270 --> 00:07:29.830
as you actually start work with it.

00:07:29.830 --> 00:07:31.340
And they really mean the same thing,even

00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:33.640
though people call them
by different names.

00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:35.865
And then last one here is Layer 1.

00:07:35.865 --> 00:07:38.660
I'm gonna copy and

00:07:38.660 --> 00:07:41.755
and that will actually

151
00:07:41.755 --> 00:07:45.741
So what in the world is this saying
when we start off with the process of

152
00:07:45.741 --> 00:07:48.378
communication and
doing this in this model?

153
00:07:48.378 --> 00:07:52.322
As computers need to be able to
communicate with a different machine

154
00:07:52.322 --> 00:07:56.403
somewhere on the network, well what
we actually have to begin with and

155
00:07:56.403 --> 00:08:00.225
understand as far as the OSI model Is,
what is a current, right?

156
00:08:00.225 --> 00:08:05.175
So, when I need to send data, let's take
for an example that what I need to do is

157
00:08:05.175 --> 00:08:09.060
to get an e-mail message to you somehow,
some way.

158
00:08:09.060 --> 00:08:11.640
Well, there has to be some
interaction between me and

159
00:08:11.640 --> 00:08:14.320
the software that I'm using and
then that software has to say,

160
00:08:14.320 --> 00:08:17.890
look, I am now ready to take that
information and send it out.

161
00:08:17.890 --> 00:08:21.850
If it just exists in the form that it
is on my computer it is not ready for

162
00:08:21.850 --> 00:08:22.860
the network at all.

163
00:08:22.860 --> 00:08:23.460
Right?
So

164
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:26.580
the data that you see on the screen
as you're typing an email

165
00:08:26.580 --> 00:08:28.610
doesn't mean that it's
ready to be transmitted,

166
00:08:28.610 --> 00:08:31.120
it doesn't mean that it's ready for
the network at all.

167
00:08:31.120 --> 00:08:36.062
So what the application layer says is that
after I'm finished typing out my email,

168
00:08:36.062 --> 00:08:40.296
it says hey, now this piece of data
needs to be prepared to be put out onto

169
00:08:40.296 --> 00:08:41.800
the network somewhere.

170
00:08:41.800 --> 00:08:42.508
Okay?

171
00:08:42.508 --> 00:08:46.339
So when it does that,
it hits the application layer first.

172
00:08:46.339 --> 00:08:49.549
The application layer says,
yes here's this data and

173
00:08:49.549 --> 00:08:52.144
it's trying actually to get sent out here.

174
00:08:52.144 --> 00:08:53.645
And what happens is it says,

175
00:08:53.645 --> 00:08:57.588
that application is an email application
that is trying to send that out and

176
00:08:57.588 --> 00:09:02.140
saying, I need to prepare whatever it
is this message is, to get sent out.

177
00:09:02.140 --> 00:09:05.890
Now, when it does that, it also brings
it down to the presentation layer.

178
00:09:05.890 --> 00:09:08.080
Presentation is about formatting.

179
00:09:08.080 --> 00:09:09.820
What is happening now, right?

180
00:09:09.820 --> 00:09:12.960
Is that, if we just put that
piece of data out there, well,

181
00:09:12.960 --> 00:09:15.880
we don't know what it's actually
gonna look like on the other side.

182
00:09:15.880 --> 00:09:18.730
So the presentation layer
allows us to be able to say,

183
00:09:18.730 --> 00:09:22.220
here's what this piece of data
should look like on the other side.

184
00:09:22.220 --> 00:09:23.430
So it formats it.

185
00:09:23.430 --> 00:09:27.637
If this was an image, you might here
people talking about formatting as

186
00:09:27.637 --> 00:09:31.982
a .png file or a .jpeg, if it was some
type of word processing document,

187
00:09:31.982 --> 00:09:34.529
like a word document, it might be a .doc.

188
00:09:34.529 --> 00:09:37.883
It's all this about the proper formatting
so that when it gets opened up on

189
00:09:37.883 --> 00:09:41.777
the other side, the computer just goes all
right, we're associating this file with

190
00:09:41.777 --> 00:09:45.070
this particular application
is what we start to do.

191
00:09:45.070 --> 00:09:47.820
And then you come down
to the session layer and

192
00:09:47.820 --> 00:09:53.640
the session layer is trying to ensure that
we actually establish a communication.

193
00:09:53.640 --> 00:09:57.654
We can then maintain that communication
between this computer and that computer on

194
00:09:57.654 --> 00:10:01.574
the other side, and also it breaks down
at the end if we're transferring a file.

195
00:10:01.574 --> 00:10:02.430
Now what does that means?

196
00:10:02.430 --> 00:10:06.840
It means when we transfer the file, the
other side knows where it's coming from.

197
00:10:06.840 --> 00:10:10.520
It knows whether or not there's actually
multiple pieces that need to come in or

198
00:10:10.520 --> 00:10:12.980
not and then it says,
hey, at the end of it,

199
00:10:12.980 --> 00:10:16.200
I know to close this session out if
we don't have any more data to send.

200
00:10:17.220 --> 00:10:21.370
And then, as we are also,
sending that data outbound as well,

201
00:10:21.370 --> 00:10:25.520
the transport layer helps us to
break it up into manageable chunks.

202
00:10:25.520 --> 00:10:27.980
When we start sending data
out across our network

203
00:10:27.980 --> 00:10:31.150
they do limit the size of
how big things can be.

204
00:10:31.150 --> 00:10:32.710
It's just like a UPS package.

205
00:10:32.710 --> 00:10:34.000
I know that sounds strange, but

206
00:10:34.000 --> 00:10:37.220
there's a limitation in how big a UPS
package can go on those trucks.

207
00:10:37.220 --> 00:10:41.470
So if you have something bigger, they tell
you you can't send this in one big size,

208
00:10:41.470 --> 00:10:43.990
you can divide it up
into multiple chunks so

209
00:10:43.990 --> 00:10:45.650
that it can be handled
a little bit better.

210
00:10:45.650 --> 00:10:47.880
Well, the transport
layer does exactly that.

211
00:10:47.880 --> 00:10:52.200
It helps to manage that process and
even does error correction for

212
00:10:52.200 --> 00:10:55.550
us too, such as labeling those
packages that are actually gonna

213
00:10:55.550 --> 00:10:57.620
be combined back together at some point.

214
00:10:57.620 --> 00:10:59.189
And then once we have that,

215
00:10:59.189 --> 00:11:03.156
the data is now prepared to be put
out onto network to a point, right?

216
00:11:03.156 --> 00:11:06.964
In other words, that data is now kind
of wrapped up in what it needs to be

217
00:11:06.964 --> 00:11:10.030
encapsulated is a term
that you'll also hear.

218
00:11:10.030 --> 00:11:14.620
That it says look, now this data is
ready except for a few other things.

219
00:11:14.620 --> 00:11:17.790
When my computer now says all right,
here's data that's ready gone on

220
00:11:17.790 --> 00:11:22.220
the network, we now need to be able
to say where the data came from and

221
00:11:22.220 --> 00:11:24.690
where the data is ultimately going.

222
00:11:24.690 --> 00:11:27.580
And that's what the network layer does.

223
00:11:27.580 --> 00:11:31.750
And then from that point, once we actually
realize where the source of it is from,

224
00:11:31.750 --> 00:11:36.300
and the destination, the data link
layer provides the physical pathway.

225
00:11:36.300 --> 00:11:39.670
In other words the device to
device to device transport.

226
00:11:39.670 --> 00:11:44.470
In other words the actual movement of the
data along the path to its destination and

227
00:11:44.470 --> 00:11:47.820
finally, the physical layer is just that.

228
00:11:47.820 --> 00:11:50.760
It literally is the wire
that it goes across, and

229
00:11:50.760 --> 00:11:52.910
it's actually gonna be read as well.

230
00:11:52.910 --> 00:11:57.180
So when we start talking about that
basic communication, every computer

231
00:11:57.180 --> 00:12:02.300
has to be able to do this when it is
going to send it out onto the network.

232
00:12:02.300 --> 00:12:06.430
So this model is by far the most
important model that we have.

233
00:12:06.430 --> 00:12:10.800
So now, regardless of who the equipment
manufacturer is on the other end,

234
00:12:10.800 --> 00:12:15.170
if they've built their hardware to do this
same model, well that means that they can

235
00:12:15.170 --> 00:12:19.360
process them at the physical layer,
the data link layer, network, transport,

236
00:12:19.360 --> 00:12:23.600
session, presentation, and
application layer as well.

237
00:12:23.600 --> 00:12:27.420
So it allows them to go, okay,
I understand this communication process

238
00:12:27.420 --> 00:12:31.310
because it was sent in that format,
I can read that format and I can actually

239
00:12:31.310 --> 00:12:36.160
have it come all back in and that's
another term that you also hear too.

240
00:12:36.160 --> 00:12:40.930
So you tend to see this as
being a theoretical approach.

241
00:12:40.930 --> 00:12:43.930
So now when you have not only
hardware vendors doing it,

242
00:12:43.930 --> 00:12:47.150
you now start having people that
are building applications and

243
00:12:47.150 --> 00:12:51.710
building protocols that are also
designed to follow this model, as well.

244
00:12:51.710 --> 00:12:55.190
The reason why that's also important
is because, now, it doesn't matter

245
00:12:55.190 --> 00:12:59.590
who you buy the application from, because
they built it to support this model.

246
00:12:59.590 --> 00:13:02.360
Protocols under use such
as email protocols,

247
00:13:02.360 --> 00:13:04.920
it doesn't matter what
email program that you use.

248
00:13:04.920 --> 00:13:07.650
It say, look,
that protocol's designed to work here.

249
00:13:07.650 --> 00:13:11.290
The benefit behind that as well,
is if I design something to work,

250
00:13:11.290 --> 00:13:12.830
let's say the presentation layer,

251
00:13:12.830 --> 00:13:16.090
there's a brand new format that
nobody else on the planet has seen.

252
00:13:16.090 --> 00:13:17.714
Well, the presentation layer says,

253
00:13:17.714 --> 00:13:21.630
that's fine as long as the other side
understands what this format actually is.

254
00:13:21.630 --> 00:13:23.807
We're good to go.
It doesn't matter if no other machine

255
00:13:23.807 --> 00:13:26.759
knows about it,
they can just influence this one layer and

256
00:13:26.759 --> 00:13:29.891
we don't have to rebuild the whole
thing again from scratch,

257
00:13:29.891 --> 00:13:32.230
just because you change something.

258
00:13:32.230 --> 00:13:35.290
It's a very layered approach,
and that's what makes it nice and

259
00:13:35.290 --> 00:13:38.020
very modular, I guess is the proper term,

260
00:13:38.020 --> 00:13:41.730
and allows that basic communication
process to begin to happen.

>> Yeah, it's all about standardization.

When it comes to the OSI model, right?

That was the whole purpose behind it.

Make sure you get all of those in

524
00:27:06.150 --> 00:27:09.490
But they are actually the applications
that those programs use.

525
00:27:09.490 --> 00:27:12.220
If I am sending something
because of email,

526
00:27:12.220 --> 00:27:15.760
I might choose something like smtp, so
this application says yep, I'm gonna be

527
00:27:15.760 --> 00:27:19.580
sending this I need to make sure it's
packaged up the way smtp would package it.

528
00:27:19.580 --> 00:27:22.840
If I'm gonna make a connection, or
do name resolution, you name it,

529
00:27:22.840 --> 00:27:24.800
there's a bunch of these protocols.

530
00:27:24.800 --> 00:27:28.110
And yes, this is something that
we just have to know again.

531
00:27:28.110 --> 00:27:31.815
I wish that there was a way around
this that it would be easy unknown,

532
00:27:31.815 --> 00:27:35.845
but I would make sure that I at least
know some of these devices over here and

533
00:27:35.845 --> 00:27:39.618
some of these protocols that are also
at each of those layers as well.

534
00:27:39.618 --> 00:27:41.525
And this is where it
becomes more practical,

535
00:27:41.525 --> 00:27:44.637
because if you know what functions and
where something stops happening,

536
00:27:44.637 --> 00:27:47.990
well then you can actually go and
troubleshoot the right device.

537
00:27:47.990 --> 00:27:51.620
Or you can actually go, oh, what,
that didn't stop at a device.

538
00:27:51.620 --> 00:27:55.550
The program is telling me
that I'm not getting this.

539
00:27:55.550 --> 00:27:58.830
And then you know that it actually
is up here at the application layer.

540
00:27:58.830 --> 00:28:01.440
So there's a lot of different
ways that this model itself and

541
00:28:01.440 --> 00:28:05.440
understand what function at each layer
can really assist us in troubleshooting.

542
00:28:05.440 --> 00:28:09.680
>> Yeah, the good news is for this exam,
you don't have to be a networking master.

543
00:28:09.680 --> 00:28:10.890
Right?
You don't have to be like

544
00:28:10.890 --> 00:28:15.010
oh I know all the IEEE specifications for
all these different things and

545
00:28:15.010 --> 00:28:16.680
I know RFCs and [LAUGH] that.

546
00:28:16.680 --> 00:28:19.240
It's very technical stuff you
don't have to be that level.

547
00:28:19.240 --> 00:28:22.610
This is all about you learning
how networks work and

548
00:28:22.610 --> 00:28:24.740
just having a good basic foundation.

549
00:28:24.740 --> 00:28:28.410
So all you really need to do is say okay,
I see DNS over there.

550
00:28:28.410 --> 00:28:29.020
Right?

551
00:28:29.020 --> 00:28:30.260
It's an application.

552
00:28:30.260 --> 00:28:33.460
It's a network application for
me and kind of know what it does.

553
00:28:33.460 --> 00:28:35.230
You don't have to be a master at it,

554
00:28:35.230 --> 00:28:38.610
you're just gonna have to understand
what works at each level.

555
00:28:38.610 --> 00:28:42.140
Get a few examples under your belt so
that you have a good reference for

556
00:28:42.140 --> 00:28:44.460
yourself to get into networking.

557
00:28:44.460 --> 00:28:48.640
And when someone starts talking about
it you have a conversation with Ronnie.

558
00:28:48.640 --> 00:28:52.590
He's like yeah, you know, my network
card is giving me real problems.

559
00:28:52.590 --> 00:28:55.710
I'm seeing double MAC
addresses on my network,

560
00:28:55.710 --> 00:28:56.870
I don't know why that's happening.

561
00:28:56.870 --> 00:28:58.180
You kind of understand
what's going on there.

562
00:28:58.180 --> 00:28:59.910
Okay, well we're at layer two,

563
00:28:59.910 --> 00:29:04.020
so obviously there's a physical
address issue on his network.

564
00:29:04.020 --> 00:29:06.140
I wonder why that's happening,
very strange?

565
00:29:06.140 --> 00:29:07.760
You've got an idea of what's happening.

566
00:29:07.760 --> 00:29:10.000
It is not just hey, oh!

567
00:29:10.000 --> 00:29:11.815
That's nice, Ronnie.

568
00:29:11.815 --> 00:29:13.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's where you wanna get,

569
00:29:13.060 --> 00:29:16.480
that's all you need to do, and Ronnie,
this is really good stuff, right?

570
00:29:16.480 --> 00:29:17.080
>> It really is.

571
00:29:17.080 --> 00:29:20.045
It's something that is
incredibly important.

572
00:29:20.045 --> 00:29:23.480
And it doesn't seem that important at
the beginning of your networking career,

573
00:29:23.480 --> 00:29:26.611
because it just seems like it's a lot
of stuff that you just have to know and

574
00:29:26.611 --> 00:29:27.610
memorize.

575
00:29:27.610 --> 00:29:29.030
But the more that you get into networking,

576
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:34.030
the more that you start thinking this way,
when things do not go right in networking.

577
00:29:34.030 --> 00:29:36.700
And if you do at least know that model and
go all right,

578
00:29:36.700 --> 00:29:40.980
I stopped at layer three, you know, then I
know I need to troubleshoot at the router

579
00:29:40.980 --> 00:29:45.020
at least look at the packets at the router
and figure out what's going on there.

580
00:29:45.020 --> 00:29:51.044
So, this OSI model, the TCP/IP model, and
even the basic protocols and devices and

581
00:29:51.044 --> 00:29:56.834
applications that work on these layers,
are really important foundationally.

582
00:29:56.834 --> 00:29:59.776
And even if you don't understand
everything like Daniel said,

583
00:29:59.776 --> 00:30:03.481
it really does help at least to know that
when somebody says switches that you know

584
00:30:03.481 --> 00:30:04.830
that's layer two.

585
00:30:04.830 --> 00:30:08.580
Or when somebody says layer three you know
it's routers, or layer one it's hubs and

586
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:10.090
cables or connectors.

587
00:30:10.090 --> 00:30:13.150
Those are really gonna be foundational
to help you out with the exam,

588
00:30:13.150 --> 00:30:14.890
to the nth degree is
what they're gonna do.

589
00:30:14.890 --> 00:30:15.780
>> That's right.

590
00:30:15.780 --> 00:30:16.440
Well guess what?

591
00:30:16.440 --> 00:30:17.810
It's not the end of networking.

592
00:30:17.810 --> 00:30:22.230
There's plenty, plenty more for
us to discuss, but our time is elapsed,

593
00:30:22.230 --> 00:30:26.620
Ronnie, great demonstrations, thanks for
the great diagrams you also have.

594
00:30:26.620 --> 00:30:27.820
All the good explanations as well.

595
00:30:27.820 --> 00:30:31.260
Hopefully you guys are following along and
getting that understanding.

596
00:30:31.260 --> 00:30:33.660
If you're not, you know what,
just watch the episode over and

597
00:30:33.660 --> 00:30:37.850
over again until it starts beating itself
in your head and you got it under control.

598
00:30:37.850 --> 00:30:40.040
But Ronnie, we're gonna have to
make a part two to this guy,

599
00:30:40.040 --> 00:30:41.410
hopefully we'll see you guys there.

600
00:30:41.410 --> 00:30:43.220
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

601
00:30:43.220 --> 00:30:45.080
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

602
00:30:45.080 --> 00:30:45.756
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

603
00:30:45.756 --> 00:30:46.943
>> And we'll see ya next time.

604
00:30:46.943 --> 00:30:53.090
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue networking basics by explaining two of the most fundamental protocols used in networks; the Transport Control Protocol (TCP) and the User Datagram Protocol (UDP). They also explain the use of different networking ports and their associated port numbers. All very important to anyone wishing to understand computer networks.
episodes.title: OSI Model Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.750
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.750 --> 00:00:10.971
All right.

3
00:00:10.971 --> 00:00:14.750
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:16.720
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:17.880
Here with me in the studio yet

6
00:00:17.880 --> 00:00:21.710
again today is the networking
guru himself, Ronald Wong.

7
00:00:21.710 --> 00:00:22.720
How's it going today Ronnie?

8
00:00:22.720 --> 00:00:24.250
>> I am doing well today.

9
00:00:24.250 --> 00:00:27.100
I don't know where I was going,
but I am doing well today.

10
00:00:27.100 --> 00:00:30.420
We are taking a look at
the MTAV Microsoft Technology Associate,

11
00:00:32.280 --> 00:00:34.650
the 98366 exam about
networking fundamentals.

12
00:00:34.650 --> 00:00:38.160
Once again, Daniel and I are here
to put fun back into networking.

13
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:41.140
Daniels looking at me like,
no way is that actually happening.

14
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:42.690
But no, we're having a little bit of fun,

15
00:00:42.690 --> 00:00:46.870
because we've been talking a little
bit About the OSI model and

16
00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:50.830
we still have to continue on with that and
actually see where that takes us as well.

17
00:00:50.830 --> 00:00:54.290
And so there's a lot more for
us to take a look at.

18
00:00:54.290 --> 00:00:57.220
Understanding just the basics
is what we're really after.

19
00:00:57.220 --> 00:01:02.000
Making sure we have those foundational
ideas and concepts down is only going to

20
00:01:02.000 --> 00:01:05.290
help you out in networking in the future
and as things get more complicated, right?

21
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:08.540
>> Yeah and even though this is a server
exam, and you're thinking, wow,

22
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:11.190
why are we learning networking
stuff if it's all about servers?

23
00:01:11.190 --> 00:01:14.470
Well, there are services
normally that you're

24
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:16.900
going to be doing as
a server administrator.

25
00:01:16.900 --> 00:01:20.580
But in this day and age, you just can't
get away with not knowing networking.

26
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:23.440
You have to know how these things connect,
you have to know how they talk, how

27
00:01:23.440 --> 00:01:27.070
they're supposed to react, how they send
messages to each other back and forth.

28
00:01:27.070 --> 00:01:31.540
So having a good fundamental understanding
of networking, very, very important.

29
00:01:31.540 --> 00:01:34.200
Now Ronnie, we're going to continue
moving along this little train

30
00:01:34.200 --> 00:01:38.470
with my favorite topic when
it comes to networking.

31
00:01:38.470 --> 00:01:42.360
TCP versus UDP, the bash of protocols.

32
00:01:42.360 --> 00:01:43.160
>> You better believe it.

33
00:01:43.160 --> 00:01:46.930
So let's take a look at what we had
just discussed in a previous episode,

34
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:49.980
just briefly, about the communication
process, and then we'll see

35
00:01:49.980 --> 00:01:53.750
where this bash of protocols that
Daniel's talking about fits in for us.

36
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:57.120
So on my screen I went ahead and created
this diagram to help us to understand

37
00:01:57.120 --> 00:02:00.260
the overall communication process
when you start seeing this.

38
00:02:00.260 --> 00:02:02.740
If the left-hand side
represents a sending computer,

39
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:06.320
the right-hand side represents
the destination computer, remember that

40
00:02:06.320 --> 00:02:10.640
this is how the OSI model really does
help us to establish this communication.

41
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:14.390
As we're sending data outbound,
it's going to continue to add more and

42
00:02:14.390 --> 00:02:17.410
more information to all
of the data that we have

43
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:20.720
until it's ready to be send across a wire.

44
00:02:20.720 --> 00:02:23.300
So this is the part that
we call encapsulation,

45
00:02:23.300 --> 00:02:25.030
is what we are taking a look at here.

46
00:02:25.030 --> 00:02:28.810
It gets put out on the wire and
then on the other side of that wire

47
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:33.810
some device is going to say, hey that
piece of data belongs to me, and that's

48
00:02:33.810 --> 00:02:38.630
where it gets processed at the data link
layer and moves up to the network layer,

49
00:02:38.630 --> 00:02:43.880
then takes a look source and destination,
or the proper destination IP address.

50
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:47.540
And then the transport layer are all
the pieces there that I need?

51
00:02:47.540 --> 00:02:50.410
Or do I need some more information,
and then the session try and

52
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:52.660
make sure it came from
who it said it came from.

53
00:02:52.660 --> 00:02:55.000
See if there is any more data
that actually needs to come in.

54
00:02:55.000 --> 00:02:59.490
And then the presentation beginning
look at formatting, and then of course

55
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:04.020
the application that's ultimately going
to end up opening that piece of data.

56
00:03:04.020 --> 00:03:05.560
Now the reason why this is important and

57
00:03:05.560 --> 00:03:11.060
fundamental to what Daniel talked about
in TCP/IP is because we do have a couple

58
00:03:11.060 --> 00:03:15.150
of different types of communication
processes that we have to understand.

59
00:03:15.150 --> 00:03:17.670
Some data is perfectly fine
just sending it out and

60
00:03:17.670 --> 00:03:21.330
putting it out onto the network and
it doesn't matter who gets the data.

61
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:24.487
And the very end as long as the data
that actually gets out there,

62
00:03:24.487 --> 00:03:28.055
the destination says yep, just keep
sending data and I'll take it, and

63
00:03:28.055 --> 00:03:29.710
it doesn't have to do anything.

64
00:03:29.710 --> 00:03:33.961
But some data wants to ensure that all
of the data is going to get there, so

65
00:03:33.961 --> 00:03:38.841
before any data is actually transmitted
between these two, what ends up happening

66
00:03:38.841 --> 00:03:43.232
is that they go ahead and they do
a little bit of communication beforehand,

67
00:03:43.232 --> 00:03:47.730
which they talk and they agree and
they synchronize before any data is sent.

68
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:51.360
And this is where we are talking
about what Dan was mentioning here,

69
00:03:51.360 --> 00:03:56.330
which is the difference between TCP,
transmission control protocol,

70
00:03:56.330 --> 00:03:59.930
and UDP, which is user datagram protocol.

71
00:03:59.930 --> 00:04:03.640
So all the data that you and I put out on
the network is going to be one of these

72
00:04:03.640 --> 00:04:07.570
two, well different types of data is
what's going to end up happening.

73
00:04:07.570 --> 00:04:11.390
It's either going to be based on TCP or
on UDP.

74
00:04:11.390 --> 00:04:13.530
TCP is by far about 80,

75
00:04:13.530 --> 00:04:19.350
I would say maybe even higher, than 80%
of all of the traffic that we send.

76
00:04:19.350 --> 00:04:22.630
Now when we start talking about that,
what does that actually mean?

77
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:27.210
It means that if this is going to be
a TCP type of connection that we need

78
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:30.020
It means that the sending machine
over here on the left-hand side and

79
00:04:30.020 --> 00:04:33.650
the destination machine
they must synchronize.

80
00:04:33.650 --> 00:04:36.580
In other words make sure that
they're ready for the data.

81
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:40.570
So what happens in between here is
what we call a three-way handshake.

82
00:04:40.570 --> 00:04:43.570
In TCP communication, the first machine,

83
00:04:43.570 --> 00:04:49.530
the sending machine sends a sig message or
it's normally abbreviated as a send.

84
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:54.350
So they send that telling the other
device that I am ready to synchronize

85
00:04:54.350 --> 00:04:57.960
with you because there's data
that needs to be transmitted.

86
00:04:57.960 --> 00:05:03.400
Well the receiving machine at that
point then acknowledges that hey,

87
00:05:03.400 --> 00:05:05.910
I got your synchronization message, but

88
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:09.760
if we're going to synchronize,
I also need to synchronize with you, so

89
00:05:09.760 --> 00:05:14.760
it sends it's same message back
to that original sending machine.

90
00:05:14.760 --> 00:05:18.790
And then the last time here,
on that three way handshake as

91
00:05:18.790 --> 00:05:23.370
the original sending machine acknowledges
that it received the same message.

92
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:26.156
And once that's done and
both sides are now synched up,

93
00:05:26.156 --> 00:05:31.350
what is going to happen is now data
can be transmitted between them.

94
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:35.770
So it's not going to put any data out onto
that network to send to some destination

95
00:05:35.770 --> 00:05:40.960
machine if it can't guarantee that
the data is going to be received.

96
00:05:40.960 --> 00:05:43.900
So that's where you do end up getting
a lot of times what they call

97
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:45.740
guaranteed delivery.

98
00:05:45.740 --> 00:05:46.760
Now, when you start talking about it,

99
00:05:46.760 --> 00:05:49.150
you might be wondering like how
in the world does that relate?

100
00:05:49.150 --> 00:05:51.170
How do I associate that
with something that I know?

101
00:05:51.170 --> 00:05:53.210
Well, let's take, for
an example, a telephone call.

102
00:05:53.210 --> 00:05:58.890
That's probably the easiest way that you
and I can actually describe TCP, right?

103
00:05:58.890 --> 00:06:02.160
So at the very beginning,
I dial your phone number.

104
00:06:02.160 --> 00:06:03.160
Well, what is happening?

105
00:06:03.160 --> 00:06:06.130
Well we are beginning the process
of synchronization at the very

106
00:06:06.130 --> 00:06:07.310
beginning, right?

107
00:06:07.310 --> 00:06:12.170
So when I call and you pick it up, and you
say hello, this is, whoever it might be.

108
00:06:12.170 --> 00:06:13.150
Let's say it's Daniel.

109
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:14.510
And Daniel says hello, this is Daniel.

110
00:06:15.600 --> 00:06:17.230
At that point, we are now starting.

111
00:06:17.230 --> 00:06:21.400
So my initial telephone call is
now sending that same message,

112
00:06:21.400 --> 00:06:24.120
Daniel is now acknowledging
when he picks up and

113
00:06:24.120 --> 00:06:28.040
says hello, he is acknowledging the very
fact that he received my synchronization.

114
00:06:28.040 --> 00:06:29.970
And if Daniel were to saying
something like hello,

115
00:06:29.970 --> 00:06:34.030
this is Daniel, how may I help you, he's
essentially saying, well let's sync up and

116
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:36.340
understand that we're on the same
page in this communication.

117
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:41.750
And that process, that's when I can say,
hey thanks for answering Daniel.

118
00:06:41.750 --> 00:06:42.890
Here's is what I need.

119
00:06:42.890 --> 00:06:45.500
Well, it's actually that thank you for

120
00:06:45.500 --> 00:06:47.740
answering that I'm doing
in the acknowledgment.

121
00:06:47.740 --> 00:06:50.690
So, at that point in that telephone
call we are now synchronized.

122
00:06:50.690 --> 00:06:51.830
We're on the same page.

123
00:06:51.830 --> 00:06:55.160
And hopefully that means Daniel and I are
actually having the same conversation, and

124
00:06:55.160 --> 00:06:58.040
he's not there distracted by
somebody else in the room, but we're

125
00:06:58.040 --> 00:07:01.790
actually communicating because what I have
now is hopefully Daniel's full attention,

126
00:07:01.790 --> 00:07:03.050
is what I'm trying to get.

127
00:07:03.050 --> 00:07:06.550
>> Yeah, the telephone conversation is
actually a really good illustration

128
00:07:06.550 --> 00:07:08.260
of the TCP protocol itself, or

129
00:07:08.260 --> 00:07:10.240
the TCP protocol--
>> Yep.

130
00:07:10.240 --> 00:07:12.420
>> the Transmission Control Protocol
protocol

131
00:07:12.420 --> 00:07:13.880
>> I always enjoy those kind of

132
00:07:13.880 --> 00:07:17.790
weird idioms of the English language,
but that's exactly what happens, right?

133
00:07:17.790 --> 00:07:19.540
He dials the phone,
I pick it up, what do I say?

134
00:07:19.540 --> 00:07:21.510
I say hello, right?

135
00:07:21.510 --> 00:07:22.110
What does Ronnie do?

136
00:07:22.110 --> 00:07:25.490
Does he just start going, on the 5th
of November you're going to start, no,

137
00:07:25.490 --> 00:07:27.700
he doesn't start hitting
me with information.

138
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:28.620
He replies right back.

139
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:29.320
"Hey!

140
00:07:29.320 --> 00:07:33.020
How's it going?" That lets me know who
it is on the other end of the line.

141
00:07:33.020 --> 00:07:35.020
I recognize Ronnie's voice.

142
00:07:35.020 --> 00:07:36.490
He knows that I've picked up.

143
00:07:36.490 --> 00:07:40.580
And now that we've established the fact

So let's go ahead and

00:27:55.770 --> 00:27:58.110
So if we take a look at the OSI model,

00:27:58.110 --> 00:28:02.200
now once again you see where it actually

00:28:02.200 --> 00:28:05.820
Well the way that we describe
the data along the OSI model

558
00:28:05.820 --> 00:28:07.660
normally comes like this.

559
00:28:07.660 --> 00:28:09.760
Up here in these upper three layers,

560
00:28:09.760 --> 00:28:12.880
everything is really
considered data at this point.

561
00:28:12.880 --> 00:28:15.590
And the reason why it's considered
data at this point is that

562
00:28:15.590 --> 00:28:20.250
even though these upper three layers help
repair that data to be put out in network,

563
00:28:20.250 --> 00:28:24.480
it really has nothing to do with
the overall delivery of that data.

564
00:28:24.480 --> 00:28:25.130
In other words,

565
00:28:25.130 --> 00:28:29.420
there's none of this information that
says here's how the data can be moved.

566
00:28:29.420 --> 00:28:32.430
Here's how the data breaks
up into little pieces.

567
00:28:32.430 --> 00:28:36.610
Here's the way that the data actually
knows it's arrived at its destination.

568
00:28:36.610 --> 00:28:40.630
So, at that point then,
what we have here is just regular data.

569
00:28:40.630 --> 00:28:45.960
Now, along that right, as you start
sending data outbound from your machine,

570
00:28:45.960 --> 00:28:49.910
and I don't know why everything keeps
kinda making me move up or down, but

571
00:28:49.910 --> 00:28:53.200
it does,
as you start sending data along that path.

572
00:28:53.200 --> 00:28:54.000
Right?

573
00:28:54.000 --> 00:28:58.040
When you start sending data out,
I talked about the term encapsulation.

574
00:28:58.040 --> 00:29:01.940
And that's because each layer adds
in a little bit of information.

575
00:29:01.940 --> 00:29:06.820
So it keeps stacking it up around the
actual data that existed on your computer.

576
00:29:06.820 --> 00:29:09.230
So what ends up happening at some point.

577
00:29:09.230 --> 00:29:11.670
If I can go back, oh there it goes.

578
00:29:11.670 --> 00:29:13.590
Where I can go back down here.

579
00:29:13.590 --> 00:29:16.680
When it gets down to that point
where now we are talking about

580
00:29:16.680 --> 00:29:19.470
what is responsible for
delivering the data.

581
00:29:19.470 --> 00:29:21.160
This is where you start seeing it.

582
00:29:21.160 --> 00:29:24.490
So, inside of the data
chunk you have here,

583
00:29:24.490 --> 00:29:27.050
you end up adding in
what we call a header.

584
00:29:27.050 --> 00:29:30.150
And that header here,
you see is called layer four.

585
00:29:30.150 --> 00:29:33.800
And it's here that they
call it a segment of data.

586
00:29:33.800 --> 00:29:38.460
And then, when it is ready to send out and
have addressing put on it, well then,

587
00:29:38.460 --> 00:29:42.310
at layer three, notice they don't
strip away the layer four header.

588
00:29:42.310 --> 00:29:44.180
They add in more information.

589
00:29:44.180 --> 00:29:48.930
And then at layer two, this is actually
the data that is put out onto the wire.

590
00:29:48.930 --> 00:29:53.290
It becomes signal, it becomes bits,
ones and zeroes, on the wire itself.

591
00:29:53.290 --> 00:29:56.830
And you see where it also
added in a footer as well.

592
00:29:56.830 --> 00:30:00.640
And notice the three different terms,
and you do need to memorize this, right?

593
00:30:00.640 --> 00:30:03.550
At layer two, data is called a frame.

594
00:30:03.550 --> 00:30:08.010
At the layer three, data is called packets
at that point or the chunk that we

595
00:30:08.010 --> 00:30:12.580
send out, and then at the transport layer
it's just called a segment of data.

596
00:30:12.580 --> 00:30:17.790
So when we start delivering data from one
device to another, we're sending frames.

597
00:30:17.790 --> 00:30:21.350
When I need to find out did data
actually arrive at it's destination,

598
00:30:21.350 --> 00:30:24.010
I'm talking about a packet of information.

599
00:30:24.010 --> 00:30:27.260
And then if I'm talking about
breaking the data up to be sent, and

600
00:30:27.260 --> 00:30:30.320
whether or not I received all of
the data on the receiving machine.

601
00:30:30.320 --> 00:30:34.200
I'm talking about the segments of
data that I'm actually receiving.

602
00:30:34.200 --> 00:30:36.570
So those are technical terms, and

603
00:30:36.570 --> 00:30:40.210
even though we tend to use packet
in everything that we describe,

604
00:30:40.210 --> 00:30:44.840
this is the technicality that you will
actually face at some point in time.

605
00:30:44.840 --> 00:30:49.530
So when you receive that data, think about
what also happens at the receiving end.

606
00:30:49.530 --> 00:30:51.960
It first takes a look at this frame, and

607
00:30:51.960 --> 00:30:56.180
if that destination mac address says,
hey, that's mine.

608
00:30:56.180 --> 00:30:57.450
It processes to Layer 2,

609
00:30:57.450 --> 00:31:01.190
and then it hands it up to Layer
3 on that receiving machine.

610
00:31:01.190 --> 00:31:04.360
And the receiving machine says,
hey, that's my IP address.

611
00:31:04.360 --> 00:31:05.810
It processes that.

612
00:31:05.810 --> 00:31:09.000
And now the data's not going to
actually go anywhere else because

613
00:31:09.000 --> 00:31:12.110
the addressing has now been taken off and
then it can process whether or

614
00:31:12.110 --> 00:31:14.280
not we actually have
all the pieces of data.

615
00:31:14.280 --> 00:31:16.310
Or do I need to request data to be resent?

616
00:31:16.310 --> 00:31:19.000
Or do I need to request
the next bit to be resent?

617
00:31:19.000 --> 00:31:21.830
And it actually continues
to process all the way up,

618
00:31:21.830 --> 00:31:23.690
until the point where it
hits the application.

619
00:31:23.690 --> 00:31:27.520
And then, I'm on that computer
receiving it and reading it.

620
00:31:27.520 --> 00:31:29.600
But, yeah,
you do have to know those terms.

621
00:31:29.600 --> 00:31:34.130
Frames, packets, and
segments in the end for the terminology.

622
00:31:34.130 --> 00:31:38.680
And that's also another kind
of gotcha on networking,

623
00:31:38.680 --> 00:31:42.680
is not only are there port numbers, there
is a whole bunch of terminologies, and we

624
00:31:42.680 --> 00:31:45.760
haven't even gotten into all the acronyms
that we'll be facing in the future.

625
00:31:45.760 --> 00:31:48.100
>> Yeah.
Now you see why systems administration is

626
00:31:48.100 --> 00:31:50.980
a whole lot more easy than
network administration.

627
00:31:50.980 --> 00:31:54.980
There's so much more, well, there's a lot
of technical aspects to networking.

628
00:31:54.980 --> 00:31:59.870
I do love the whole idea of packets,
and frames, and segments, because,

629
00:31:59.870 --> 00:32:04.800
basically, what all it's telling you is,
if I have a segment, right?

630
00:32:04.800 --> 00:32:09.580
It's letting me know that only that layer
five type of talking needs to occur.

631
00:32:09.580 --> 00:32:14.070
It's all the other data is just kind of
like put inside of the segment, sealed up,

632
00:32:14.070 --> 00:32:16.660
and it says all that you need
to know about this segment

633
00:32:16.660 --> 00:32:18.650
is right here on
the segment header itself.

634
00:32:18.650 --> 00:32:21.080
And that can deal with it and
can pass it on accordingly.

635
00:32:21.080 --> 00:32:24.070
If it needs to get into layer four,
not a problem.

636
00:32:24.070 --> 00:32:26.040
It strips that segment,
opens the segment up and

637
00:32:26.040 --> 00:32:27.700
says let me see the layer four data.

638
00:32:27.700 --> 00:32:29.500
Oh, okay, there it is right there.

639
00:32:29.500 --> 00:32:31.170
Now I can pass it on accordingly.

640
00:32:31.170 --> 00:32:33.490
So each one of those
different types of maps, and

641
00:32:33.490 --> 00:32:37.070
that's why we differentiate
between segments and frames.

642
00:32:37.070 --> 00:32:38.840
What device needs this, right?

643
00:32:38.840 --> 00:32:42.840
If I have a device that works on layer
two, a switch or a abridge, right?

644
00:32:42.840 --> 00:32:44.450
Those are layer two devices.

645
00:32:44.450 --> 00:32:46.540
They don't care about IP.

646
00:32:46.540 --> 00:32:52.700
They have no idea or care about IP at all,
and that is a layer three protocol.

647
00:32:52.700 --> 00:32:57.060
So they just deal with that
lovely little data links that's,

648
00:32:57.060 --> 00:32:59.055
can't think of it now,
blew out of my head.

649
00:32:59.055 --> 00:33:00.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, what's the.

650
00:33:00.420 --> 00:33:01.310
>> Data link layer?

651
00:33:01.310 --> 00:33:02.230
>> Yeah.
>> Networking layer?

652
00:33:02.230 --> 00:33:02.760
>> The frame.

653
00:33:02.760 --> 00:33:03.290
>> Frame.

654
00:33:03.290 --> 00:33:03.900
Oh frame, sorry.

655
00:33:03.900 --> 00:33:04.885
>> Yeah, frames, yes.

656
00:33:04.885 --> 00:33:05.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> As you can see,

657
00:33:05.780 --> 00:33:07.570
it gets really confusing at this point.

658
00:33:07.570 --> 00:33:09.120
All they care about is that frame.

659
00:33:09.120 --> 00:33:10.860
So that's all it's gonna look at.

660
00:33:10.860 --> 00:33:14.720
If it needs anything else, it'll dive into
it, but other than that, it just wants to

661
00:33:14.720 --> 00:33:18.040
work with those frames and pass them
along through its layer 2 network.

662
00:33:18.040 --> 00:33:20.900
If it needs to go somewhere else,
it'll look at those headers and

663
00:33:20.900 --> 00:33:24.700
pass it along to the device that utilizes
those different types of headers,

664
00:33:24.700 --> 00:33:26.570
making it very much segmented, right.

665
00:33:26.570 --> 00:33:29.654
>> There is no doubt that this
is an important concept here.

666
00:33:29.654 --> 00:33:34.440
So our beginning foray, right,
is just understanding that there has to be

667
00:33:34.440 --> 00:33:38.080
communication that goes on between two
devices, and the way that they've arrived

668
00:33:38.080 --> 00:33:39.980
at that today,
because we all have different devices,

669
00:33:39.980 --> 00:33:42.790
is that they've come up with
a network communication model.

670
00:33:42.790 --> 00:33:45.770
And even that breaks down of course
into portions of ports and protocols.

671
00:33:45.770 --> 00:33:48.240
Break down into the type of traffic
that we're actually doing, so

672
00:33:48.240 --> 00:33:52.180
that we all get the data that we need when
we're sending data inside of that network.

673
00:33:52.180 --> 00:33:56.160
So there's a lot more information to go,
but that's a good foundational level for

674
00:33:56.160 --> 00:33:56.710
us to be at.

675
00:33:56.710 --> 00:33:58.920
>> That's right.
All right, Ronnie, thanks a lot for that.

676
00:33:58.920 --> 00:34:01.310
You did a great job explaining this to us,

677
00:34:01.310 --> 00:34:03.030
even though it is
a little bit complicated.

678
00:34:03.030 --> 00:34:06.405
Just take you a little bit of time, watch
these episodes a couple of times, and

679
00:34:06.405 --> 00:34:07.675
it'll start to sink in.

680
00:34:07.675 --> 00:34:09.075
It'll start to make sense and

681
00:34:09.075 --> 00:34:12.560
you will one day become networking master,
much like my friend Ronnie here.

682
00:34:12.560 --> 00:34:13.475
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right Ronnie,

683
00:34:13.475 --> 00:34:14.895
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

684
00:34:14.895 --> 00:34:16.435
Thanks for watching this episode.

685
00:34:16.435 --> 00:34:18.125
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

686
00:34:18.125 --> 00:34:19.875
I've been your host, Daniel Lowery.

687
00:34:19.875 --> 00:34:20.595
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

688
00:34:20.595 --> 00:34:22.825
>> And we'll see you next time.

689
00:34:22.825 --> 00:34:28.090
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain IP addressing which is necessary for connecting devices on a network. They cover all the major bases involved in IP addressing such as the addresses themselves, subnet masks, and gateways; what they are and how they are used to connect devices.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.459
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.459 --> 00:00:11.421
All right.

3
00:00:11.421 --> 00:00:14.990
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.990 --> 00:00:16.230
I'm your host Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:19.120
Here with me in the studio, yet
again today, is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.120 --> 00:00:20.350
How's it going Ronnie?

7
00:00:20.350 --> 00:00:21.580
>> It is going well today.

8
00:00:21.580 --> 00:00:23.398
It's another great day that we
get to be right here in studio.

9
00:00:23.398 --> 00:00:26.099
And we're taking a look at
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

10
00:00:26.099 --> 00:00:30.330
The 98-366 exam on
networking fundamentals.

11
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:33.230
Yes, I actually remembered that whole
thing without actually messing up.

12
00:00:33.230 --> 00:00:36.335
Putting the fun back in networking,
that's what Daniel and I are doing.

13
00:00:36.335 --> 00:00:38.850
[LAUGH] Is we're going to put
the fun back in networking.

14
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:42.460
And today, we're taking a look at well,
IP addressing.

15
00:00:42.460 --> 00:00:44.550
In previous episodes,
we took a look at the OSI model,

16
00:00:44.550 --> 00:00:48.530
which truly does help us to understand the
concept of communication between devices.

17
00:00:48.530 --> 00:00:51.090
But when we start to
actually have to send data

18
00:00:51.090 --> 00:00:54.340
well the foundational aspect of that is
going to be IP addressing right Daniel.

19
00:00:54.340 --> 00:00:54.890
>> That's right.

20
00:00:54.890 --> 00:00:58.300
Without an IP address I can't get
data to go where I want it to go.

21
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:00.490
It's just like a letter
out in the mail system.

22
00:01:00.490 --> 00:01:04.075
I gotta have an address to send it to or
it's going nowhere real fast.

23
00:01:04.075 --> 00:01:06.825
Same thing with our computers,
you've gotta have a way of differentiating

24
00:01:06.825 --> 00:01:11.805
how to send data from one computer or
another based off of some sort of address.

25
00:01:11.805 --> 00:01:16.235
IP addressing is what the standard is for
today's computer networks and

26
00:01:16.235 --> 00:01:18.050
Ronnie says we're gonna
put the fun back into it.

27
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:20.065
>> [LAUGH]
>> We sure need to because

28
00:01:20.065 --> 00:01:23.735
it can definitely be a little daunting
if you've never seen this stuff before,

29
00:01:23.735 --> 00:01:25.650
it can be a little difficult.

30
00:01:25.650 --> 00:01:27.522
But we're gonna try to
help you through that.

31
00:01:27.522 --> 00:01:29.230
[LAUGH] Ronnie is a master at this stuff.

32
00:01:29.230 --> 00:01:30.380
I've seen him at work.

33
00:01:30.380 --> 00:01:34.122
You're going to be mystified at his
ability to explain this, right, Ronnie?

34
00:01:34.122 --> 00:01:35.201
>> I doubt it but [LAUGH]-
>> And go.

35
00:01:35.201 --> 00:01:38.140
[LAUGH]
>> That ends up working for us but when we

36
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.550
start taking a look at IP addressing, it
is a little bit more of the dry material.

37
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:46.370
That we have to understand that we're
gonna be doing networking at all.

38
00:01:46.370 --> 00:01:48.480
And it is so foundational.

39
00:01:48.480 --> 00:01:51.760
If we don't understand this concept,
a lot of everything else that we

40
00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:55.810
try to build networking off of is
really not gonna make sense either.

41
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:58.990
So when we start talking about that
idea of IP addressing, there's really

42
00:01:58.990 --> 00:02:03.780
two different versions of it that you and
I are going to encounter right now.

43
00:02:03.780 --> 00:02:08.070
There's what we call IP version 4,
and also IP version 6.

44
00:02:08.070 --> 00:02:10.600
Now you might be wondering like
I did at some point, well,

45
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:15.030
what happened to version 1 and
version 5 and versions 1 through 3 and 5?

46
00:02:15.030 --> 00:02:15.850
Well, who knows?

47
00:02:15.850 --> 00:02:16.640
>> Leave those out, Ronnie.

48
00:02:16.640 --> 00:02:18.030
>> Yeah,
we don't really wanna get into them.

49
00:02:18.030 --> 00:02:19.010
>> Don't talk about those.

50
00:02:19.010 --> 00:02:22.036
>> But the functional ones that we
actually are dealing with today,

51
00:02:22.036 --> 00:02:24.908
of course are two of them,
the IP version 4 and IP version 6.

52
00:02:24.908 --> 00:02:27.612
Today we're gonna focus in on IPv4.

53
00:02:27.612 --> 00:02:31.660
And the reason why need to, it's still
the protocol that's being used today.

54
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:33.220
And I just use that word, protocol.

55
00:02:33.220 --> 00:02:34.980
And that's actually the key for us.

56
00:02:34.980 --> 00:02:38.580
Remember that when we start talking
then about being able to send data

57
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:40.310
from one machine to the other one,

58
00:02:40.310 --> 00:02:43.610
we end up using what we call
different protocols to help us out.

59
00:02:43.610 --> 00:02:46.310
Now, in those protocols,
right, we've heard other ones.

60
00:02:46.310 --> 00:02:49.460
We talked about TCP as well as UDP,

61
00:02:49.460 --> 00:02:54.650
the transmission control protocol as
well as the user datagram protocol.

62
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:57.710
And if you're going, now, I don't remember
seeing any of that in this episode.

63
00:02:57.710 --> 00:03:01.060
Well, that's because we did have another
episode where we did talk about those.

64
00:03:01.060 --> 00:03:05.290
Well, those are protocols, and protocols
are essentially rules that we use so

65
00:03:05.290 --> 00:03:08.480
that we know we're gonna be able
to send data back and forth.

66
00:03:08.480 --> 00:03:13.070
Well, the most important protocol that
you and I end up using to transmit data

67
00:03:13.070 --> 00:03:18.070
from source to destination is gonna be
what we call an IP version 4 address.

68
00:03:18.070 --> 00:03:22.250
Now that address has been around for
a long, long time.

69
00:03:22.250 --> 00:03:25.760
So long and that we've actually
used up all the addresses so

70
00:03:25.760 --> 00:03:29.600
much so that we really did have to
come up with a new version of that,

71
00:03:29.600 --> 00:03:31.350
which is going to be IP version six.

72
00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:34.730
And we will have another segment
in which we'll deal with that one.

73
00:03:34.730 --> 00:03:37.720
But at this point here, we want to
understand that we're going to actually

74
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:42.360
talk about specifically IP version
four is what we want to talk about.

75
00:03:42.360 --> 00:03:46.730
So, when I emphasize a very factor of this
protocol, I cannot over emphasize that it

76
00:03:46.730 --> 00:03:51.210
is the most important protocol
that you and I will learn about.

77
00:03:51.210 --> 00:03:55.010
If you're new to networking, this is where
it gets a little more confusing, because

78
00:03:55.010 --> 00:03:59.190
now we're starting to deal with numbers
and addresses that we have to worry about.

79
00:03:59.190 --> 00:04:02.360
And we also start dealing with concepts
that we may not have actually dealt with

80
00:04:02.360 --> 00:04:05.080
before, such as binary numbering as well.

81
00:04:05.080 --> 00:04:07.870
And so we do need to talk
a little bit about that.

82
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:10.890
So let me go ahead and show some of
the bullet points that I made on my screen

83
00:04:10.890 --> 00:04:14.080
to try and help us out to understand
what we're seeing it, right?

84
00:04:14.080 --> 00:04:17.240
So, remember, it's the most important
protocol that we use in networking by far

85
00:04:17.240 --> 00:04:18.540
of all the ones,

86
00:04:18.540 --> 00:04:22.340
if I want to send data from me to you,
I have to have your IP address.

87
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:24.000
It's not because I need
to know what it is,

88
00:04:24.000 --> 00:04:26.320
it's because my machine
needs to know what it is.

89
00:04:26.320 --> 00:04:29.240
So even if you're sitting out there on
the Internet somewhere and I'm here in my

90
00:04:29.240 --> 00:04:33.790
office, if I want to get data from me to
you it has to be out there somewhere.

91
00:04:33.790 --> 00:04:38.075
Then, this actually It represents what
we call a pool of addresses here.

92
00:04:38.075 --> 00:04:41.415
In IP version 4 there's
a pool of addresses,

93
00:04:41.415 --> 00:04:44.965
it's actually two to
the 32nd power in size.

94
00:04:44.965 --> 00:04:48.415
Now if you're like me and
you don't know a lot about binary,

95
00:04:48.415 --> 00:04:51.665
there are some things that you
do need to pay attention to and

96
00:04:51.665 --> 00:04:55.615
that is actually going to be how big
this pool of numbers really is which is

97
00:04:55.615 --> 00:05:01.460
a little bit under 4.3 billion
possible numbers that we can use.

98
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:05.373
Now when we start you go,
man, that's a large number.

99
00:05:05.373 --> 00:05:08.840
That is an incredible number,
if you're actually gonna use that.

100
00:05:08.840 --> 00:05:15.500
But the very fact is, in today,
the time of the recording

101
00:05:15.500 --> 00:05:20.710
of our episode today those numbers have
now been depleted on the Internet.

102
00:05:20.710 --> 00:05:24.390
And what we mean by that is you
can't get any new ones out there.

103
00:05:24.390 --> 00:05:25.860
So they're not making up new ones.

104
00:05:25.860 --> 00:05:27.940
They're just saying hey, it's depleted.

105
00:05:27.940 --> 00:05:31.560
You can't get new addresses that aren't
already currently out there, and

106
00:05:31.560 --> 00:05:34.820
the limitation is up as of this point.

107
00:05:34.820 --> 00:05:39.050
So that actually means that what we have
to learn is a little bit more, right?

108
00:05:39.050 --> 00:05:42.080
It's not that there aren't any available,
it just means that they're not actually

109
00:05:42.080 --> 00:05:44.140
releasing any,
there's none actually left in reserve.

110
00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:47.750
Those last few have been assigned
out there and they are ready to go.

111
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:50.450
So that's the 4.3 billion,
and you might be going,

112
00:05:50.450 --> 00:05:54.200
how in the world did that end up being
that particular number and size?

113
00:05:54.200 --> 00:05:57.500
Well, it has to do with binary,
is what it has to do with.

114
00:05:57.500 --> 00:06:01.620
And the very fact is in binaries we're
just using a string of ones and zeros, and

115
00:06:01.620 --> 00:06:05.060
they decided 32 bits would be enough,
about 4.3 billion.

116
00:06:05.060 --> 00:06:08.830
And that's because at the time when this
started coming out, they thought about

117
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:13.170
the idea of how many addresses would
really need to be used over all.

118
00:06:13.170 --> 00:06:16.450
And right about 4 billion people were
on the planet at that point in time,

119
00:06:16.450 --> 00:06:19.190
and they thought, maybe if we
assigned a single IP address to every

120
00:06:19.190 --> 00:06:20.340
single person on the planet.

121
00:06:20.340 --> 00:06:21.220
That should be enough.

122
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:23.640
Why?
Not everybody's ever going to get

123
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:26.540
an IP address for
every single person on the planet.

124
00:06:26.540 --> 00:06:28.670
But, then they did
something silly which is,

125
00:06:28.670 --> 00:06:31.390
they started dividing it up when realized
that they weren't going to do that.

126
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:35.660
For big gigantic companies, medium large
companies, and then small companies,

127
00:06:35.660 --> 00:06:40.870
well, and all of a sudden, it started
eating up the space or these numbers.

128
00:06:40.870 --> 00:06:43.030
Very quickly too.

129
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:47.480
Now Daniel also made a more important
