00:20:06.749 --> 00:20:08.375
Yep, all right.

359
00:20:08.375 --> 00:20:12.995
Now when we start taking a look at
these addresses you might be wondering

360
00:20:12.995 --> 00:20:16.845
how in the world do we get these
number of hosts per network or

361
00:20:16.845 --> 00:20:19.542
number of devices per network, as well.

362
00:20:19.542 --> 00:20:24.332
And that's because, with an IP address,
that IP address represents two different

363
00:20:24.332 --> 00:20:27.041
portions, is what it represents here,
okay?

364
00:20:27.041 --> 00:20:31.360
So, an IP address is sorta
like a street address, right?

365
00:20:31.360 --> 00:20:35.780
If you live at 123 Main Street,
right, you have your house number and

366
00:20:35.780 --> 00:20:37.940
you have the street as well.

367
00:20:37.940 --> 00:20:39.580
So an IP address does the same thing.

368
00:20:39.580 --> 00:20:44.167
It's broken up into a network portion
as well as into a host portion of

369
00:20:44.167 --> 00:20:45.124
the address.

370
00:20:45.124 --> 00:20:48.850
So if I were to give an address for
example,

371
00:20:48.850 --> 00:20:53.613
let's take 192.168.1.0 as the address,

372
00:20:53.613 --> 00:21:00.667
normally there is following what's behind
it is what we call a subnet mask here.

373
00:21:00.667 --> 00:21:03.624
So let's say that we have an IP
address and we have a subnet mask.

374
00:21:03.624 --> 00:21:08.214
Rarely will you see an IP
address without a subnet mask,

375
00:21:08.214 --> 00:21:12.624
unless somebody actually
has typed it incorrectly.

376
00:21:12.624 --> 00:21:14.666
So you normally have something like this.

377
00:21:14.666 --> 00:21:21.374
So here's the IP address,
And here is the subnet mask.

378
00:21:21.374 --> 00:21:24.828
Well what we're focusing in
on now is actually this part

379
00:21:24.828 --> 00:21:27.410
which is the subnet mask itself.

380
00:21:27.410 --> 00:21:30.680
The reason why the subnet mask is
important is because it helps us to

381
00:21:30.680 --> 00:21:35.530
identify how many devices we can
actually hold on a single network.

382
00:21:35.530 --> 00:21:40.890
And so when we do that it actually does
eliminate the possibilities of how big

383
00:21:40.890 --> 00:21:45.210
this network is or how small this network
is and it really does help us out here.

384
00:21:45.210 --> 00:21:50.390
The process that it actually works
on is what we call binary anding.

385
00:21:50.390 --> 00:21:54.880
Now we don't really have to get into that
too much but what it does is it's able to

386
00:21:54.880 --> 00:22:00.660
take the network address itself and
mask it in this way.

387
00:22:00.660 --> 00:22:01.916
Let me see if I can grab that.

388
00:22:01.916 --> 00:22:04.582
>> And by mask, Ronnie, you're really
talking about filtering, right?

389
00:22:04.582 --> 00:22:05.207
>> That's it.

390
00:22:05.207 --> 00:22:08.744
>> We're filtering through the mask
to see what network are we on,

391
00:22:08.744 --> 00:22:11.690
how many devices can
actually be on that network.

392
00:22:11.690 --> 00:22:14.890
Kind of getting back up into that class A,
B, and C idea.

393
00:22:14.890 --> 00:22:20.200
Where am I at in regards to the other
networks that are available and

394
00:22:20.200 --> 00:22:21.590
the devices on those networks?

395
00:22:21.590 --> 00:22:23.620
So that's what we're talking about
when we come to subnet mask.

396
00:22:23.620 --> 00:22:27.130
>> There it is exactly the way
that Daniel is describing it.

397
00:22:27.130 --> 00:22:28.480
So I'm just trying to line these up so

398
00:22:28.480 --> 00:22:31.960
that we can at least
see the basics of this.

399
00:22:31.960 --> 00:22:36.520
So, when it comes down to it and the way
that the binary works, when we have

400
00:22:36.520 --> 00:22:40.750
this come out, when you have 255 and then
the number, well what ends up happening is

401
00:22:40.750 --> 00:22:46.475
that, that number actually can fall
through that line and the same thing here.

402
00:22:46.475 --> 00:22:50.490
168 falls through, and
then of course we have 001,

403
00:22:50.490 --> 00:22:54.820
and now that last one, the way that
the zeros work, is it filters it.

404
00:22:54.820 --> 00:22:58.720
It does not allow anything to
pass through it, is what happens.

405
00:22:58.720 --> 00:23:00.840
So it's right here that all of a sudden,
yes,

406
00:23:00.840 --> 00:23:04.340
you end up seeing,
well this number will actually change.

407
00:23:04.340 --> 00:23:08.764
So even if I put a one up here, well that
number would actually not come through,

408
00:23:08.764 --> 00:23:10.624
it'd actually be a 0 down here.

409
00:23:10.624 --> 00:23:15.700
Even if I put a 255 up there,
that number would actually still be a 0.

410
00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:22.380
So wherever that doesn't match, that
is now considered your network portion.

411
00:23:22.380 --> 00:23:27.550
So this is now where you actually do
have that division of that number.

412
00:23:27.550 --> 00:23:33.375
And so on the left-hand side, this is
gonna be what is called your network.

413
00:23:33.375 --> 00:23:34.291
I can't spell it.

414
00:23:34.291 --> 00:23:35.916
Network ID.

415
00:23:35.916 --> 00:23:40.791
And then to the right hand side of this,
you may hear the term host ID.

416
00:23:40.791 --> 00:23:44.438
So however many bits are left
out of that 32-bit address,

417
00:23:44.438 --> 00:23:47.666
that is how many devices you
can have on your network.

418
00:23:47.666 --> 00:23:51.791
So for example, on this side,
if I have 8 bits here,

419
00:23:51.791 --> 00:23:55.571
8 bits here, 8 bits here, that's 24 bits.

420
00:23:55.571 --> 00:23:57.570
Out of a 32 bit address.

421
00:23:57.570 --> 00:24:01.440
And that means there should be
eight bits represented here.

422
00:24:01.440 --> 00:24:05.430
Well, that network ID of two to

423
00:24:05.430 --> 00:24:10.340
the eight power really gives me 254,
256 combinations, so in theory,

424
00:24:10.340 --> 00:24:13.860
I am limited to just those
numbers on each network.

425
00:24:13.860 --> 00:24:16.700
So that subnet mask really
does help us to do that.

426
00:24:16.700 --> 00:24:20.500
So, if I take a look at my own machine,
right here, and

427
00:24:20.500 --> 00:24:27.330
I run a simple utility here,
called ipconfig.

428
00:24:27.330 --> 00:24:29.890
I can press Enter from
that command prompt.

429
00:24:29.890 --> 00:24:34.400
And when I do so, you can see and
here it is, here are the addresses.

430
00:24:34.400 --> 00:24:35.910
Oops, let me see if I can mark this.

431
00:24:37.290 --> 00:24:41.170
Here's the address and
the subnet mask, right here.

432
00:24:41.170 --> 00:24:46.230
So if I were to try and identify what
network that this device was on,

433
00:24:46.230 --> 00:24:51.870
I can then go ahead and
see that my network is 172.16.95 here,

434
00:24:51.870 --> 00:24:56.140
and notice this 12 and the zero and
it doesn't come through.

435
00:24:56.140 --> 00:25:01.350
So my network would actually be
the 172.16.95 network dot zero and

436
00:25:01.350 --> 00:25:05.420
then my machine would actually just be
one of those devices within that network.

437
00:25:05.420 --> 00:25:07.070
The same thing with
your street address and

438
00:25:07.070 --> 00:25:09.490
your house number,
whereas that last number there,

439
00:25:09.490 --> 00:25:13.620
that 12 would represent my house number
whereas this other part of this address

440
00:25:13.620 --> 00:25:17.000
would represent the street number as well,
and that's what networks really do.

441
00:25:17.000 --> 00:25:21.870
And the subnet mask is what helps them
to differentiate that portion from

442
00:25:21.870 --> 00:25:24.020
the actual host portion as well.

443
00:25:24.020 --> 00:25:26.225
So you have network ID,
you have host ID here.

444
00:25:26.225 --> 00:25:29.575
>> Yeah, to help flesh that out
practically, Ronnie's IP address,

445
00:25:29.575 --> 00:25:30.939
we have that on the screen.

446
00:25:30.939 --> 00:25:35.707
Right it's telling us that it
is 172.1695.12 right if I'm

447
00:25:35.707 --> 00:25:37.618
not mistaken that's 12.

448
00:25:37.618 --> 00:25:43.084
Now my IP address might be 172.16.95.13.

449
00:25:43.084 --> 00:25:46.198
Now it lets me know I'm different than
Ronnie, we're all on the same network.

450
00:25:46.198 --> 00:25:51.160
That 172.16.95 network,
then we're on the same network, so

451
00:25:51.160 --> 00:25:53.230
that means that we can talk to each other.

452
00:25:53.230 --> 00:25:56.150
I don't have to cross into
a different network to get to Ronnie,

453
00:25:56.150 --> 00:25:58.250
we are locally connected.

454
00:25:58.250 --> 00:26:02.010
But the differentiation between
his machine and mine, so

455
00:26:02.010 --> 00:26:05.540
I know that I get my traffic, he gets his,

456
00:26:05.540 --> 00:26:10.190
I don't worry about seeing his traffic,
is that last octet that we have.

457
00:26:10.190 --> 00:26:12.890
That host id portion,
that is the important one

458
00:26:12.890 --> 00:26:16.970
when it comes to our computers themselves
are nodes on the network, anything or

459
00:26:16.970 --> 00:26:20.150
hosts that's what we use this
terms they are on the network,

460
00:26:20.150 --> 00:26:24.627
they are the end device that needs an
address so they can say, hey I'm Daniel's

461
00:26:24.627 --> 00:26:28.010
computer, hey I'm Ronnie's computer, and
now we can tell the difference between

462
00:26:28.010 --> 00:26:31.615
the two because we have a different
host ID on our IP address.

463
00:26:31.615 --> 00:26:32.930
That is why we use this.

464
00:26:32.930 --> 00:26:35.075
>> Yeah, the other thing
that this also helps us do,

465
00:26:35.075 --> 00:26:38.702
the way that Daniel's describing it, is it
actually lets us know what devices are on

466
00:26:38.702 --> 00:26:41.230
the same network and
what devices are what we call remote.

467
00:26:41.230 --> 00:26:44.010
In other words,
different from our network as well,

468
00:26:44.010 --> 00:26:46.320
sometimes that's what
we need to distinguish.

469
00:26:46.320 --> 00:26:48.780
Are these two computers
on the same network or

470
00:26:48.780 --> 00:26:50.810
are they going to be
on different networks?

471
00:26:50.810 --> 00:26:53.770
And the subnet mask is what
helps us to determine that.

472
00:26:53.770 --> 00:26:56.280
If you take just a simple way
that I just did it right,

473
00:26:56.280 --> 00:27:00.340
describing when you get that 255
those numbers are gonna come through.

474
00:27:00.340 --> 00:27:02.170
But if you actually do
get another number and

475
00:27:02.170 --> 00:27:05.880
you get a zero there, that number is
probably not going to come through.

476
00:27:05.880 --> 00:27:08.400
So wherever that number stops right?

477
00:27:08.400 --> 00:27:09.770
That falls through here.

478
00:27:09.770 --> 00:27:12.030
So this is actually those
first three octets.

479
00:27:12.030 --> 00:27:13.510
Then you know that that's
your network portion.

480
00:27:13.510 --> 00:27:17.360
And wherever the other one stops
that's going to be your host ID.

481
00:27:17.360 --> 00:27:18.950
If you get two devices, right?

482
00:27:18.950 --> 00:27:21.300
Two IP addresses that
somebody is asking about.

483
00:27:21.300 --> 00:27:23.430
Like are these two on the same network?

484
00:27:23.430 --> 00:27:25.460
Just take an examination like that.

485
00:27:25.460 --> 00:27:27.398
If now you actually compare and

486
00:27:27.398 --> 00:27:32.060
it says 172.16.96, well those devices
are not gonna be on the same network.

487
00:27:32.060 --> 00:27:35.262
They're gonna be treated as if they're
actually on different networks, which

488
00:27:35.262 --> 00:27:38.290
means they will not be able to directly
communicate with each other as well.

489
00:27:38.290 --> 00:27:42.896
Now if we needed communication
though to happen between

490
00:27:42.896 --> 00:27:48.880
the 172.16.95 network and
the 172.16.96 network.

491
00:27:48.880 --> 00:27:54.551
Well what we also need to have on every
device in our network is gonna be what

492
00:27:54.551 --> 00:28:01.450
is called a default gateway, or you might
hear the term router IP address as well.

493
00:28:01.450 --> 00:28:05.610
And so this is actually
the IP address that tells us

494
00:28:05.610 --> 00:28:08.990
how we get outside of our own network.

495
00:28:08.990 --> 00:28:11.900
And this is important, it is like
the doorway outside of your house,

496
00:28:11.900 --> 00:28:15.270
outside of your room, it doesn't mean
that you know what the IP address

497
00:28:15.270 --> 00:28:16.990
is that you're going to connect to.

498
00:28:16.990 --> 00:28:19.310
But if can actually take
a look at the source and

499
00:28:19.310 --> 00:28:23.030
destination address of any
packet that we send, and it

500
00:28:23.030 --> 00:28:26.990
says it's on a different network well the
first place that your computer says for

501
00:28:26.990 --> 00:28:31.560
me to get it there I'm gonna send
it to this address right here.

502
00:28:31.560 --> 00:28:35.166
If your computer does not have a default

503
00:28:35.166 --> 00:28:39.984
gateway on the same network,
so notice there it is.

504
00:28:39.984 --> 00:28:44.996
172.16.95, 172.16.95,
if this says 97, 99, something else,

505
00:28:44.996 --> 00:28:50.021
I won't be able to communicate with any
other device outside of this 172.16.95.

506
00:28:50.021 --> 00:28:54.667
So if we are gonna communicate with
devices inside of our own network,

507
00:28:54.667 --> 00:28:57.960
they have to have that same network ID.

508
00:28:57.960 --> 00:29:01.920
If we're gonna be communicating with
devices between different networks,

509
00:29:01.920 --> 00:29:06.880
we need a default gateway
to help us to do that.

510
00:29:06.880 --> 00:29:09.550
And the way that we
distinguish whether a remote or

511
00:29:09.550 --> 00:29:14.240
whether actually on the same network is
going to be using this subnet mask to

512
00:29:14.240 --> 00:29:18.720
help us out to identify
that same process as well.

513
00:29:18.720 --> 00:29:23.590
So there is a lot of information that
we do have to kind of glean in a fairly

514
00:29:23.590 --> 00:29:26.310
quick moment of time that we
have that we're together.

515
00:29:26.310 --> 00:29:28.930
But this is not the last
time you're gonna see this.

516
00:29:28.930 --> 00:29:31.040
You're gonna work with this
throughout your networking career.

517
00:29:31.040 --> 00:29:34.580
>> Oh, yeah, yeah,
get prepared to become very familiar

518
00:29:34.580 --> 00:29:39.600
with the IPv4 addressing scheme, subnet
mask, gateways, things of that nature.

519
00:29:39.600 --> 00:29:40.120
Like Ronnie said,

520
00:29:40.120 --> 00:29:43.570
not the last time you're gonna go
down this rodeo, that is for sure.

521
00:29:43.570 --> 00:29:46.150
All of this will eventually start
making a whole lot more sense.

522
00:29:46.150 --> 00:29:50.740
We understand that it can be a bit
daunting at first when you first see this.

523
00:29:50.740 --> 00:29:54.360
But as you continue to look at it and
you start to see, okay,

524
00:29:54.360 --> 00:29:56.390
I look at my IP address, and

525
00:29:56.390 --> 00:30:00.090
then you can use some tools to figure
out what is Google's IP address, right.

526
00:30:00.090 --> 00:30:01.700
Take a look at those and
they're different.

527
00:30:01.700 --> 00:30:03.450
They're not even close to the same.

528
00:30:03.450 --> 00:30:04.470
Subnet mask different.

529
00:30:04.470 --> 00:30:06.180
Everything's different about them.

530
00:30:06.180 --> 00:30:09.030
So how do we get from one
network to the other and

531
00:30:09.030 --> 00:30:10.770
it's all through this addressing scheme.

532
00:30:10.770 --> 00:30:13.130
Things like the gateway and
the subnet mask help us out.

533
00:30:13.130 --> 00:30:16.960
So that we can differentiate between
networks as well as host and

534
00:30:16.960 --> 00:30:19.000
that is what it's all about ladies and
gentlemen.

535
00:30:19.000 --> 00:30:20.590
Hopefully it's making some sense to you.

536
00:30:20.590 --> 00:30:23.770
But Ronnie we've got more to
talk about and little time.

537
00:30:23.770 --> 00:30:25.730
>> We really do and so
that means we are ready for

538
00:30:25.730 --> 00:30:30.200
then of course part two which means we
do have a little bit more to cover.

539
00:30:30.200 --> 00:30:33.400
So when we start taking a look into part
two, we're gonna see some other things

540
00:30:33.400 --> 00:30:36.620
that there are special addresses that
we need to pay attention to as well.

541
00:30:36.620 --> 00:30:40.182
And not only just about getting
the IP addresses on the machines,

542
00:30:40.182 --> 00:30:43.620
which we still need to talk about,
but there is a lot more.

543
00:30:43.620 --> 00:30:47.110
And even in later episodes, we're going
to see that newer version as well.

544
00:30:47.110 --> 00:30:47.880
>> That's right.

545
00:30:47.880 --> 00:30:49.660
So stick with us networking gurus.

546
00:30:49.660 --> 00:30:51.200
Thanks for watching this episode.

547
00:30:51.200 --> 00:30:53.100
Hopefully we'll see you in part two.

548
00:30:53.100 --> 00:30:56.440
Signing off for ITProTv,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

549
00:30:56.440 --> 00:30:57.484
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

550
00:30:57.484 --> 00:30:58.079
>> We'll see you next time.

551

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue to explain IP addressing which is necessary for connecting devices on a network. They cover all the major bases involved in IP addressing such as the addresses themselves, subnet masks, and gateways; what they are and how they are used to connect devices.

binary networking as we call it
subnetting is what we call it.

251
00:13:36.740 --> 00:13:38.070
So if you can take that number.

252
00:13:38.070 --> 00:13:39.060
That binary number and

253
00:13:39.060 --> 00:13:42.690
divide it in to four equal parts,
you can do the same thing.

254
00:13:42.690 --> 00:13:45.010
But the way that we do it in
networking is right here.

255
00:13:45.010 --> 00:13:48.970
Where we do change that subnet mask
which identifies what that network

256
00:13:48.970 --> 00:13:50.780
portion is going to be.

257
00:13:50.780 --> 00:13:54.560
And that's how you actually are able
to be doing something like that/

258
00:13:54.560 --> 00:13:56.500
If you will choose to do it.

259
00:13:56.500 --> 00:13:59.530
So you will learn more about it as you
get on into your networking career.

260
00:13:59.530 --> 00:14:03.220
At least at this point understand it's
about taking one big network block.

261
00:14:03.220 --> 00:14:05.370
And then changing it into
smaller network blocks.

262
00:14:05.370 --> 00:14:07.060
That's probably the easiest
way to think about it.

263
00:14:07.060 --> 00:14:09.170
>> Yeah perfect explanation Ronnie.

264
00:14:09.170 --> 00:14:11.545
I couldn't have said it better myself.

265
00:14:11.545 --> 00:14:12.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right

266
00:14:12.240 --> 00:14:13.680
Ronnie what else do we need to talk about?

267
00:14:13.680 --> 00:14:17.619
I guess there's the different
versions of IP that are out there.

268
00:14:17.619 --> 00:14:20.990
As you said, IPv4,
kind of out of addresses, now.

269
00:14:20.990 --> 00:14:24.800
So, IPv6 has come out.

270
00:14:24.800 --> 00:14:25.810
Tell us about that a little bit.

271
00:14:25.810 --> 00:14:27.960
>> Yeah, the problem that we're
having here is simple, right?

272
00:14:27.960 --> 00:14:30.900
Because we don't have any more addresses,
IPv6, which is

273
00:14:30.900 --> 00:14:35.170
the next generation of the IP addressing,
well we're switching over to that.

274
00:14:35.170 --> 00:14:37.140
Now it's probably not
gonna be overnight so

275
00:14:37.140 --> 00:14:40.500
you're not gonna worry about it too much
but you will begin to learn about it.

276
00:14:40.500 --> 00:14:43.050
And actually you'll begin to learn about
it in another episode here in this

277
00:14:43.050 --> 00:14:43.630
series too.

278
00:14:43.630 --> 00:14:47.890
Where you'll at least take a look at
the foundations and the formatting of it.

279
00:14:47.890 --> 00:14:50.820
But the problem that we have is
as we switch on over, right?

280
00:14:50.820 --> 00:14:54.070
There's a bunch of technology that
we have to get ready to do so and

281
00:14:54.070 --> 00:14:57.860
the good thing is most of our computers
are already doing it, and the way they

282
00:14:57.860 --> 00:15:01.800
they're doing it is by implementing
what we call Transitional Technologies.

283
00:15:01.800 --> 00:15:05.310
So, how do we actually
move from my IPv4 to IPv6?

284
00:15:05.310 --> 00:15:08.380
Well there's several different techniques
that are out there, and I hate to say it.

285
00:15:08.380 --> 00:15:10.001
All of them are pretty much trash.

286
00:15:10.001 --> 00:15:10.903
>> [LAUGH]
>> They really are.

287
00:15:10.903 --> 00:15:11.610
They're garbage.

288
00:15:11.610 --> 00:15:13.053
They don't tend to work that well.

289
00:15:13.053 --> 00:15:13.773
>> Well don't sugarcoat it Ronnie.

290
00:15:13.773 --> 00:15:15.762
[CROSSTALK] Tell us how you really feel.

291
00:15:15.762 --> 00:15:17.420
>> Well I mean, you think about it.

292
00:15:17.420 --> 00:15:19.670
It really is kind of backward here, right?

293
00:15:19.670 --> 00:15:23.550
The very fact that I'm moving to newer
technology is easier to implement on

294
00:15:23.550 --> 00:15:27.687
the land inside of my own network than it
is across the entirety of the internet.

295
00:15:27.687 --> 00:15:30.355
So there may be pockets of
people out on the internet,

296
00:15:30.355 --> 00:15:32.502
the ISPs that say no we're going to IPv6.

297
00:15:32.502 --> 00:15:36.769
But then there's other ones that sit there
an go maybe we'll switch on over, but

298
00:15:36.769 --> 00:15:38.538
we're not gonna switch on over.

299
00:15:38.538 --> 00:15:41.754
So what happens is you get
smaller islands of, you know,

300
00:15:41.754 --> 00:15:44.571
different areas which
are actually using IPv6.

301
00:15:44.571 --> 00:15:47.050
And then different areas
which are using IPv4.

302
00:15:47.050 --> 00:15:47.627
So what does that mean?

303
00:15:47.627 --> 00:15:51.959
That means we have to actually have
some transition that if you are actually

304
00:15:51.959 --> 00:15:55.604
crossing from IPv6 to IPv4 you
might have to actually use some

305
00:15:55.604 --> 00:15:59.543
technology that either masks it or
actually translates it into it.

306
00:15:59.543 --> 00:16:00.544
You know, no matter what.

307
00:16:00.544 --> 00:16:02.501
So you have a weird thing.

308
00:16:02.501 --> 00:16:06.966
So, let's take for an example,
we have internally on a network,

309
00:16:06.966 --> 00:16:11.400
IPv6, but my ISP's only running IPv4,
well what do I do?

310
00:16:11.400 --> 00:16:12.280
I can change it.

311
00:16:12.280 --> 00:16:14.510
There's transitional technology
out there that says,

312
00:16:14.510 --> 00:16:19.640
we can kind of convert IPv6 addresses and
encapsulate it inside of IPv4, and

313
00:16:19.640 --> 00:16:24.392
then when it goes over to an IPv6 address,
we'll kind of take it out of the IPv4 box.

314
00:16:24.392 --> 00:16:26.164
And then put it back on IPv6.

315
00:16:26.164 --> 00:16:29.970
Well, that sounds like a lot of overhead,
a lot of, it is.

316
00:16:29.970 --> 00:16:31.830
It's a mess to do that.

317
00:16:31.830 --> 00:16:34.770
You can also of course,,
use some different technologies

318
00:16:34.770 --> 00:16:38.300
that help to try and
mask it across the networks as well.

319
00:16:38.300 --> 00:16:40.980
All of them are pretty
much not designed or

320
00:16:40.980 --> 00:16:45.330
not really designed for primetime and
not even across the Internet.

321
00:16:45.330 --> 00:16:47.070
A lot of times if you're
actually doing that.

322
00:16:47.070 --> 00:16:50.080
So there's different ones depending on
whether you're running network address

323
00:16:50.080 --> 00:16:52.220
translation on your network or
whether you're not.

324
00:16:52.220 --> 00:16:53.650
So you name it.

325
00:16:53.650 --> 00:16:56.130
There's so many of them,
it's hard to choose.

326
00:16:56.130 --> 00:16:59.170
The one that is the most stable is
the one It's actually running on this

327
00:16:59.170 --> 00:17:00.230
machine right here.

328
00:17:00.230 --> 00:17:02.310
And let me show you
what I'm talking about.

329
00:17:02.310 --> 00:17:06.710
So on this machine, if I bring up
that command prompt again, and

330
00:17:06.710 --> 00:17:11.070
I do an IP config, and
then I'm gonna use an option called /all.

331
00:17:11.070 --> 00:17:14.680
Let me scroll down here to
this ethernet adaptor, and

332
00:17:14.680 --> 00:17:18.100
you will see something a little
bit more unusual here.

333
00:17:18.100 --> 00:17:22.680
This machine is already running IPv6,
as well as IPv4.

334
00:17:24.100 --> 00:17:27.460
And you can see both of these
addresses are the ones that,

335
00:17:27.460 --> 00:17:29.730
notice they're both marked
as being preferred.

336
00:17:29.730 --> 00:17:34.650
So IPv6 and IPv4 are actually
running right now, simultaneously.

337
00:17:34.650 --> 00:17:37.980
And that is what is called
a dual stack configuration.

338
00:17:37.980 --> 00:17:40.550
Now you can see it not only right there.

339
00:17:40.550 --> 00:17:45.510
But if I were to get into the control
panel, so Start, Control Panel.

340
00:17:45.510 --> 00:17:50.590
And then go inside of Network and Internet
and then the Network and Sharing Center.

341
00:17:52.800 --> 00:17:55.400
Over on the left-hand side,
Change adapter settings.

342
00:17:55.400 --> 00:17:59.820
And then I right-click on Local area
connection and go to Properties.

343
00:17:59.820 --> 00:18:03.350
Notice that they are both check marked,
IPv6 and IPv4.

344
00:18:03.350 --> 00:18:07.570
This is the one that says, look,
let's run them simultaneously.

345
00:18:07.570 --> 00:18:10.020
They shouldn't interfere with each other,
so

346
00:18:10.020 --> 00:18:12.620
what I can do is I can have my
network up and running on IPv4.

347
00:18:12.620 --> 00:18:17.830
And then if I wanted to practice IPv6,
I can go ahead and

348
00:18:17.830 --> 00:18:21.620
start implementing IPv6
addressing in the background.

349
00:18:21.620 --> 00:18:25.238
And then, when I believe that
we're ready to transition over,

350
00:18:25.238 --> 00:18:29.057
I simply uncheck the IPv4 and
now I'm running completely IPv6 and

351
00:18:29.057 --> 00:18:33.144
hopefully nobody else in my network
that cares will actually really know

352
00:18:33.144 --> 00:18:36.570
that its happened and
we'll still get networking going on.

353
00:18:36.570 --> 00:18:40.080
Now you may think like no way,
I'm not ever gonna do that, but

354
00:18:40.080 --> 00:18:42.980
more than likely if you are running
Windows 8, and actually,

355
00:18:42.980 --> 00:18:46.380
even if you're running Windows 7 and all
the server products that are out there for

356
00:18:46.380 --> 00:18:48.470
windows, you're probably
already doing it and

357
00:18:48.470 --> 00:18:50.690
you don't know about it,
if you haven't checked.

358
00:18:50.690 --> 00:18:53.810
And actually, a lot of the network
communications going on in the background,

359
00:18:53.810 --> 00:18:58.626
even though we set IPv4 addresses, a lot
of it's actually being handled over IPv6.

360
00:18:58.626 --> 00:19:01.000
In other words,
it's already doing that for you.

361
00:19:01.000 --> 00:19:04.120
You and I just haven't been paying
attention as they've already switched

362
00:19:04.120 --> 00:19:05.350
the protocols over, and

363
00:19:05.350 --> 00:19:09.258
started trying to use that by default
to make the switch easier for us.

364
00:19:09.258 --> 00:19:11.980
So yeah,
there's a lot of technology out there, and

365
00:19:11.980 --> 00:19:14.250
it is coming as something that you and
I will have to get used to.

366
00:19:14.250 --> 00:19:17.442
But you're gonna see hopefully these
transitional technologies will kind of

367
00:19:17.442 --> 00:19:21.330
solidify into one that will work, but
ultimately you're gonna see it's just

368
00:19:21.330 --> 00:19:25.290
gonna be one day where somebody's
gonna say hey are we on IPv6 yet?

369
00:19:25.290 --> 00:19:28.630
And somebody just finally smiles and
goes we've been on it for two years.

370
00:19:28.630 --> 00:19:32.070
We just kept the IPv4 addresses
on there just to see, but

371
00:19:32.070 --> 00:19:33.810
we've been turning it off
all across the network.

372
00:19:33.810 --> 00:19:35.080
That's what's gonna probably happen.

373
00:19:35.080 --> 00:19:38.680
>> Yeah I've always said IPv6 is
coming right around the corner.

374
00:19:38.680 --> 00:19:41.761
It's just a very long, sweeping corner.

375
00:19:41.761 --> 00:19:42.296
>> You better believe it.

376
00:19:42.296 --> 00:19:44.510
>> That's more like an ellipse.

377
00:19:44.510 --> 00:19:47.290
>> It's been about ten years in
the making, cuz I just remember,

378
00:19:47.290 --> 00:19:51.680
every time when I started, it was like,
IPv6 is coming, you better start studying!

379
00:19:51.680 --> 00:19:54.650
And five years later, it was like,
IPv6 is coming, you better start studying!

380
00:19:54.650 --> 00:19:55.982
And I was like, what in the world?

381
00:19:55.982 --> 00:19:59.120
And then now,
what we mean is IPv6 is coming.

382
00:19:59.120 --> 00:20:00.694
You'd better start studying.

383
00:20:00.694 --> 00:20:03.410
[LAUGH] So, even now,
we're still having the same call.

384
00:20:03.410 --> 00:20:04.730
But now, it's actually more urgent.

385
00:20:04.730 --> 00:20:05.290
And it really is.

386
00:20:05.290 --> 00:20:06.116
>> The end is nigh, Ronnie.

387
00:20:06.116 --> 00:20:06.976
The end is nigh.

388
00:20:06.976 --> 00:20:07.578
>> The end is nigh.

389
00:20:07.578 --> 00:20:09.360
>> Everybody out there, get ready.

390
00:20:09.360 --> 00:20:10.850
IPv6 is coming.

391
00:20:10.850 --> 00:20:13.630
Believe it or not,
it's actually kind of already here.

392
00:20:13.630 --> 00:20:16.980
And, since we have exhausted
all the IPv4 stuff, well,

393
00:20:16.980 --> 00:20:19.560
that's gonna push it along
a little bit faster.

394
00:20:19.560 --> 00:20:21.610
So we gotta see that and
be ready for it when it comes.

395
00:20:21.610 --> 00:20:24.360
All right, Ronnie, is there anything
else that we need to go over before

396
00:20:24.360 --> 00:20:25.140
we end the show?

397
00:20:25.140 --> 00:20:29.060
>> Not with IPv4, but remember that
we are really scratching the surface.

398
00:20:29.060 --> 00:20:33.370
Get those foundational concepts in your
mind, about what the addresses look like.

399
00:20:33.370 --> 00:20:35.042
And where they come from.

400
00:20:35.042 --> 00:20:38.260
That's gonna be key for you if you're
preparing for the exam, as well.

401
00:20:38.260 --> 00:20:40.370
Make sure you can identify,
of course the public and

402
00:20:40.370 --> 00:20:42.600
the reserve ranges of addresses.

403
00:20:42.600 --> 00:20:43.930
Those are also key.

404
00:20:43.930 --> 00:20:47.120
And really a key concept for
us in networking, right?

405
00:20:47.120 --> 00:20:48.410
Is being able to identify whether or

406
00:20:48.410 --> 00:20:51.825
not devices are on the same network versus
whether they're on remote networks.

407
00:20:51.825 --> 00:20:55.130
And if they are on a remote network,
remember you need a default gateway.

408
00:20:55.130 --> 00:20:57.840
So that's a good kind of summary of
some of the stuff that we covered

409
00:20:57.840 --> 00:21:00.960
in these particular episodes,
that we've been taking a look at.

410
00:21:00.960 --> 00:21:02.700
And it's something that's foundational for

411
00:21:02.700 --> 00:21:07.430
everything that you will actually do in
networking, so make sure you learn them.

412
00:21:07.430 --> 00:21:10.000
>> Awesome stuff,
hopefully you guys enjoyed this episode.

413
00:21:10.000 --> 00:21:13.440
We go ahead and thank you for watching,
we're gonna sign off for ITProTV,

414
00:21:13.440 --> 00:21:15.430
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

415
00:21:15.430 --> 00:21:16.100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

416
00:21:16.100 --> 00:21:19.228
>> And we'll see you next time.

417
00:21:19.228 --> 00:21:24.180
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe Internet Protocol version 6 or IPv6. They explain how the new version differs from its predecessor as well as ways that they are similar in function. Specific topics covered are the IPv6 address, prefix number, gateway, and backward compatibility with IPv4.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv6
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.079
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.079 --> 00:00:11.355
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.355 --> 00:00:14.060
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.060 --> 00:00:15.760
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:15.760 --> 00:00:19.000
Joining me today on the show is
none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.000 --> 00:00:20.582
How's it going, Ronnie?
>> It is going great today.

7
00:00:20.582 --> 00:00:22.706
It's another great day to be
right here in the studio.

8
00:00:22.706 --> 00:00:26.830
Today we're taking a look at the MTA,
the Microsoft Technology Associate,

9
00:00:26.830 --> 00:00:29.882
specifically on the exam for
networking fundamentals.

10
00:00:29.882 --> 00:00:34.629
The exam number is 98366, so
if you are preparing for that exam,

11
00:00:34.629 --> 00:00:36.483
you are in the right place.

12
00:00:36.483 --> 00:00:41.478
And what we're focussing specifically on
today is gonna be understanding IPv6 is

13
00:00:41.478 --> 00:00:43.845
actually what we're taking a look at.

14
00:00:43.845 --> 00:00:47.733
And yes, I just saw a look of
surprise on Daniel's face as

15
00:00:47.733 --> 00:00:51.135
his eyebrows went about
this high above his head.

16
00:00:51.135 --> 00:00:53.140
And the reason why is that most of us,

17
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:57.949
have we been in networking at any point in
time, this is where we start going, man.

18
00:00:57.949 --> 00:00:59.556
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then all of a sudden,

19
00:00:59.556 --> 00:01:01.363
I can't believe we're focusing in on this.

20
00:01:01.363 --> 00:01:03.442
But it is a great topic for us to cover.

21
00:01:03.442 --> 00:01:05.486
And it's something that we have to know,
right, Daniel?

22
00:01:05.486 --> 00:01:09.174
>> Yeah, unfortunately, those days
where we could just, yeah, IPv6,

23
00:01:09.174 --> 00:01:10.569
I'll get to that, right?

24
00:01:10.569 --> 00:01:13.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's coming, it's not yet live at five.

25
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:15.880
Yeah, guess what, it's live at five.

26
00:01:15.880 --> 00:01:21.539
I know that IPv4 has been a long-held
lovely thing that we've just embraced so

27
00:01:21.539 --> 00:01:25.175
gratefully but
its day is coming quickly to an end.

28
00:01:25.175 --> 00:01:27.103
So IPv6, it's on the horizon.

29
00:01:27.103 --> 00:01:31.872
We have to be ready for it and yeah, it is
a little bit scary because of those huge

30
00:01:31.872 --> 00:01:36.012
Internet addresses or the IP
addresses that they give us for IPv6.

31
00:01:36.012 --> 00:01:39.576
But a little bit of walkthrough
with our little mentor here.

32
00:01:39.576 --> 00:01:44.142
Ronnie's gonna clear the path and make it
easy for us to understand so it's not so

33
00:01:44.142 --> 00:01:47.377
scary and we can tackle that
guy as it comes down the road.

34
00:01:47.377 --> 00:01:49.944
So Ronnie, IPv6, where do we begin?

35
00:01:49.944 --> 00:01:55.181
>> Yeah, so with IPv6 we start off with
the same concept as we do with IPv4.

36
00:01:55.181 --> 00:01:59.973
Remember that what happens is that when
we have an IPv4 address and another IPv4,

37
00:01:59.973 --> 00:02:01.763
we can send data between them.

38
00:02:01.763 --> 00:02:04.026
Well, with IPv6, it's the same way.

39
00:02:04.026 --> 00:02:07.067
We have to make sure that all the devices
that are gonna communicate directly,

40
00:02:07.067 --> 00:02:08.601
they're gonna be on the same network.

41
00:02:08.601 --> 00:02:12.450
And that each device is also going
to be able to be identified well,

42
00:02:12.450 --> 00:02:15.650
as unique as well inside
of that network too.

43
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:18.840
So, that's where we fundamentally
do some of the same things.

44
00:02:18.840 --> 00:02:21.420
People normally get a bit
nervous about this.

45
00:02:21.420 --> 00:02:25.068
And it's because when you change the
address, it now looks so foreign and so

46
00:02:25.068 --> 00:02:29.229
different that now everybody believes that
that means everything else has to change,

47
00:02:29.229 --> 00:02:32.369
such as the other layers of the OSI
model and everything else too.

48
00:02:32.369 --> 00:02:36.236
But because of the OSI model, which we've
covered in different episodes, well,

49
00:02:36.236 --> 00:02:37.958
it's actually a layered approach.

50
00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.918
The only thing we're really changing
is the layer three approach is all

51
00:02:40.918 --> 00:02:41.569
we're doing.

52
00:02:41.569 --> 00:02:44.065
And the rest of the model stays the same.

53
00:02:44.065 --> 00:02:46.526
So that's really what
we're focusing in on.

54
00:02:46.526 --> 00:02:48.473
And when we start taking a look at that,

55
00:02:48.473 --> 00:02:51.895
it will allow you to relax a little
bit more once you go, all right, so

56
00:02:51.895 --> 00:02:55.880
I don't have to worry about anything
except that this is gonna look different.

57
00:02:55.880 --> 00:02:57.020

00:26:40.580 --> 00:26:44.020
If you see an address that begins
with FE80, now you might say,

496
00:26:44.020 --> 00:26:49.400
I think I saw something like that
earlier in the show, you absolutely did.

497
00:26:49.400 --> 00:26:52.722
So right here on my computer, oops.

498
00:26:52.722 --> 00:26:57.503
See if I can mark that up, there is FE80,
and you see that :: there.

499
00:26:57.503 --> 00:27:00.363
Now, it doesn't always have to be
the :: directly underneath, but

500
00:27:00.363 --> 00:27:01.790
you do see this right here.

501
00:27:01.790 --> 00:27:06.420
When you see an address like that, that is
what is called that link local address.

502
00:27:06.420 --> 00:27:10.355
A link local address in IPv6
is when the IPv6 device and

503
00:27:10.355 --> 00:27:15.139
machine that's running that
protocol assigns itself an address.

504
00:27:15.139 --> 00:27:19.191
And you might have actually remembered
this from the days of IPv4, so

505
00:27:19.191 --> 00:27:22.979
you do wanna pay attention to
an address like that as well, okay?

506
00:27:22.979 --> 00:27:25.700
So make sure you take a look there too.

507
00:27:25.700 --> 00:27:27.772
So you will see stuff like this and

508
00:27:27.772 --> 00:27:32.286
the nice thing about it is that this
is fairly useful in comparison to that

509
00:27:32.286 --> 00:27:38.000
169.254 address that we also talk about
too in the troubleshooting in IPv4.

510
00:27:38.000 --> 00:27:42.070
That address today is not as useful as
it once was but this one really is.

511
00:27:42.070 --> 00:27:46.480
When you are making direct communication
to another device on your network,

512
00:27:46.480 --> 00:27:50.040
this is probably the one that's
actually being used in the background.

513
00:27:50.040 --> 00:27:52.430
So even if you actually have
a lot of other addresses,

514
00:27:52.430 --> 00:27:54.180
when you talk about
direct communications and

515
00:27:54.180 --> 00:27:58.070
commands, this is the one that's gonna
be used the majority of the time.

516
00:27:58.070 --> 00:28:01.050
Now there are actually several
different addresses that we

517
00:28:01.050 --> 00:28:02.908
still need to go back and take a look at.

518
00:28:02.908 --> 00:28:05.110
But Daniel, taking a look at the time,

519
00:28:05.110 --> 00:28:08.130
I think we're gonna have to do
a part two on this, I really do.

520
00:28:08.130 --> 00:28:09.574
>> Do you think it'll
take a whole part two?

521
00:28:09.574 --> 00:28:10.740
>> I think it may take a whole part two.

522
00:28:10.740 --> 00:28:11.870
>> Wow.

523
00:28:11.870 --> 00:28:14.740
All right, Ronnie, well if it takes
a part two, it takes a part two and

524
00:28:14.740 --> 00:28:15.460
that's what we'll have to do.

525
00:28:15.460 --> 00:28:16.870
Hopefully we'll see you guys there.

526
00:28:16.870 --> 00:28:19.450
Thank you so much for
those demonstrations and explanations.

527
00:28:19.450 --> 00:28:20.990
And thank you guys for
watching, and again,

528
00:28:20.990 --> 00:28:22.520
hopefully we'll see you in that part two.

529
00:28:22.520 --> 00:28:24.980
As for this episode, we're gonna
go ahead and sign off for ITProTV,

530
00:28:24.980 --> 00:28:26.800
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

531
00:28:26.800 --> 00:28:27.460
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

532
00:28:27.460 --> 00:28:28.880
>> And we'll see you next time.

533
00:28:28.880 --> 00:28:35.350
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining the IPv6 address, this time going over some special or reserved IPv6 addresses like the Link Local address, as well as Private, Multicast, and Loopback IPv6 addresses.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv6 Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.947
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.947 --> 00:00:11.780
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.780 --> 00:00:16.200
Welcome to another exciting episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host Daniel Lowery.

4
00:00:16.200 --> 00:00:19.000
Joining me today is none other than Mr.
Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:19.000 --> 00:00:19.770
How's it going Ronnie?

6
00:00:19.770 --> 00:00:20.920
>> It is going great today.

7
00:00:20.920 --> 00:00:25.087
We're right here in the studio ready
to begin taking a look at the MTA,

8
00:00:25.087 --> 00:00:29.483
the Microsoft Technology Associate Getting
ready for exam 98366.

9
00:00:29.483 --> 00:00:31.505
That's the networking fundamentals.

10
00:00:31.505 --> 00:00:35.455
Trying to put these fun back in networking
fundamentals is what we're trying to do.

11
00:00:35.455 --> 00:00:37.765
It is our job, we really do enjoy this.

12
00:00:37.765 --> 00:00:40.125
And what we're taking a look
at today specifically right,

13
00:00:40.125 --> 00:00:45.220
is finishing up some details in IPv6 and
understanding IPv6.

14
00:00:45.220 --> 00:00:48.160
So, where we took a look
at in a previous episode,

15
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:49.850
is talking about
the foundation of a foray.

16
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:52.710
Let me show you what I'm talking
about right here on the screen,

17
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:57.300
is that we kind of took a little bit
about where it actually comes from too.

18
00:00:57.300 --> 00:01:00.820
So it starts off in the same place where
we have IP addressing that you and

19
00:01:00.820 --> 00:01:04.802
I know is IPv4 in the binary and
it quickly transitions in.

20
00:01:04.802 --> 00:01:08.190
And then today what we're talking about
in IPv6 is really what we'll call

21
00:01:08.190 --> 00:01:12.320
a hexidecimal looking
type of notation here.

22
00:01:12.320 --> 00:01:15.989
So this address base is much bigger
than what was previously done.

23
00:01:15.989 --> 00:01:19.137
And the reason why we want to actually
understand that is because well,

24
00:01:19.137 --> 00:01:21.348
we don't wanna run out of
these addresses again.

25
00:01:21.348 --> 00:01:25.277
So IPv6, at least for what we're doing
today, is not only the networking of

26
00:01:25.277 --> 00:01:28.610
today, it's actually gonna
be forever more than likely.

27
00:01:28.610 --> 00:01:31.590
Is how big this address
pool is going to be.

28
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:35.370
So when you start seeing these addresses
on the network, remember that that's when

29
00:01:35.370 --> 00:01:40.040
you're gonna see in the future when
it comes down to networking, right.

30
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:42.980
You and I are gonna see these
on individual machines like PCs

31
00:01:42.980 --> 00:01:43.720
inside of our network.

32
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:45.830
We're gonna see them
used across the Internet.

33
00:01:45.830 --> 00:01:47.950
You're gonna see them
on every single device.

34
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:50.560
And unlike IPv4,
we don't have to worry about

35
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:53.560
managing a lot of it unless
we just want to control it.

36
00:01:53.560 --> 00:01:56.180
So what are we left with that
we really have to talk on.

37
00:01:56.180 --> 00:01:57.970
Well there's several things here and

38
00:01:57.970 --> 00:02:01.620
one of them has to do with what we call
different types of special addresses.

39
00:02:01.620 --> 00:02:06.480
And the reason for that is to remember
that what we have is an IPv6.

40
00:02:06.480 --> 00:02:09.360
There are gonna be different
types of addresses

41
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:13.020
depending on the traffic that's
actually gonna come across you.

42
00:02:13.020 --> 00:02:16.160
So, gone are gonna be the days where
a single device is gonna have just

43
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:17.290
one IP address.

44
00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:20.270
And then regardless of the way
that traffic gets to that device

45
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:22.370
it only uses that one address.

46
00:02:22.370 --> 00:02:25.490
Your machines are gonna be
assigned special addressed

47
00:02:25.490 --> 00:02:29.170
that are going to be used in the way
that you actually do communicate.

48
00:02:29.170 --> 00:02:32.150
And so you do have to get
used to another system here

49
00:02:32.150 --> 00:02:35.670
in which your single device is actually
gonna have multiple IP addresses.

50
00:02:35.670 --> 00:02:38.350
And it just depends on what's being done.

51
00:02:38.350 --> 00:02:41.070
So, when we start taking
a look here on my machine.

52
00:02:41.070 --> 00:02:44.090
Now, I went ahead and typed out on
one of them that we had addressed in

53
00:02:44.090 --> 00:02:46.690
a previous episode, but
it's good for us to review.

54
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:49.800
Is that if you see any address
that begins with an FE80, and

55
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:52.730
then you actually have colons, and

56
00:02:52.730 --> 00:02:56.720
then you have a bunch of other numbers,
whatever it might, and it has a slash 10.

57
00:02:56.720 --> 00:03:00.530
That's just telling you that the first
ten bits of this address is significant.

58
00:03:00.530 --> 00:03:03.970
Now, each one of these letters
represents about four bits, so

59
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:04.980
it's actually saying that.

60
00:03:04.980 --> 00:03:07.660
And when you start seeing that, that's
what they're saying here, is that hey,

61
00:03:07.660 --> 00:03:10.560
only those first ten bits
are really significant

62
00:03:10.560 --> 00:03:13.200
in this address as being
the network portion.

63
00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:17.422
Well, that type of address is
equivalent to what we see in IPv4

64
00:03:17.422 --> 00:03:19.261
as being an APIPA address.

65
00:03:19.261 --> 00:03:21.981
If you remember that 169.254 address,

66
00:03:21.981 --> 00:03:26.605
in which those computers assign themselves
that type of address when they don't

67
00:03:26.605 --> 00:03:29.808
actually have communication
the way that they need to.

68
00:03:29.808 --> 00:03:33.250
Well that address is really used for
troubleshooting today.

69
00:03:33.250 --> 00:03:38.330
Well in IPv6 though, that address is
actually the first one that's designed,

70
00:03:38.330 --> 00:03:40.970
that's assigned, excuse me, to itself.

71
00:03:40.970 --> 00:03:44.040
And that is because it's not
something just for troubleshooting.

72
00:03:44.040 --> 00:03:46.370
It's because it's the most useful address.

73
00:03:46.370 --> 00:03:48.880
And we did take a look at
where we can find that.

74
00:03:48.880 --> 00:03:53.010
If you do bring up your command prompt in
a machine, regardless of whether you're

75
00:03:53.010 --> 00:03:56.970
talking about server 2008 or Windows 8 or
Windows 7, and you do a IP configuration,

76
00:03:56.970 --> 00:04:02.520
it normally shows you an IP
address that begins with FE80.

77
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:05.120
And there it is.
They call it a link local.

78
00:04:05.120 --> 00:04:09.840
So the link local address is
equivalent to what you and I would see

79
00:04:09.840 --> 00:04:14.490
as being that APIPA address, but
this one I put in parenthesis is useful.

80
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:17.530
It's the first one that's assigned and
that's because it's going to be used

81
00:04:17.530 --> 00:04:21.780
more often than most of the addresses
that we also end up seeing.

82
00:04:21.780 --> 00:04:24.670
Now there's other things that
we also have to worry about

83
00:04:24.670 --> 00:04:27.320
too inside of IPv6 networks.

84
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:29.880
See if I can actually get to the point
where I can type back into this

85
00:04:29.880 --> 00:04:30.940
machine here.

86
00:04:30.940 --> 00:04:34.200
Another one that you might end up
seeing is one that begins with FC00

87
00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:42.450
here and then that's also gonna be a ::/8.

88
00:04:42.450 --> 00:04:44.980
And this is where we begin
with what we call the,

89
00:04:46.030 --> 00:04:50.220
it's what's gonna be the same as
we we call private IP addresses.

90
00:04:50.220 --> 00:04:54.187
Now, this is where we talk
about the reserved addresses.

91
00:04:54.187 --> 00:04:57.217
Again, if you go back to the IPV 4 show,
please do take a look at that.

92
00:04:57.217 --> 00:05:01.584
Remember that there are private IP
addresses that we can use within our own

93
00:05:01.584 --> 00:05:02.294
networks.

94
00:05:02.294 --> 00:05:07.350
And in IPv6, they still give you that
ability to also use private addresses

95
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:11.787
that you might only use within
a single network, if you choose to.

96
00:05:11.787 --> 00:05:14.874
And when you start taking that,
it actually begins with FC00.

97
00:05:14.874 --> 00:05:19.783
And the way that, that ends up translating
out is a little bit strange, too.

98
00:05:19.783 --> 00:05:24.328
Is that what will end up really happening
here, is that when they assign it,

99
00:05:24.328 --> 00:05:28.743
because it's an address pool,
it really turns out to be FD00 instead.

100
00:05:28.743 --> 00:05:31.090
So the even though the range begins at FC,

101
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:35.210
it really translates into FD as
kind of a strange way to do things.

102
00:05:35.210 --> 00:05:39.020
So if you're talking about private
IP addresses, well, in IPv6,

103
00:05:39.020 --> 00:05:43.530
that's where you see that as either FC or
FD too.

104
00:05:43.530 --> 00:05:46.580
And so, you have different
traffic that's only designed for

105
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:49.760
a certain group of computers
inside of your network.

106
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:52.090
That's what you're gonna
end up using as well,

107
00:05:52.090 --> 00:05:53.990
when you want something
like that to happen.

108
00:05:53.990 --> 00:05:56.640
>> So Ronnie, we're gonna use
these private IP addresses.

109
00:05:56.640 --> 00:06:00.530
Even though it's IPv6 and we've got
a bazillion, gajillion addresses.

110
00:06:00.530 --> 00:06:02.190
>> [LAUGH] We do.
>> We wouldn't need to.

111
00:06:02.190 --> 00:06:04.490
We do this more for
organizational purposes, right?

112
00:06:04.490 --> 00:06:08.320
So, we can keep an eye on
what we know is ours and

113
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:11.700
I don't have to worry about going,
okay, which IPv6 address is this?

114
00:06:11.700 --> 00:06:13.475
Cuz like you said,
there's so many of them.

115
00:06:13.475 --> 00:06:14.331
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

116
00:06:14.331 --> 00:06:17.751
there's no doubt that this is gonna be a
little bit confusing at the beginning for

117
00:06:17.751 --> 00:06:19.927
network administrators
to start seeing traffic.

118
00:06:19.927 --> 00:06:23.000
But once you realize that you're only
gonna receive that type of traffic on

119
00:06:23.000 --> 00:06:24.134
those types of addresses.

120
00:06:24.134 --> 00:06:28.266
It really helps to eliminate like is this
traffic actually designed for everybody or

121
00:06:28.266 --> 00:06:28.800
is it not.

122
00:06:28.800 --> 00:06:30.260
If it's coming in over here,

123
00:06:30.260 --> 00:06:33.140
that means that somebody specifically
sent it with that address in mind.

124
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:36.054
So that your machine's also gonna
be able to partake in that too.

125
00:06:36.054 --> 00:06:41.616
Now this comes because
broadcast is also dead in IPv6.

126
00:06:41.616 --> 00:06:44.308
And that means we don't just send
out data on the network hopefully

127
00:06:44.308 --> 00:06:46.740
somebody will actually hear it and
understand it.

128
00:06:46.740 --> 00:06:49.300
It's because of the way
that multicast is working.

129
00:06:49.300 --> 00:06:52.715
So not only do you have specific kind of
sub branches of multi-casting like this,

130
00:06:52.715 --> 00:06:56.300
but if you did need to do, oops, let me
see if I can get away from that there.

131
00:06:56.300 --> 00:07:02.070
If you did need to do multi-casting,
which is kind of the equivalent of broad,

132
00:07:02.070 --> 00:07:05.500
I'm not allowed to say it that way,
but it does seem like that.

133
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:06.810
When you do see something like this,
and think,

134
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:11.030
this is also the first eight here,
too, on that one.

135
00:07:11.030 --> 00:07:15.440
I may actually be wrong on that one, but
this is what we call multi-casting too.

136
00:07:15.440 --> 00:07:20.445
So, if you need to send out an address
just to a multicast group, designed

137
00:07:20.445 --> 00:07:25.884
to only hit certain computers, you can do
that in a general sense by using this.

138
00:07:25.884 --> 00:07:26.803
On the private one,

139
00:07:26.803 --> 00:07:30.490
it's probably because you do have special
subsets of data that you need to send.

140
00:07:30.490 --> 00:07:35.900
If it's just regular multi-casting your
gonna use the FF00 instead, and that will

141
00:07:35.900 --> 00:07:41.650
also help out when you start dealing with
that, especially that type of traffic.

142
00:07:41.650 --> 00:07:44.740
Now there are routing information

143
00:07:44.740 --> 00:07:48.610
in these special addresses that we
also need to pay attention to as well.

144
00:07:48.610 --> 00:07:52.570
So there's a special one that you
probably, hopefully not see too often, and

145
00:07:52.570 --> 00:07:58.050
that's if it's just a double colon, and
this is called an unspecified address.

146
00:07:59.650 --> 00:08:03.670
If you do happen to end up seeing
traffic that is destined for

147
00:08:03.670 --> 00:08:05.650
this, where it's just a double colon.

148
00:08:05.650 --> 00:08:07.907
That means that hey,
we're trying to send it.

149
00:08:07.907 --> 00:08:11.396
We don't really know what that
end address is going to be.

150
00:08:11.396 --> 00:08:14.211
So instead what they do is
that they send it here and

151
00:08:14.211 --> 00:08:18.436
what normally happens at that point,
it actually just tries to distribute

152
00:08:18.436 --> 00:08:21.207
it as much as possible to
whoever it need to go to.

153
00:08:21.207 --> 00:08:25.996
So, the unspecified address is
actually equivalent in IPV 4 to

154
00:08:25.996 --> 00:08:30.532
a special address,
that you might also see as being 0.0.

155
00:08:30.532 --> 00:08:31.716
Oops.

156
00:08:31.716 --> 00:08:33.860
0.0.0.0 here.

157
00:08:33.860 --> 00:08:36.125
So hopefully you won't see that too often.

158
00:08:36.125 --> 00:08:40.881
What that actually means is, just go
out the default as much as you can,

159
00:08:40.881 --> 00:08:42.957
that default gateway as well.

160
00:08:42.957 --> 00:08:48.513
Now there's one more that we need to
pay attention to, and that's when the,

161
00:08:48.513 --> 00:08:53.398
anything that ends in this 001
here is considered the loop back.

162
00:08:53.398 --> 00:08:57.993
And so this is equivalent to
127.0.0.1 network, and so

163
00:08:57.993 --> 00:09:01.007
that's the same as the loop back address.

164
00:09:01.007 --> 00:09:04.362
So it still gives us that
ability to do the testing and

165
00:09:04.362 --> 00:09:06.280
do all the different things.

166
00:09:06.280 --> 00:09:10.690
Let me see if I can stretch that out so
that we can see it a little bit better.

167
00:09:10.690 --> 00:09:14.630
So there are multiple special
addresses that we have access to

168
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:16.830
that we really do need
to pay attention to.

169
00:09:16.830 --> 00:09:20.060
These are by far the most common,
are the only ones out there.

170
00:09:20.060 --> 00:09:20.820
No.

171
00:09:20.820 --> 00:09:23.917
But once you get these in mind
inside of your own network.

172
00:09:23.917 --> 00:09:25.897
You'll probably see these more often.

173
00:09:25.897 --> 00:09:29.020
When you actually want to start
communicating across the network, oh,

174
00:09:29.020 --> 00:09:31.628
not across the network,
across the Internet I should say.

175
00:09:31.628 --> 00:09:34.120
And so at that point,
you actually start seeing other addresses

176
00:09:34.120 --> 00:09:36.170
instead that should begin
with something like this.

177
00:09:36.170 --> 00:09:39.446
Where it actually begins with a two
instead, and that's because of the way

178
00:09:39.446 --> 00:09:43.270
that the global addressing works versus
what you actually see internally.

179
00:09:43.270 --> 00:09:46.840
So these special addresses,
even though they are a little more, and

180
00:09:46.840 --> 00:09:48.950
you might be like oh do I
really need to know this?

181
00:09:48.950 --> 00:09:49.620
You really do.

182
00:09:49.620 --> 00:09:52.765
At least the basics here and
understanding what the equivalent is.

183
00:09:52.765 --> 00:09:54.982
If you're having to do testing against
your own computer to see if it works.

184
00:09:54.982 --> 00:09:58.190
You're gonna use this colon,
colon one, right?

185
00:09:58.190 --> 00:10:00.790
If you know that hey,
something needs to be sent outbound but

186
00:10:00.790 --> 00:10:03.340
your not sure what the destination or
where it was going.

187
00:10:03.340 --> 00:10:04.914
You might use that double colon.

188
00:10:04.914 --> 00:10:09.010
If you know something is actually going
to be directly connected on that same

189
00:10:09.010 --> 00:10:12.342
segment, and it needs to go really
in a unicast or a one to one.

190
00:10:12.342 --> 00:10:15.369
More than likely inside that network,
it's gonna use this address up here,

191
00:10:15.369 --> 00:10:16.729
that's equivalent to the APIPA.

192
00:10:16.729 --> 00:10:19.859
And then you have private and
of course, multi-casting,

193
00:10:19.859 --> 00:10:22.720
designed for
very specialized traffic for us.

194
00:10:22.720 --> 00:10:27.020
So all of this is part of
the entire package that we see.

195
00:10:27.020 --> 00:10:30.405
So just by knowing these addresses,
it really does help.

196
00:10:30.405 --> 00:10:34.690
Now you might be wondering, okay, so on my
machine, where in the world would I put

197
00:10:34.690 --> 00:10:39.020
an address like what we see even up here,
if I needed to do that?

198
00:10:39.020 --> 00:10:44.159
Well, if I go back to my machine,
notice I don't have an IPv6 address,

199
00:10:44.159 --> 00:10:48.961
but what I can do is, I can get out
of that configuration, and I go and

200
00:10:48.961 --> 00:10:51.010
find my local area adapter.

201
00:10:51.010 --> 00:10:53.204
So I can click on the.

202
00:10:53.204 --> 00:10:53.889
Oops.

203
00:10:53.889 --> 00:10:58.000
Yep.
I can right-click on the Start button, go

204
00:10:58.000 --> 00:11:04.959
to Control Panel > Network and Internet,
and then Network and Sharing Center.

205
00:11:06.190 --> 00:11:13.080
And from there I can select this,
the ethernet zero and properties here.

206
00:11:13.080 --> 00:11:17.590
Now when you're actually in networking
you'll do this more often then you think,

207
00:11:17.590 --> 00:11:18.440
but it's right here.

208
00:11:18.440 --> 00:11:21.180
Instead of actually going
where I normally would go,

209
00:11:21.180 --> 00:11:26.380
which is to IPv4,
I can select IPv6 and properties.

210
00:11:26.380 --> 00:11:29.590
And this is where you can also add it in,
too.

211
00:11:29.590 --> 00:11:33.810
The majority of the time, you and
I are not gonna have to do anything,

212
00:11:33.810 --> 00:11:37.590
when IPv6 comes along,
because it will be auto configured.

213
00:11:37.590 --> 00:11:41.850
But if you do need to have an assignment,
all you have to do is be willing to

214
00:11:43.080 --> 00:11:46.830
type in the actual address that
you think you're gonna be using.

215
00:11:46.830 --> 00:11:53.340
So let's just make it a little bit easy on
us and I'll kind of still doing this here.

216
00:11:53.340 --> 00:11:58.050
A ten network, and then we'll actually
assign it, let's say, a dot one there.

217
00:11:58.050 --> 00:12:01.890
And I can do the subnet
prefix here of a 64.

218
00:12:01.890 --> 00:12:03.820
Oops, maybe not.

219
00:12:03.820 --> 00:12:05.410
Not 664, that would be silly.

220
00:12:05.410 --> 00:12:10.890
64 and click OK, and
then I click close from there and

221
00:12:10.890 --> 00:12:14.030
now if I go to the details and
did it save it?

222
00:12:15.100 --> 00:12:16.470
See there it goes.

223
00:12:16.470 --> 00:12:20.850
So you can now see I can assign
an ipv6 address there if we need to so

224
00:12:20.850 --> 00:12:23.690
if you're having to statically
assign them for control.

225
00:12:23.690 --> 00:12:25.918
You'd do it in the same location but

226
00:12:25.918 --> 00:12:28.977
instead of picking IPV4
you also select IPV6.

227
00:12:28.977 --> 00:12:30.740
Now, everything that we're talking about,
right,

228
00:12:30.740 --> 00:12:32.478
if we're having to manually
do something like this.

229
00:12:32.478 --> 00:12:37.109
It's all about control of those addresses,
and one of the controls that we

230
00:12:37.109 --> 00:12:40.650
had inside of IPV4 is the use
of what we call subnetting.

231
00:12:40.650 --> 00:12:43.160
Now, when we start
talking about subnetting,

232
00:12:43.160 --> 00:12:46.469
in IPV4 we're taking a large
chunk of an address space.

233
00:12:47.550 --> 00:12:50.530
And what we're doing is we're
subdividing it into smaller sections.

234
00:12:50.530 --> 00:12:52.330
Well, can we do that in IPv6?

235
00:12:52.330 --> 00:12:53.720
Yes you can.

236
00:12:54.740 --> 00:12:58.180
You can actually subnet, but the only
reason that you're probably going to be

237
00:12:58.180 --> 00:13:02.570
doing that is if you really do need
to control the address spacing.

238
00:13:02.570 --> 00:13:06.650
The actual specifications and
documentation, they don't recommend that

239
00:13:06.650 --> 00:13:10.490
you actually have the subnet at
all if you really don't have to.

240
00:13:10.490 --> 00:13:13.780
But if you really are needing to
control something for one reason or

241
00:13:13.780 --> 00:13:16.560
another, dividing it up because
you really want to make sure that

242
00:13:16.560 --> 00:13:21.030
these addresses are actually different
from this particular division's address,

243
00:13:21.030 --> 00:13:22.110
perfectly fine.

244
00:13:22.110 --> 00:13:24.180
You can still do subnetting.

245
00:13:24.180 --> 00:13:28.253
But when you do it this time, you're not
actually doing binary division anymore,

246
00:13:28.253 --> 00:13:31.527
you're actually having to learn
hexidecimal division instead.

247
00:13:31.527 --> 00:13:34.569
And so it does require
a little bit more practice and

248
00:13:34.569 --> 00:13:37.964
being able to do this, but
the good thing is there's only

249
00:13:37.964 --> 00:13:41.740
a limited amount of subnetting
that the ISP's are going to do.

250
00:13:41.740 --> 00:13:46.670
And so, that means that whatever you do
internally, that's up to you as well.

251
00:13:46.670 --> 00:13:50.250
So, if you do need that extra control,
you still have the ability to subnet.

252
00:13:50.250 --> 00:13:52.323
Most of the time we don't really need to.

253
00:13:52.323 --> 00:13:55.110
Once they assign it to us and
we have all the addresses that we need.

254
00:13:55.110 --> 00:13:57.088
It really doesn't matter
any more at that point.

255
00:13:57.088 --> 00:14:01.053
So just kinda realize that subnetting is
still a possibility, but it's probably not

256
00:14:01.053 --> 00:14:04.930
recommended for anything that you and
I are going to do at least at this point.

257
00:14:04.930 --> 00:14:09.420
>> Yeah, it's kinda the purpose of IPv6
is that we no longer need the subnet.

258
00:14:09.420 --> 00:14:11.000
There's plenty of addresses.

259
00:14:11.000 --> 00:14:14.910
Go for broke, give every hair on your
head an IP address if you feel like it.

260
00:14:14.910 --> 00:14:16.018
Give your toaster an IP address.

261
00:14:16.018 --> 00:14:17.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> Give your cat an IP address.

262
00:14:17.640 --> 00:14:19.800
And give all the hairs on
your cat an IP address.

263
00:14:19.800 --> 00:14:20.900
And we're still not gonna run out of them.

264
00:14:20.900 --> 00:14:22.820
We're not gonna have to
worry about depleting them.

265
00:14:22.820 --> 00:14:25.008
Ronnie, you talked about that earlier,

266
00:14:25.008 --> 00:14:28.830
how even the feasibility of running
out of IP addresses now is just gone.

267
00:14:28.830 --> 00:14:30.037
It's out the window.

268
00:14:30.037 --> 00:14:32.998
So, subnetting it's still there-
>> Right.

269
00:14:32.998 --> 00:14:35.111
>> But it's not really necessary.

270
00:14:35.111 --> 00:14:38.664
>> Yeah, so hopefully you will never see
that where somebody says let's start

271
00:14:38.664 --> 00:14:39.950
subnetting this.

272
00:14:39.950 --> 00:14:40.810
Don't get me wrong.

273
00:14:40.810 --> 00:14:41.840
Can it be done, yes.

274
00:14:41.840 --> 00:14:43.830
Can you learn it relatively easily?

275
00:14:43.830 --> 00:14:45.080
Believe it or not, you can.

276
00:14:45.080 --> 00:14:49.010
Once you actually get the hexadecimal
math down, it makes sense.

277
00:14:49.010 --> 00:14:50.570
But if you don't know that part.

278
00:14:50.570 --> 00:14:52.970
Well then it doesn't make as much sense.

279
00:14:52.970 --> 00:14:54.990
But if you do want to learn more about it,
go ahead and

280
00:14:54.990 --> 00:14:57.570
check out some of the other
shows that we have as well.

281
00:14:57.570 --> 00:15:00.833
So IPv6 and
IPv4 is actually covered in Network+ and

282
00:15:00.833 --> 00:15:06.020
CompTIA A+ and, actually, just about every
other show that we have on networking.

283
00:15:06.020 --> 00:15:09.180
Some type of networking and
IP addressing is covered, but

284
00:15:09.180 --> 00:15:11.020
for more details, do check that out.

285
00:15:11.020 --> 00:15:13.300
At least right here,
these are the fundamentals.

286
00:15:13.300 --> 00:15:15.400
These are the foundations that
will at least get us started and

287
00:15:15.400 --> 00:15:17.450
that's what we want here at the MTA level.

288
00:15:17.450 --> 00:15:20.710
>> Yeah Ronnie, it can't be anymore
difficult than IPv4 subnetting it.

289
00:15:20.710 --> 00:15:23.110
It will drive a man to the bottle,
that is for sure.

290
00:15:23.110 --> 00:15:24.944
But once you get it down you feel
like you've accomplished something.

291
00:15:24.944 --> 00:15:26.442
It's gonna be the same with IPv6.

292
00:15:26.442 --> 00:15:28.528
If you do need to
understand that subnetting,

293
00:15:28.528 --> 00:15:31.414
you're just gonna have to spend
a little time behind the wheel,

294
00:15:31.414 --> 00:15:35.450
get used to it, figure out how it works
and then implement it for your solution.

295
00:15:35.450 --> 00:15:38.130
All right Ronnie, is there anything else
we need to cover when it comes to IPv6?

296
00:15:38.130 --> 00:15:39.180
>> Not really, right.

297
00:15:39.180 --> 00:15:41.260
The key here is not
letting it frighten you.

298
00:15:41.260 --> 00:15:45.050
So everybody will, you do,
you hear a kind of mystical frightening

299
00:15:45.050 --> 00:15:48.370
even when you get into the industry,
like man IPv6 is coming.

300
00:15:48.370 --> 00:15:49.440
That's tough.

301
00:15:49.440 --> 00:15:52.260
Well, if you're learning it for
the first time, don't look at it that way.

302
00:15:52.260 --> 00:15:53.700
You're learning it for the first time.

303
00:15:53.700 --> 00:15:56.244
Look at it as, okay,
let me just get used to this.

304
00:15:56.244 --> 00:15:58.566
And once you do,
it's not gonna be tough for you.

305
00:15:58.566 --> 00:16:00.454
It's not gonna be as tough for
you as it was for

306
00:16:00.454 --> 00:16:03.010
me when I was like I really
don't want to learn this.

307
00:16:03.010 --> 00:16:04.410
So, if you're brand new at this,

308
00:16:04.410 --> 00:16:07.690
this is a great time because
this will be your foundation.

309
00:16:07.690 --> 00:16:09.880
It's not gonna be learning the old stuff.

310
00:16:09.880 --> 00:16:12.666
The old stuff may,
actually after you learn this, you go,

311
00:16:12.666 --> 00:16:14.576
why would anyone do anything like that?

312
00:16:14.576 --> 00:16:18.048
And we're gonna say we don't know why
anyone would do anything like IPv6.

313
00:16:18.048 --> 00:16:22.276
So it is all about perspective, but
if you're doing this for the first time,

314
00:16:22.276 --> 00:16:26.568
take more time to make sure you understand
this even more than the IPv4 because

315
00:16:26.568 --> 00:16:29.978
IPv4 will come naturally once
you actually get this as well.

316
00:16:29.978 --> 00:16:32.218
>> Yeah this is the future.

317
00:16:32.218 --> 00:16:35.810
So if you get a nice IPv6 foundation laid.

318
00:16:35.810 --> 00:16:39.850
As it progresses in becoming the standard,
you're going to be set to go.

319
00:16:39.850 --> 00:16:41.890
It's gonna be nothing for you.

320
00:16:41.890 --> 00:16:44.880
All right, Ronnie, well thank you so
much for those demonstrations as well.

321
00:16:44.880 --> 00:16:46.800
And thank you, everyone, for watching.

322
00:16:46.800 --> 00:16:48.856
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

323
00:16:48.856 --> 00:16:50.420
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrey.

324
00:16:50.420 --> 00:16:51.100
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

325
00:16:51.100 --> 00:16:52.327
>> And we'll see you next time.

326
00:16:52.327 --> 00:16:58.849
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie cover the topic of Domain Name Resolution or DNS which enables you and I to use human language to interact with computers that rely on numbered addresses for communication. They explain how we use DNS to convert the name of a website to the actual IP address instead of needing to remember a myriad of IP addresses ourselves.
episodes.title: Understanding Name Resolution
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.087 --> 00:00:10.129
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.129 --> 00:00:14.310
All right greetings everyone, welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.310 --> 00:00:18.490
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, here with me
today is none other than Mr Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:18.490 --> 00:00:19.570
How's it going today Ronnie?

5
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:20.580
>> It's going great today.

6
00:00:20.580 --> 00:00:24.330
Today we're looking at the MTA,
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

7
00:00:24.330 --> 00:00:28.836
We're talking about networking
fundamentals, the exam 98-366.

8
00:00:28.836 --> 00:00:33.532
So if you are preparing for that exam you
are in the right place as we continue on

9
00:00:33.532 --> 00:00:38.030
talking about just some of the basic
foundational networking concepts.

10
00:00:38.030 --> 00:00:40.500
And that's what we want to get into today.

11
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:45.600
And specifically, this is actually one
of the concepts that you're using and

12
00:00:45.600 --> 00:00:47.960
I'm using even if you don't
know you're using it.

13
00:00:47.960 --> 00:00:50.788
So, you're probably a master at using
the concepts of name resolution,

14
00:00:50.788 --> 00:00:52.212
that's what we're talking about.

15
00:00:52.212 --> 00:00:53.837
>> That's right, so thank you for
joining us today, no.

16
00:00:53.837 --> 00:00:56.629
[LAUGH] We're gonna give you
a little more than that.

17
00:00:56.629 --> 00:01:00.829
That's right, DNS,
the domain name resolution or

18
00:01:00.829 --> 00:01:05.230
systems as we like to do,
is the topic of choice today.

19
00:01:05.230 --> 00:01:09.120
And it's basically how we take our
computer, and have it understand what

20
00:01:09.120 --> 00:01:13.190
the heck we're telling it to do when
it comes to the Internet specifically.

21
00:01:13.190 --> 00:01:15.040
And that's what we want to do,
and that's why Ronnie said,

22
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:17.030
you're probably using this technology.

23
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:20.160
And you don't even realize it because
every time you open a web browser and

24
00:01:20.160 --> 00:01:25.830
you type in www.something something
something.com, well that is using DNS.

25
00:01:25.830 --> 00:01:28.950
And you're thinking, well, okay, I get it,

26
00:01:28.950 --> 00:01:32.440
I get to type in a name,
that's interesting, I guess.

27
00:01:32.440 --> 00:01:34.630
It is actually a little more
interesting than it sounds just on

28
00:01:34.630 --> 00:01:35.902
the surface of things.

29
00:01:35.902 --> 00:01:39.231
Because it's basically how we can interact
with a computer that doesn't really speak

30
00:01:39.231 --> 00:01:40.090
our language.

31
00:01:40.090 --> 00:01:43.570
It's kind of the intermediary between
the two languages, English or

32
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:48.100
whatever language you speak, and the
computer language of numbers and bits and

33
00:01:48.100 --> 00:01:49.650
binary and all that other good stuff,
right Ronnie?

34
00:01:49.650 --> 00:01:51.930
>> There is no doubt.
That's a great description to think about.

35
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:55.750
Remember that when computers need to
be able to communicate with each other,

36
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:59.060
well really what they need to have on
their systems is fairly something simple

37
00:01:59.060 --> 00:02:00.510
as a IP address.

38
00:02:00.510 --> 00:02:04.330
Well computers can work with
the binary numbering, easily,

39
00:02:04.330 --> 00:02:06.110
to them it is second nature to them.

40
00:02:06.110 --> 00:02:09.120
Just like,
language is second nature to us.

41
00:02:09.120 --> 00:02:11.740
But the problem that we have is that
the computers really don't need to

42
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:13.208
communicate with each other.

43
00:02:13.208 --> 00:02:15.880
We're the ones that are using
the computers, the computers

44
00:02:15.880 --> 00:02:18.762
then need to actually connect to each
other to get the information that we need,

45
00:02:18.762 --> 00:02:21.270
and that's where the key comes in.

46
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:24.610
What we have the ability to
do is if we are someone that

47
00:02:24.610 --> 00:02:26.310
can actually memorize numbers.

48
00:02:26.310 --> 00:02:30.640
If we're like Daniel and he has that mind,
that still trap mind to memorize

49
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:33.663
every single number that he
sees at the drop of a hat,

50
00:02:33.663 --> 00:02:37.671
well, all we have to do is actually
be able to communicate like that.

51
00:02:37.671 --> 00:02:42.254
Daniel can actually just say,
oh yes I'm connecting to 192.168.10.12.

52
00:02:42.254 --> 00:02:46.713
Oh no, I'm gonna connect to 172.31.254.73.

53
00:02:46.713 --> 00:02:48.837
And he might be able to remember all that.

54
00:02:48.837 --> 00:02:52.978
But most of us, most of us mere humans,
mere humans like me,

55
00:02:52.978 --> 00:02:56.640
we actually need something
easier to do that.

56
00:02:56.640 --> 00:02:57.890
And that is names.

57
00:02:57.890 --> 00:03:01.730
So, when we actually talk about the idea
of names, computers don't care.

58
00:03:01.730 --> 00:03:03.690
Computers care nothing about names.

59
00:03:03.690 --> 00:03:06.690
Nothing about any human
readable format that there is.

60
00:03:06.690 --> 00:03:09.710
Computers can use IP addresses,
could care less about names.

61
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:12.800
Humans, though, we actually use names and
use those a lot easier.

62
00:03:12.800 --> 00:03:15.860
Now if you're super human like Daniel,
you don't have to worry about that.

63
00:03:15.860 --> 00:03:16.970
But if you're like me,

64
00:03:16.970 --> 00:03:21.270
just kind of regular old human self,
names are actually a lot easier.

65
00:03:21.270 --> 00:03:25.580
And somebody actually taught me this cuz
I was thinking, how do you get across

66
00:03:25.580 --> 00:03:29.330
how easy it is, and why this is actually
something good for us to remember.

67
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:30.770
And somebody actually said this.

68
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:32.050
Well, Ronnie, think about it this way.

69
00:03:33.600 --> 00:03:36.800
Tell me the name of the very
first girlfriend you had.

70
00:03:36.800 --> 00:03:37.610
That's fairly simple.

71
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:38.360
And I was able to do so.

72
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:41.980
And then they turn around and said, all
right, tell me what her phone number is.

73
00:03:41.980 --> 00:03:44.050
And all of a sudden I'm like,
I don't have a clue.

74
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:47.560
I really don't have a clue
what her phone number is now.

75
00:03:47.560 --> 00:03:48.940
I really don't.

76
00:03:48.940 --> 00:03:52.830
And so, when we think about that for
networking and for

77
00:03:52.830 --> 00:03:56.710
being able to connect computers together
in a human way that makes it easy,

78
00:03:56.710 --> 00:03:59.950
well it's a lot easier for
me to put a name to a device.

79
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:02.250
And even though it has a unique address,

80

sort of like a phone number I don't have

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain two of the most widely used networking services, namely the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol(DHCP) and Remote access. They walk you through the process of dynamically assigning IP addresses using DHCP services. Then they show you how to use the different Remote Access methods like Remote Desktop and Remote Assistance, found in the Microsoft operating systems.
episodes.title: Understanding Network Services
