00:26:45.760 --> 00:26:48.130
Let me use my domain credentials,

503
00:26:48.130 --> 00:26:50.980
sometimes I may actually
type that in incorrectly.

504
00:26:50.980 --> 00:26:54.000
So you need to have the credentials that
will actually allow you to get access in

505
00:26:54.000 --> 00:26:55.140
or you cant do it.

506
00:26:55.140 --> 00:26:57.080
And then I can click OK.

507
00:26:57.080 --> 00:26:58.520
And now, there it is.

508
00:26:58.520 --> 00:27:01.650
It's an application that's
running on top of my desktop.

509
00:27:01.650 --> 00:27:04.020
If I do it this way,
you can see that, right?

510
00:27:04.020 --> 00:27:08.280
So from any machine on my network,
as long as I have access to that one,

511
00:27:08.280 --> 00:27:12.380
I can now sit here and configure this
machine the way that I want to and

512
00:27:12.380 --> 00:27:14.900
be able to work with it perfectly fine.

513
00:27:14.900 --> 00:27:16.942
So you can use this remote access for

514
00:27:16.942 --> 00:27:20.973
control of those machines instead of
having to go to every single one.

515
00:27:20.973 --> 00:27:24.571
Now it doesn't mean that it's always
gonna be turned on on every machine,

516
00:27:24.571 --> 00:27:28.810
normally you do want to limit it to
the ones that you do need to connect to.

517
00:27:28.810 --> 00:27:32.430
And what I was doing is, always
the servers that I was in charge of,

518
00:27:32.430 --> 00:27:34.530
that I would actually be able to do this.

519
00:27:34.530 --> 00:27:38.800
So, it actually does give you nice control
because it's sitting here just like

520
00:27:38.800 --> 00:27:44.100
I was sitting directly at that machine's
terminal, keyboard and everything.

521
00:27:44.100 --> 00:27:47.400
And then I can gain access,
I can configure, I can change things, and

522
00:27:47.400 --> 00:27:50.300
I can manage it directly from
wherever I am in the world.

523
00:27:50.300 --> 00:27:53.690
It really is one of the neatest
services that we end up using,

524
00:27:53.690 --> 00:27:55.980
that makes an impact and the difference.

525
00:27:55.980 --> 00:27:57.410
Now somebody can call me up and says,

526
00:27:57.410 --> 00:28:00.100
hey look I don't have access
to what I think I need.

527
00:28:00.100 --> 00:28:02.570
I can go ahead and check that
out even if I'm sitting at home,

528
00:28:02.570 --> 00:28:05.830
I can use this remote desktop connection,
and it works perfectly fine.

529
00:28:05.830 --> 00:28:07.960
And it's just like I'm
right there at the server.

530
00:28:07.960 --> 00:28:08.974
Very neat technology.

531
00:28:08.974 --> 00:28:10.530
>> Oh yeah, it's great technology.

532
00:28:10.530 --> 00:28:14.230
As administrators, once you get into that
role of you actually having to support

533
00:28:14.230 --> 00:28:17.410
maybe some services or
a server this is your bread and butter.

534
00:28:17.410 --> 00:28:20.290
You're not gonna be going in and
out of the server room.

535
00:28:20.290 --> 00:28:21.550
I'll give you a primary example.

536
00:28:21.550 --> 00:28:27.080
On my desk and office literally was
four feet from the server closet.

537
00:28:28.220 --> 00:28:31.540
I could have easily gotten up from my
desk, walked into the server room,

538
00:28:31.540 --> 00:28:34.270
grabbed a keyboard, mouse, and monitor,
and went to town on the server.

539
00:28:34.270 --> 00:28:35.750
I never did that.

540
00:28:35.750 --> 00:28:40.880
Only if things went completely haywire
did I actually enter the server room

541
00:28:40.880 --> 00:28:41.800
to do something?

542
00:28:41.800 --> 00:28:46.060
I sat at my desk, I used Remote Desktop
Connection to access those servers,

543
00:28:46.060 --> 00:28:48.130
because it's a whole lot more convenient.

544
00:28:48.130 --> 00:28:51.680
And it's not like I'm limited to one
server, I could have five servers open if

545
00:28:51.680 --> 00:28:55.200
I want to, all in different tabs,
all doing different things.

546
00:28:55.200 --> 00:28:57.150
It makes that administration
that much easier.

547
00:28:57.150 --> 00:29:00.750
I never leave the comfort of my own
chair to be able to access those,

548
00:29:00.750 --> 00:29:04.130
make changes, allocate resources,
do whatever it is I need to do.

549
00:29:04.130 --> 00:29:08.400
And Ronnie you made a really good point
when it came to who has access to this.

550
00:29:08.400 --> 00:29:12.365
Just because you go in and enable remote
desktop doesn't mean you're just going to

551
00:29:12.365 --> 00:29:16.345
be, but okay now I can use my credentials
here and jump right on that server.

552
00:29:16.345 --> 00:29:20.515
Only by default I think
is the administrators and

553
00:29:20.515 --> 00:29:24.485
the remote desktop users,
have access to this.

554
00:29:24.485 --> 00:29:27.325
So you either need to be in
the administrators group or

555
00:29:27.325 --> 00:29:31.005
in a group that is in the remote
desktop administrators group.

556
00:29:31.005 --> 00:29:32.605
So it's very controlled.

557
00:29:32.605 --> 00:29:35.190
They don't want just anybody
having access to those things.

558
00:29:35.190 --> 00:29:40.310
There is also the remote assistance as
well, which is similar but different.

559
00:29:40.310 --> 00:29:44.310
But like I said, it's very similar in
any ability that you're able to look at

560
00:29:44.310 --> 00:29:47.210
a computer and make changes,
click on items, and

561
00:29:47.210 --> 00:29:51.550
it's from your computer to a computer
that is nowhere near you at all.

562
00:29:51.550 --> 00:29:54.460
Or even if it is sitting right
next to you, you're remote in, so

563
00:29:54.460 --> 00:29:56.260
you don't have to use two
different keyboards and stuff.

564
00:29:56.260 --> 00:29:58.810
>> Yeah, when you are actually using
remote assistance, it's because somebody

565
00:29:58.810 --> 00:30:01.970
is asking you to connect in,
to do some type of troubleshooting.

566
00:30:01.970 --> 00:30:03.200
But on most of these things,

567
00:30:03.200 --> 00:30:07.100
like you also saw on the server program
there, that option is grayed out.

568
00:30:07.100 --> 00:30:08.890
So you can't find it on
every single machine,

569
00:30:08.890 --> 00:30:12.440
because they don't ever expect
a server to actually be using that.

570
00:30:12.440 --> 00:30:14.120
But setting up these services,

571
00:30:14.120 --> 00:30:17.450
these are kind of key elements
that in networking really do help.

572
00:30:17.450 --> 00:30:21.300
Because you do, you have access to so many
more devices by being able to do that on

573
00:30:21.300 --> 00:30:24.160
machines, so
that you can manage them a lot easier.

574
00:30:24.160 --> 00:30:29.940
And networking, the services really
are all about making networking easier so

575
00:30:29.940 --> 00:30:33.290
that we can control a lot
more by using a lot less.

576
00:30:33.290 --> 00:30:37.180
And so dynamic host configuration
protocol remote access are just

577
00:30:37.180 --> 00:30:41.950
two of the foundational ones that you're
gonna find yourself in a lot of times.

578
00:30:41.950 --> 00:30:43.600
Just verifying that it works and

579
00:30:43.600 --> 00:30:47.370
then of course with remote access you can
actually do that across multiple machines

580
00:30:47.370 --> 00:30:50.850
and it really does make it easy and
makes it do what networks should do.

581
00:30:50.850 --> 00:30:51.560
>> Yes.

582
00:30:51.560 --> 00:30:53.410
All right, Ronnie,
we've covered a lot of ground today,

583
00:30:53.410 --> 00:30:55.070
even though it was just a few topics.

584
00:30:55.070 --> 00:30:56.860
Obviously very important ones.

585
00:30:56.860 --> 00:30:59.190
We thank you for your demonstrations and
your explanations.

586
00:30:59.190 --> 00:31:02.170
Is there anything else we need to cover
before we let these good people go?

587
00:31:02.170 --> 00:31:05.830
>> No just kind of remember that the
services, don't get confused by that term,

588
00:31:05.830 --> 00:31:10.310
it really is just software that's running
on that computer that we configure.

589
00:31:10.310 --> 00:31:13.560
And you and I shouldn't have to touch
it again unless something breaks.

590
00:31:13.560 --> 00:31:16.380
So when somebody says that,
when somebody tries to sound impressive,

591
00:31:16.380 --> 00:31:18.650
oh I'm running six or
seven servers, you're gonna go.

592
00:31:18.650 --> 00:31:19.910
Okay, fine.

593
00:31:19.910 --> 00:31:23.110
Don't get me wrong, it does take
some skill to configure them right,

594
00:31:23.110 --> 00:31:24.630
to do whatever they need to.

595
00:31:24.630 --> 00:31:27.600
But when it comes down to it,
that's really the goal of the server.

596
00:31:27.600 --> 00:31:30.840
Configure it once, leave it alone,
let it do its job.

597
00:31:30.840 --> 00:31:33.690
No human really needs to interact
with it after that unless it breaks.

598
00:31:33.690 --> 00:31:35.420
>> That's right.
Let's automate our entire lives,

599
00:31:35.420 --> 00:31:36.660
that's what I'm talking about.

600
00:31:36.660 --> 00:31:39.150
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> All right everyone,
hopefully you've enjoyed this episode,

601
00:31:39.150 --> 00:31:40.140
you got a lot out of it.

602
00:31:40.140 --> 00:31:41.470
We had a great time making it for you.

603
00:31:41.470 --> 00:31:42.970
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

604
00:31:42.970 --> 00:31:45.420
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowry.

605
00:31:45.420 --> 00:31:46.070
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

606
00:31:46.070 --> 00:31:47.815
>> And we'll see you next time.

607
00:31:47.815 --> 00:31:51.631
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe some of the different tools and protocols used to help troubleshoot and verify network connectivity. Some of the tools and protocols discussed include: ping, tracert, ipconfig, DNS, telnet, and Netstat.
episodes.title: Understanding TCP/IP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.314
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.314 --> 00:00:11.951
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.951 --> 00:00:14.841
Welcome to another fantastic
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.841 --> 00:00:18.961
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, joining me
today is none other than good old Mr.

5
00:00:18.961 --> 00:00:19.540
Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.540 --> 00:00:20.490
How's it going today, Ronnie?

7
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:21.540
>> It's going great today.

8
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:25.220
We're here to take a look at the MTA,
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

9
00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:29.730
Getting ready for exam 98366,
that Networking Fundamentals exam.

10
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:32.870
So, that's the one you're preparing for,
you are in the right place.

11
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:36.490
What we're gonna take a look at today
is we're gonna talk a little bit about

12
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:39.800
the TCP/IP protocols is
what we're talking about.

13
00:00:39.800 --> 00:00:40.660
A lot of times when you hear

14
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:43.890
this term you're actually talking
about what's called a protocol family.

15
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:45.740
Or you may hear the term
protocol suite and,

16
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:48.420
what the heck does that actually mean for
us?

17
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:51.263
Well, when we start taking
a look at the idea of TCP/IP,

18
00:00:51.263 --> 00:00:53.411
when we start talking about the protocol.

19
00:00:53.411 --> 00:00:56.508
Usually, you'll hear it called
that language of the internet,

20
00:00:56.508 --> 00:00:58.210
which is what TCP/IP is.

21
00:00:58.210 --> 00:01:02.270
And what that means is that we are gonna
be following the rules set fourth

22
00:01:02.270 --> 00:01:06.480
by that picker protocol standard is
what we're gonna actually be able to do.

23
00:01:06.480 --> 00:01:10.415
So there are many different types of
protocol families that are out there.

24
00:01:10.415 --> 00:01:14.660
But on the internet the one that
we use is what we call TCP/IP.

25
00:01:14.660 --> 00:01:19.070
So included in TCP/IP is not only
the rules about communication and

26
00:01:19.070 --> 00:01:22.790
things like addressing the IP
addressing that we use on the internet.

27
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:26.500
It also has to deal with a lot of
ways that we transfer the data, and

28
00:01:26.500 --> 00:01:31.030
it also ends up dealing with the way
that the OSI model also works, too.

29
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:34.420
So it really does define two
things right at the beginning.

30
00:01:34.420 --> 00:01:39.710
TCP, if you remember from the early shows
where we talked about the OSI model,

31
00:01:39.710 --> 00:01:41.790
happens on layer four.

32
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:45.618
And what that's really describing is
the type of connection that needs to

33
00:01:45.618 --> 00:01:48.778
be made between devices before
data is actually exchanged.

34
00:01:48.778 --> 00:01:53.033
And then IP, which happens on
layer three of the OSI model,

35
00:01:53.033 --> 00:01:55.850
tells you the way that we deliver that.

36
00:01:55.850 --> 00:01:58.210
In other words the addressing
scheme that we use.

37
00:01:58.210 --> 00:02:02.956
So in the beginning of networking across
the internet what used to always happen is

38
00:02:02.956 --> 00:02:05.930
that every single piece of
data before it was sent.

39
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:08.342
Those connections had
to be established and

40
00:02:08.342 --> 00:02:12.140
synchronized before we would
transmit data to each other.

41
00:02:12.140 --> 00:02:15.720
After a while what started to happen was
this, is that they started realizing

42
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:20.270
not every single piece of data needs to
actually have a synchronization first.

43
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:23.420
There's some data that we can just send,
so they even included in that

44
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:28.520
User Datagram Protocol stuff after awhile,
and once they did that they were fine.

45
00:02:28.520 --> 00:02:30.790
So now we have the addressing
that we're using on the internet.

46
00:02:30.790 --> 00:02:35.216
We understand that we can actually send
data whether or not the actual machines

47
00:02:35.216 --> 00:02:39.340
have a direct connection or
whether actually they don't have one.

48
00:02:39.340 --> 00:02:41.850
It's perfectly fine and we can do that.

49
00:02:41.850 --> 00:02:46.361
So along with that they introduced,
of course, other protocols and

50
00:02:46.361 --> 00:02:50.657
other utilities and tools to help
us out when we needed to verify.

51
00:02:50.657 --> 00:02:54.220
Or when we needed to do a little bit
of troubleshooting to ensure that

52
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:57.340
the entire networking
would also end up working.

53
00:02:57.340 --> 00:02:59.452
So we wanna do a little bit of a reminder.

54
00:02:59.452 --> 00:03:03.394
As well as just show us some of the tools
that we're gonna be using when we start

55
00:03:03.394 --> 00:03:06.427
talking about the use of TCP/IP and
being able to verify and

56
00:03:06.427 --> 00:03:08.993
being able to do a little
bit of troubleshooting.

57
00:03:08.993 --> 00:03:13.970
>> Yeah, TCP/IP has a lot of really
cool tools actually that are built

58
00:03:13.970 --> 00:03:16.250
into that suite of protocols.

59
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:18.510
It's starts getting a little confusing.

60
00:03:18.510 --> 00:03:22.710
It's like well, I've got a TCP protocol,
I've got an IP protocol and

61
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:24.545
now they're a TCP/IP protocol.

62
00:03:24.545 --> 00:03:28.075
And I've got tools that use
those protocols that yes,

63
00:03:28.075 --> 00:03:29.345
it does get a little layered.

64
00:03:29.345 --> 00:03:31.830
Really what it boils down to is this,

65
00:03:31.830 --> 00:03:36.410
is PCP/IP is the suite of protocols
that we use to talk on a network.

66
00:03:36.410 --> 00:03:36.955
Right?

67
00:03:36.955 --> 00:03:41.692
And then there are tools that utilize that
suite of protocols for us to verify things

68
00:03:41.692 --> 00:03:46.000
like activity, troubleshoot problems,
all that other good stuff.

69
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:49.995
And then there are even other protocols
that you use that suite of protocols.

70
00:03:49.995 --> 00:03:51.477
I know, right?

71
00:03:51.477 --> 00:03:53.676
It's a crazy wrapped up ball of string.

72
00:03:53.676 --> 00:03:57.380
As you start unraveling it,
it starts to make more sense though.

73
00:03:57.380 --> 00:04:00.331
But those other protocols
that we use to send data and

74
00:04:00.331 --> 00:04:03.284
do specific types of connection for
our computers,

75
00:04:03.284 --> 00:04:07.259
making sure that they are connected
correctly and working as needed.

76
00:04:07.259 --> 00:04:07.761
And Ronnie,

77
00:04:07.761 --> 00:04:10.823
we're gonna start off with some tools,
because well that's where the fun is.

78
00:04:10.823 --> 00:04:12.390
Right?
>> That really is.

79
00:04:12.390 --> 00:04:16.210
It's one of those things that we as
technicians really do need to understand.

80
00:04:16.210 --> 00:04:20.160
Some of the basic command line utilities
that you are gonna have to be able

81
00:04:20.160 --> 00:04:24.130
to not only see but know what they do,
as well as be able to use.

82
00:04:24.130 --> 00:04:26.790
So let's go ahead and
take a look at a few of them right here.

83
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:29.170
So on my screen I went ahead and
launched a command prompt.

84
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:31.910
I'm running server 2008 r2, and

85
00:04:31.910 --> 00:04:35.250
right here I've just brought up
a command prompt to help us out.

86
00:04:35.250 --> 00:04:38.260
One of the initial tools that we
should be familiar with that's

87
00:04:38.260 --> 00:04:42.930
found in our TCP/IP protocol suite
is is gonna be what we call ping.

88
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:47.270
Ping allows us to test for
basic connectivity between my machine and

89
00:04:47.270 --> 00:04:49.640
whatever the end device is.

90
00:04:49.640 --> 00:04:52.020
Now the reason why one
established basic connectivity,

91
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:56.380
of course, is that if I can't get
a ping through, I can't expect for

92
00:04:56.380 --> 00:04:58.740
any other traffic to get through as well.

93
00:04:58.740 --> 00:05:02.430
So either the other side is answering or
the other side is not.

94
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:06.520
Ping is the best connectivity tool that
we have and it really does help us

95
00:05:06.520 --> 00:05:10.960
out in a pinch to verify, hey,
the other side is up and ready to respond.

96
00:05:10.960 --> 00:05:13.370
So normally when we start
off it's fairly simple.

97
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:17.230
We can actually do ping and then we can
pick an address out there on the internet.

98
00:05:17.230 --> 00:05:21.130
So if I should do something like,
let's just do ITPro.tv.

99
00:05:21.130 --> 00:05:25.850
If I do that, notice that what ends up
happening right now is that what we get is

100
00:05:25.850 --> 00:05:31.950
this little bit of information, and ping
inside of Windows sends out four packets.

101
00:05:31.950 --> 00:05:34.958
And what it does is expecting,
well, replies to come back as well.

102
00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:38.349
Now if you were to do this, let's say,
in another type of machine,

103
00:05:38.349 --> 00:05:41.750
like in the Linus world or
something, this goes on forever.

104
00:05:41.750 --> 00:05:44.950
But here in Microsoft, they said look,
four is enough to verify and

105
00:05:44.950 --> 00:05:46.500
test what we're looking for.

106
00:05:46.500 --> 00:05:48.600
And in this line of what we see.

107
00:05:48.600 --> 00:05:52.490
Right?
I ping the name, and then it also returned

108
00:05:52.490 --> 00:05:57.450
to me the IP address and it told me
how much data was also sent too.

109
00:05:57.450 --> 00:05:59.730
And notice we have 32 bytes of data and

110
00:05:59.730 --> 00:06:03.680
each one is returned in
a time period that we see.

111
00:06:03.680 --> 00:06:05.170
What we're really looking for, right,

112
00:06:05.170 --> 00:06:08.850
is that we get all four replies
that come back, which means, hey.

113
00:06:08.850 --> 00:06:13.245
I'm actually able to send and to able
to get data perfectly fine from them.

114
00:06:13.245 --> 00:06:14.765
And the other thing that we're looking for

115
00:06:14.765 --> 00:06:18.075
is this time period where you see
it in milliseconds or microseconds.

116
00:06:18.075 --> 00:06:19.365
I think it's milliseconds here.

117
00:06:19.365 --> 00:06:22.625
It's 28 milliseconds is what
we're expecting to see.

118
00:06:22.625 --> 00:06:24.815
When you start getting
into the hundreds or

119
00:06:24.815 --> 00:06:27.415
two hundred millisecond range
in getting this stuff back.

120
00:06:27.415 --> 00:06:30.706
You're now starting to actually have
it where you are experiencing lag at

121
00:06:30.706 --> 00:06:31.298
that point.

122
00:06:31.298 --> 00:06:34.570
But, that's not so important for
what we're talking about right here.

123
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:38.060
The key is actually about is
the other side answering.

124
00:06:38.060 --> 00:06:40.600
Is it actually getting
back what we expect?

125
00:06:40.600 --> 00:06:45.390
If we get losses, that may indicate
that somewhere along that path

126
00:06:45.390 --> 00:06:49.250
is not actually up and
it's not actually doing what we need to.

127
00:06:49.250 --> 00:06:53.970
And so they either rerouted it
somewhere or what happened is that

128
00:06:53.970 --> 00:06:58.650
particular interface has actually gone up
and then went down and came back up again.

129
00:06:58.650 --> 00:07:01.450
We only get, let's say,
three out of the four that comes in.

130
00:07:01.450 --> 00:07:04.250
Or it could just be it's a little
bit of a delayed response.

131
00:07:04.250 --> 00:07:06.660
So this is one of the initial
things that we have to do.

132
00:07:06.660 --> 00:07:08.330
Now when we start talking about it,

133
00:07:08.330 --> 00:07:12.210
there is an order to the way that
we should ping devices as well.

134
00:07:12.210 --> 00:07:15.000
Depending on what we're
trying to establish here.

135
00:07:15.000 --> 00:07:18.110
So internally,
if I'm actually inside of my network,

136
00:07:18.110 --> 00:07:22.210
normally the way that we do this is that
we normally need to ping ourselves first.

137
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:23.760
So what we do is we ping 127.

138
00:07:23.760 --> 00:07:24.626
Oops.

139
00:07:24.626 --> 00:07:30.160
172 [LAUGH] 127.0.0.1 and
that is my loop back address.

140
00:07:30.160 --> 00:07:33.950
That indicates to me that
my own network adapter

141
00:07:33.950 --> 00:07:38.985
can actually be able to respond to,
well a command that's being sent to it.

142
00:07:38.985 --> 00:07:42.785
So I know that my network adapter
card can send and receive.

143
00:07:42.785 --> 00:07:45.252
And that is actually just
verifying that that is good.

144
00:07:45.252 --> 00:07:48.517
The next thing that we
might choose to do is ping

145
00:07:48.517 --> 00:07:51.709
another device inside
of my network as well.

146
00:07:51.709 --> 00:07:53.169
And I'm going to ping my default gateway,

147
00:07:53.169 --> 00:07:55.780
cuz that's the only other machine that
I have on this network for right now.

148
00:07:55.780 --> 00:07:57.668
So I'm going to ping that.

149
00:07:57.668 --> 00:08:01.473
But with that default gateway,
now I know that, internally on my network,

150
00:08:01.473 --> 00:08:04.920
things are still good because I can
actually reach another machine,

151
00:08:04.920 --> 00:08:07.016
the other machine is reaching back to me.

152
00:08:07.016 --> 00:08:11.525
And then we can actually ping
outside of our network as well.

153
00:08:11.525 --> 00:08:16.065
So there's a couple of DNS servers that
have been around for a long time as well.

154
00:08:16.065 --> 00:08:21.815
And so right there 4.2.2.1 is one that we
can also use and I'm getting reply back.

155
00:08:21.815 --> 00:08:24.338
By doing this I'm verifying each path or

156
00:08:24.338 --> 00:08:28.947
each step along the way that I have
good connectivity to be able to do that.

157
00:08:28.947 --> 00:08:33.072
And that is the order that you do want to
follow when you are trying to ping cuz it

158
00:08:33.072 --> 00:08:34.229
could be that you do.

159
00:08:34.229 --> 00:08:38.760
You have a ping perfectly fine between
you and another machine on your network.

160
00:08:38.760 --> 00:08:42.560
But if you can't get past your default
gateway, well, the last place that you can

161
00:08:42.560 --> 00:08:46.620
ping, or the last place you can't ping, is
probably where your issue is going to be.

162
00:08:46.620 --> 00:08:52.310
So this little tiny tool as you go, what's
the big deal about finding out about it?

163
00:08:52.310 --> 00:08:55.010
But notice a lot of
the information that we get back

164
00:08:55.010 --> 00:08:57.570
is from actually understanding
where the pings stop.

165
00:08:57.570 --> 00:09:00.390
And understanding the order that
can actually lead us to where it's

166
00:09:00.390 --> 00:09:01.880
actually gonna be where we have a problem.

167
00:09:01.880 --> 00:09:02.680
Pretty cool.

168
00:09:02.680 --> 00:09:04.590
>> Definitely, very, very cool.

169
00:09:04.590 --> 00:09:06.100
I'll tell you what.
I've been doing this job for

170
00:09:06.100 --> 00:09:08.420
quite a while now,
probably over ten years.

171
00:09:08.420 --> 00:09:11.380
Ping is one of the tools that
I use almost on a daily basis.

172
00:09:11.380 --> 00:09:13.810
I'm always verifying connectivity
because what happens is,

173
00:09:13.810 --> 00:09:17.100
a lot of people will say I'm
having network trouble, right?

174
00:09:17.100 --> 00:09:19.180
And oh, okay,
my computer's running slowly.

175
00:09:19.180 --> 00:09:21.920
Maybe those milliseconds
are way jacked up and

176
00:09:21.920 --> 00:09:25.630
they would be experiencing some
sort of slowdown in web traffic.

177
00:09:25.630 --> 00:09:27.730
So you wanna check that ping does that for
us.

178
00:09:27.730 --> 00:09:29.770
Ping checks that connectivity.

179
00:09:29.770 --> 00:09:31.710
I can't print to the printer.

180
00:09:31.710 --> 00:09:33.400
Well do you have connectivity
with the printer?

181
00:09:33.400 --> 00:09:34.860
You go sit down at their computer.

182
00:09:34.860 --> 00:09:37.210
You ping the printer if it's
a network-based printer.

183
00:09:37.210 --> 00:09:38.060
If you get a reply,

184
00:09:38.060 --> 00:09:41.510
well at least you know that network
connectivity is not the problem.

185
00:09:41.510 --> 00:09:44.410
At that point, it's probably some sort
of issue with the print driver or

186
00:09:44.410 --> 00:09:45.900
the print device itself.

187
00:09:45.900 --> 00:09:47.150
But not the network.

188
00:09:47.150 --> 00:09:50.890
If I don't get a reply from the printer,
well I found my problem.

189
00:09:50.890 --> 00:09:52.080
Ping does that for us.

190
00:09:52.080 --> 00:09:55.500
And even out to letting me know,
all right, I've pinged myself,

191
00:09:55.500 --> 00:09:56.600
I know I'm working.

192
00:09:56.600 --> 00:09:58.710
I've pinged my gateway like Ronnie's done.

193
00:09:58.710 --> 00:10:02.238
I know that every device inside of
my network is working properly.

194
00:10:02.238 --> 00:10:04.408
But I'm not able to get to ITProTV.

195
00:10:04.408 --> 00:10:05.760
I ping ITProTV.

196
00:10:05.760 --> 00:10:06.840
I get nothing.

197
00:10:06.840 --> 00:10:08.910
And now I know, problem's not inside.

198
00:10:08.910 --> 00:10:12.990
It's outside of my network because I
pinged up to the edge of my network.

199
00:10:12.990 --> 00:10:14.470
And everything's working fine.

200
00:10:14.470 --> 00:10:17.070
The problem must lie somewhere else.

201
00:10:17.070 --> 00:10:19.180
And Ronnie that brings us actually
to another tool, doesn't it?

202
00:10:19.180 --> 00:10:20.000
>> It really does.

203
00:10:20.000 --> 00:10:23.220
Once we actually understand ping is
showing us what it's showing us and

204
00:10:23.220 --> 00:10:26.430
we can't get past that the way
that Daniel was describing.

205
00:10:26.430 --> 00:10:29.650
We actually do have another
utility that we can use,

206
00:10:29.650 --> 00:10:33.570
that will help us to pinpoint
where the issue will be.

207
00:10:33.570 --> 00:10:37.215
And that is something that we
call a trace RT or trace route.

208
00:10:37.215 --> 00:10:40.320
And in Microsoft,
it is actually limited to that.

209
00:10:40.320 --> 00:10:42.300
So it's trace RT.

210
00:10:42.300 --> 00:10:45.060
Now you may see it in other forms as well.

211
00:10:45.060 --> 00:10:47.240
You might see somebody actually
type out the word trace route.

212
00:10:47.240 --> 00:10:50.200
But here in Microsoft, this is
the way you're going to see it here.

213
00:10:50.200 --> 00:10:54.030
So, if I know that if I actually get
ping failures that come back, and

214
00:10:54.030 --> 00:10:56.700
I need to figure out where
it's actually failed,

215
00:10:56.700 --> 00:11:00.390
this only works if the failure
is past my network.

216
00:11:00.390 --> 00:11:03.190
So if I ping my default gateway,
and just like Daniel said,

217
00:11:03.190 --> 00:11:07.830
I still can't reach ITProTV, this is
a perfect opportunity for me to use this.

218
00:11:07.830 --> 00:11:10.020
But If I do a trace route and

219
00:11:10.020 --> 00:11:13.360
it's actually to another device inside
of my network, then I know this is not

220
00:11:13.360 --> 00:11:16.540
the one to use because that's not gonna
actually trace anywhere, because what

221
00:11:16.540 --> 00:11:19.970
we're expecting to find is different
network changes along the way, right?

222
00:11:19.970 --> 00:11:23.030
>> Yah, that's exactly right,
I'm looking to see what happens

223
00:11:23.030 --> 00:11:27.750
once the packet leaves my network,
or it goes to another network.

224
00:11:27.750 --> 00:11:30.390
It might be a network I actually own and
operate.

225
00:11:30.390 --> 00:11:34.100
But once it gets out of this network
that it's in, what happens to it?

226
00:11:34.100 --> 00:11:35.160
Does it continue on?

227
00:11:35.160 --> 00:11:36.990
Does it fail there?

228
00:11:36.990 --> 00:11:37.872
I don't know.

229
00:11:37.872 --> 00:11:41.440
Tracer RT, that helps me figure
out whether that is happening.

230
00:11:41.440 --> 00:11:44.970
Does it make it all the way to the end and
if it stops, where does it stop?

231
00:11:44.970 --> 00:11:49.750
Kinda showing us exactly where
the problem most likely is occurring

232
00:11:49.750 --> 00:11:53.950
if that trace route, you type in
the command and it goes to town.

233
00:11:53.950 --> 00:11:56.150
You find it stops and
it doesn't continue on.

234
00:11:56.150 --> 00:11:59.690
Well, it's probably hit somewhere that's
got a down link, something like that.

235
00:11:59.690 --> 00:12:02.240
Now you know exactly where
at least it's going down at.

236
00:12:02.240 --> 00:12:02.820
>> Right.

237
00:12:02.820 --> 00:12:05.370
So, we take a look at the output
of what's happening here.

238
00:12:05.370 --> 00:12:09.350
I went ahead and just did a trace
route out to ITProTV like we've said.

239
00:12:09.350 --> 00:12:11.370
And what we're actually
starting to see is right here.

240
00:12:11.370 --> 00:12:13.260
This is what we're normally looking for

241
00:12:13.260 --> 00:12:17.900
is this indication that nothing is
actually getting past that point.

242
00:12:17.900 --> 00:12:20.590
And the funny thing is,
this is my default gateway.

243
00:12:20.590 --> 00:12:23.800
So what we'd normally do is we would
troubleshoot right here to see what's

244
00:12:23.800 --> 00:12:25.330
actually causing the issue.

245
00:12:25.330 --> 00:12:28.362
Now on this one,
it is getting past it, right?

246
00:12:28.362 --> 00:12:32.070
So but this is the last point that you or
I have any information about.

247
00:12:32.070 --> 00:12:35.210
So that's why we would actually
troubleshoot beginning from that point.

248
00:12:35.210 --> 00:12:37.550
Whenever you see these
asterisks that are here,

249
00:12:37.550 --> 00:12:39.510
you're not getting any information back.

250
00:12:39.510 --> 00:12:44.690
But the funny thing is,
notice that it's still continuing on.

251
00:12:44.690 --> 00:12:46.230
So that means it's still trying.

252
00:12:46.230 --> 00:12:49.080
It's still actually doing
something in the background.

253
00:12:49.080 --> 00:12:53.210
And so this has a chance to go up
to it says maximum of 30 hops.

254
00:12:53.210 --> 00:12:55.110
So if it cant reach it in 30,
its just saying,

255
00:12:55.110 --> 00:12:56.800
look we dont know what to tell you.

256
00:12:56.800 --> 00:12:59.320
Its not out there,
its not what address your looking for.

257
00:12:59.320 --> 00:13:01.120
Something else must be wrong.

258
00:13:01.120 --> 00:13:02.550
But there is a possibility and

259
00:13:02.550 --> 00:13:05.810
theres a chance,
that this could be hidden on purpose.

260
00:13:05.810 --> 00:13:10.790
In other words, that look, these devices
in between are not returning something

261
00:13:10.790 --> 00:13:14.710
because they're choosing not to
return something, but in the end,

262
00:13:14.710 --> 00:13:18.200
if you still get the reply, in other
words, something that says, look, hey,

263
00:13:18.200 --> 00:13:22.300
you still made it there, but we're just
not showing you the path in between.

264
00:13:22.300 --> 00:13:25.720
Well that might be because it
is secured in some way somehow.

265
00:13:25.720 --> 00:13:27.640
Now in this one, I don't know
how long it's going to take, but

266
00:13:27.640 --> 00:13:30.580
I think I'd already previously
pulled this one up here.

267
00:13:30.580 --> 00:13:32.430
So that we could see it.

268
00:13:32.430 --> 00:13:36.110
So I ran this a little bit earlier,
right before we started here.

269
00:13:36.110 --> 00:13:40.860
And you can see that at number 11,
this did hit our firewall,

270
00:13:40.860 --> 00:13:42.260
is what it ended up hitting.

271
00:13:42.260 --> 00:13:46.240
So in between my machine and
that firewall, it didn't show anything.

272
00:13:46.240 --> 00:13:48.700
But this is what it
resolved to right here.

273
00:13:48.700 --> 00:13:50.120
And so, that actually means, hey,

274
00:13:50.120 --> 00:13:55.530
I did get the ITProTV, but I'm not showing
you any of the path in between because

275
00:13:55.530 --> 00:13:59.910
I don't really want you to know
how it actually traced out.

276
00:13:59.910 --> 00:14:01.890
And you can see right here
it actually did finish.

277
00:14:01.890 --> 00:14:05.380
This one a couple of hops later than
my early one did but you can see that.

278
00:14:05.380 --> 00:14:07.820
So sometimes it will show
you the end result so

279
00:14:07.820 --> 00:14:09.670
it's not that you're disconnected but

280
00:14:09.670 --> 00:14:12.740
just all the stuff in there like
yeah we're not showing that to you.

281
00:14:12.740 --> 00:14:14.750
>> Yeah it's interesting
Ronnie shows that.

282
00:14:14.750 --> 00:14:17.810
On the first time I ran this it
had less hops than this one.

283
00:14:17.810 --> 00:14:18.920
Well, what does that mean?

284
00:14:18.920 --> 00:14:21.820
It just means it took a different
path to get to the end work station.

285
00:14:21.820 --> 00:14:22.740
Sometimes that happens.

286
00:14:22.740 --> 00:14:25.950
As you route through the Internet,
you have no control over that.

287
00:14:25.950 --> 00:14:28.000
It could go this path,
it could go that path.

288
00:14:28.000 --> 00:14:31.410
Those routers figure out what's
the best path for you at that time, and

289
00:14:31.410 --> 00:14:32.180
that's how they send you.

290
00:14:32.180 --> 00:14:35.910
So be just aware that when
you do a trace route,

291
00:14:35.910 --> 00:14:39.990
it could show you less hops, more hops,
more information, less information.

292
00:14:39.990 --> 00:14:43.160
It just depends on the equipment
that you actually pass through and

293
00:14:43.160 --> 00:14:45.310
what it's designed to give you back.

294
00:14:45.310 --> 00:14:48.950
>> Yeah, the next one that we also want
to talk about is one we call path ping.

295
00:14:48.950 --> 00:14:50.810
Path ping does something very interesting.

296
00:14:50.810 --> 00:14:54.780
Remember where ping itself really just
shows whether or not we can get connected.

297
00:14:54.780 --> 00:14:57.472
And then trace route
shows the path along it.

298
00:14:57.472 --> 00:15:02.190
Path ping is kind of a combination
of both of these together as one.

299
00:15:02.190 --> 00:15:06.650
And when you can run path ping it's just
not very successful against ours cuz we

300
00:15:06.650 --> 00:15:09.170
do have good security and
we're very proud of that.

301
00:15:09.170 --> 00:15:12.850
But when you see the term path ping,
notice it begins tracing the route and

302
00:15:12.850 --> 00:15:15.380
it also does ping at the same time.

303
00:15:15.380 --> 00:15:18.110
And what we get from
this is more statistics,

304
00:15:18.110 --> 00:15:21.460
is what we're actually looking for
when we take a look at this.

305
00:15:21.460 --> 00:15:26.470
Normally, the type of statistics that are
shown here usually have to do with latency

306
00:15:26.470 --> 00:15:29.940
and have to do with the percentages of the
packets that are dropped along the way.

307
00:15:29.940 --> 00:15:33.650
And so if you do need that type of
information, path ping is the way to go.

308
00:15:33.650 --> 00:15:37.960
Now for this one, you can see what ends up
happening at the very beginning when they

309
00:15:37.960 --> 00:15:39.530
start off with trace route.

310
00:15:39.530 --> 00:15:42.050
They go ahead and they run that,
and they continue to try and

311
00:15:42.050 --> 00:15:43.800
run it until it gets to the very end.

312
00:15:43.800 --> 00:15:48.001
And then once they do, notice it says
it's computing statistic at this point.

313
00:15:48.001 --> 00:15:52.891
And the reason why that's important
is because it is trying to generate

314
00:15:52.891 --> 00:15:55.752
the best amount of statistics and value.

315
00:15:55.752 --> 00:15:58.830
So that you can actually determine where
things are actually happening, and

316
00:15:58.830 --> 00:16:00.322
where you're getting the latency.

317
00:16:00.322 --> 00:16:03.350
Where the things are actually
dropping out a lot of times here.

318
00:16:03.350 --> 00:16:07.470
Now because we do see where it's
ultimately gone from my machine, and

319
00:16:07.470 --> 00:16:09.520
then it's actually stopping some place.

320
00:16:09.520 --> 00:16:14.330
Well, it's saying, look your particular
pathing is not getting past well

321
00:16:14.330 --> 00:16:18.570
anything besides your default
gateway at this point.

322
00:16:18.570 --> 00:16:22.910
So my firewall, or at least at this
point here, my router is saying.

323
00:16:22.910 --> 00:16:24.610
Yeah, and go ahead and
PathPing all you want,

324
00:16:24.610 --> 00:16:26.760
I'm not showing you diddly squat here.

325
00:16:26.760 --> 00:16:29.720
So it can compute those statistics and
hand that back to me.

326
00:16:29.720 --> 00:16:33.190
Very good if you're really not sure if
things are happening the way that you

327
00:16:33.190 --> 00:16:34.050
think they are.

328
00:16:34.050 --> 00:16:37.320
But if you are getting slow down, PathPing
is probably the way that you will go

329
00:16:37.320 --> 00:16:39.910
instead that does show you
those statistics that you need.

330
00:16:39.910 --> 00:16:40.690
>> That's right.

331
00:16:40.690 --> 00:16:43.230
Obviously we're showing you some really
cool tools that give you a lot of

332
00:16:43.230 --> 00:16:47.860
information to figure out what is going
on via your network connectivity.

333
00:16:47.860 --> 00:16:49.100
And that's what it's all about.

334
00:16:49.100 --> 00:16:50.560
As you get into networking,

335
00:16:50.560 --> 00:16:54.090
these are things that you're gonna
use on a very rare regular basis.

336
00:16:54.090 --> 00:16:56.950
Another tool that you're probably
[LAUGH] gonna use almost daily,

337
00:16:56.950 --> 00:16:59.590
almost guaranteed, is ipconfig.

338
00:16:59.590 --> 00:17:03.150
In a Windows environment,
this is the go-to for figuring out

339
00:17:03.150 --> 00:17:07.200
on my end station that I'm actually
working with, what is its configuration?

340
00:17:07.200 --> 00:17:10.080
How's this thing set up to
actually talk to the network?

341
00:17:10.080 --> 00:17:11.280
And Ronnie, I don't know about you,

342
00:17:11.280 --> 00:17:15.250
but I've probably entered this
command half a million times.

343
00:17:15.250 --> 00:17:17.030
I mean a lot, we use it a lot.

344
00:17:17.030 --> 00:17:19.670
>> There is no doubt that this is one
of the main commands that you and

345
00:17:19.670 --> 00:17:20.950

You know everything that there
is about these commands.

573
00:29:15.700 --> 00:29:19.510
We really didn't do a lot, except for
just kind of the most basic commands

574
00:29:19.510 --> 00:29:21.700
that you'll probably encounter
out there in the field.

575
00:29:21.700 --> 00:29:23.650
>> That's right.
We're just trying to deep your toe into

576
00:29:23.650 --> 00:29:27.590
the water, get you acclimated to
the systems, and networking in general.

577
00:29:27.590 --> 00:29:30.410
That's really what this
course is all about.

578
00:29:30.410 --> 00:29:34.290
So, hopefully, you've seen some cool
stuff today, and you can use that,

579
00:29:34.290 --> 00:29:35.560
apply that in your life.

580
00:29:35.560 --> 00:29:36.620
And figure out, oh!

581
00:29:36.620 --> 00:29:39.760
If you're having networking
issues at home, maybe, or

582
00:29:39.760 --> 00:29:42.920
maybe you're at a job and
you're wanting to help out in that realm.

583
00:29:42.920 --> 00:29:45.920
Hey, you can take some of these tips and
tricks that we've shown you,

584
00:29:45.920 --> 00:29:48.900
using these tools, these protocols,
and apply them to that.

585
00:29:48.900 --> 00:29:52.800
Maybe try to help figure out and resolve
a network issue because I'm not lying to

586
00:29:52.800 --> 00:29:57.300
you, when things like Ping and
IP config, trace route,

587
00:29:57.300 --> 00:30:01.200
things like that, they are what the big
dogs use to figure out problems.

588
00:30:01.200 --> 00:30:04.400
They do have more sophisticated tools but
I guarantee,

589
00:30:04.400 --> 00:30:06.710
they're still running these tools as well.

590
00:30:06.710 --> 00:30:09.230
So, you learn how to
use them very well and

591
00:30:09.230 --> 00:30:13.150
you will be a networking admin before
long in some way, shape or form.

592
00:30:13.150 --> 00:30:16.030
All right, Ronnie, is there anything
else we need these good people to know?

593
00:30:16.030 --> 00:30:18.130
>> Well,
what we want to know of course is that.

594
00:30:18.130 --> 00:30:19.270
Don't be afraid of it, right?

595
00:30:19.270 --> 00:30:22.850
Even though it requires a little bit of
learning, it requires you to do a little

596
00:30:22.850 --> 00:30:26.360
bit of typing, examining the information
and becoming better at it

597
00:30:26.360 --> 00:30:30.340
is only going to make you a more skillful
technician in your networking career.

598
00:30:30.340 --> 00:30:32.370
And it's something that we all need to do.

599
00:30:32.370 --> 00:30:34.690
Getting back to the basics
is not very difficult.

600
00:30:34.690 --> 00:30:37.280
You saw where we're able to
run these easy commands but

601
00:30:37.280 --> 00:30:40.920
they are very powerful commands because
of how much information they reveal.

602
00:30:40.920 --> 00:30:44.510
So, take the time, take a look at
the results cause that's what's also

603
00:30:44.510 --> 00:30:46.900
gonna help you out is that way you'll
actually be able to go oh yeah.

604
00:30:46.900 --> 00:30:48.610
I think I know what's happening here.

605
00:30:48.610 --> 00:30:50.160
And then move on to that next step.

606
00:30:50.160 --> 00:30:53.800
It really is good because a lot times
in networking it's really about

607
00:30:53.800 --> 00:30:55.420
the troubleshooting that we have to do.

608
00:30:55.420 --> 00:30:58.090
then get things back online,
and these tools will help you.

609
00:30:58.090 --> 00:30:59.130
>> That's right.
Well said.

610
00:30:59.130 --> 00:31:01.770
Well good way to wrap up
a great show we just had.

611
00:31:01.770 --> 00:31:03.420
Thanks, Ronnie for joining us today.

612
00:31:03.420 --> 00:31:04.330
Thank you for watching.

613
00:31:04.330 --> 00:31:06.589
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

614
00:31:06.589 --> 00:31:08.134
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

615
00:31:08.134 --> 00:31:08.926
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

616
00:31:08.926 --> 00:31:10.451
>> And we'll see you next time.

617
00:31:10.451 --> 00:31:16.680
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into the wonderful world of network switches and how they are used to connect attached devices. They talk about all the fundamental basics like transmission speeds, ports, and Virtual Local Area Networks.
episodes.title: Understanding Switches
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.545
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.545 --> 00:00:11.045
All right.

3
00:00:11.045 --> 00:00:14.940
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.940 --> 00:00:16.180
I'm your host Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:19.870
Joining me in the studio today is none
other than my good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.870 --> 00:00:20.700
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:21.960
>> It is going great today.

8
00:00:21.960 --> 00:00:26.020
We are taking a look at the MTA,
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

9
00:00:26.020 --> 00:00:30.590
Getting ready for Exam 98366,
Networking Fundamentals.

10
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:35.160
Daniel and I are here to actually put
the fun back into networking fundamentals.

11
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:39.670
So, what we're starting with today is
taking a look at some networking hardware.

12
00:00:39.670 --> 00:00:44.440
Now in previous episodes, we talked
about really kind of the basic concepts.

13
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:48.390
We understand that what we need of
course are our network addresses

14
00:00:48.390 --> 00:00:50.150
on every device that
we need to connect to.

15
00:00:50.150 --> 00:00:53.390
So we spend a bit of time in taking
a look at network addressing.

16
00:00:53.390 --> 00:00:56.440
We've also taken a look at different
networking services that are out

17
00:00:56.440 --> 00:00:57.490
there as well.

18
00:00:57.490 --> 00:01:00.120
Now what we're talking about of
course is the infrastructure,

19
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:03.300
the hardware that makes
the network really work.

20
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:04.980
And today we are focusing in on,

21
00:01:04.980 --> 00:01:07.630
well switches is what we're
taking a look at, Daniel.

22
00:01:07.630 --> 00:01:10.420
So there's a lot of technology for
us to actually take a look at, but

23
00:01:10.420 --> 00:01:12.820
switches is one of those
foundational concepts for us, right?

24
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:13.890
>> Yeah, switches are great.

25
00:01:13.890 --> 00:01:14.800
We love switches.

26
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:18.260
They basically build our networks for us.

27
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:21.070
We attach all our end devices to them,
and they say, hey you know what?

28
00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:24.330
If this computer needs to communicate
with that computer, I got you covered.

29
00:01:24.330 --> 00:01:27.960
I'm gonna figure out where that
information's supposed to go, and

30
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:28.960
send it to that device.

31
00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:30.940
Oh, I've got another one over here,
not a problem.

32
00:01:30.940 --> 00:01:31.850
Usually there is many,

33
00:01:31.850 --> 00:01:35.660
many ports in a switch so
you can attach a bunch of devices to them.

34
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:37.340
And get them communicating as you need to.

35
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:38.830
But that's not the only
thing that they do.

36
00:01:38.830 --> 00:01:42.390
They do actually a lot of
networking function for

37
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:46.020
us in our environments, so
that's why we need to understand them.

38
00:01:46.020 --> 00:01:48.960
We gotta take a look under the hood,
as it were.

39
00:01:48.960 --> 00:01:51.320
See how they work,
understand some of the terms and

40
00:01:51.320 --> 00:01:54.820
definitions as we talk
about switches as well.

41
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:58.810
So that you, who is maybe a little
bit more green than Ronnie and

42
00:01:58.810 --> 00:02:02.900
I, probably not much though [LAUGH],
are able to understand what's going on

43
00:02:02.900 --> 00:02:04.940
what's being talked about, and
you're not left out of the loop.

44
00:02:04.940 --> 00:02:06.830
So that's what we're
hoping to get you today.

45
00:02:06.830 --> 00:02:09.860
Switches, so Ronnie, you've dealt
with a switch or two, haven't you?

46
00:02:09.860 --> 00:02:12.940
>> I have played around with just a couple
in my lifetime when we start talking about

47
00:02:12.940 --> 00:02:16.560
switches, but the easiest thing to
think about if you haven't dealt with

48
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:19.490
switches at al,l and trying to
figure out what the concept is...

49
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:22.190
Well, the very beginning models
of networking when they started

50
00:02:22.190 --> 00:02:23.620
cabling them together...

51
00:02:23.620 --> 00:02:25.100
You know it used to be just simple cables.

52
00:02:25.100 --> 00:02:26.970
They would run from one
machine to another one.

53
00:02:26.970 --> 00:02:30.170
But then after a while they said,
look why don't we run a central cable and

54
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:34.080
then everybody will tap into that
cable and end up being able to work.

55
00:02:34.080 --> 00:02:36.430
Well that became super inefficient.

56
00:02:36.430 --> 00:02:40.490
So then they came up with little hardware
devices then,say look let's just run well

57
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:45.570
regular connections from each device into
a centralized connectivity device, and

58
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:48.680
that little device will
act as a cable itself.

59
00:02:48.680 --> 00:02:50.860
So we don't have to run
this one long cable.

60
00:02:50.860 --> 00:02:55.200
We can just run this device we call a hub,
and that will get us connected.

61
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:58.510
Now when we actually had something
like that that worked perfectly fine,

62
00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:00.760
until you had a lot of devices.

63
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:02.980
And when you have a lot of devices,
the problem that we had is that,

64
00:03:02.980 --> 00:03:04.840
we had what were called
network congestion.

65
00:03:04.840 --> 00:03:05.510
In other words,

66
00:03:05.510 --> 00:03:09.710
only one device can actually use
that one device at any one time.

67
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:13.540
So even though you might have ten or
15 devices plugged into that hub,

68
00:03:13.540 --> 00:03:16.670
the problem is it actually is
a one at a time type of usage.

69
00:03:16.670 --> 00:03:21.240
So one guy's sending, another guy can't
actually be talking at the same time.

70
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:23.180
And even though it
manages it very quickly,

71
00:03:23.180 --> 00:03:28.360
because it does it in electrical signals,
very quickly within milliseconds.

72
00:03:28.360 --> 00:03:32.000
Well the problems still happen to be that
as more and more devices got connected,

73
00:03:32.000 --> 00:03:35.550
the more it really didn't work
as well as they wanted it to.

74
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:37.560
So then newer devices came along, and

75
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:42.500
the next device that came along is
really what we call the switch itself.

76
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:44.830
And the switch does something different.

77
00:03:44.830 --> 00:03:47.780
Unlike what the hub does which
is just give us connectivity.

78
00:03:47.780 --> 00:03:51.050
And then we have to kind of just let
the devices work themselves out.

79
00:03:51.050 --> 00:03:55.270
A switch is a little bit more proactive
and what a switch says is this.

80
00:03:55.270 --> 00:03:59.110
What we're gonna do is I'm gonna actually
say as data comes into this port,

81
00:03:59.110 --> 00:04:01.930
I'm gonna forward it out the port
that it's supposed to go out, and

82
00:04:01.930 --> 00:04:04.890
not really mess around with
the other ports as well.

83
00:04:04.890 --> 00:04:08.950
So, that is really what the main
functionality of this switch does for

84
00:04:08.950 --> 00:04:11.930
us, is it really makes decisions.

85
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:15.820
And so if we tie everything
back to that unusual OSI.

86
00:04:15.820 --> 00:04:17.800
I said unusual,
it's actually in everything that we have.

87
00:04:17.800 --> 00:04:22.760
We tie everything back to the foundation
of networking communications and patterns,

88
00:04:22.760 --> 00:04:25.920
right, and we go back to the OSI model.

89
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:29.170
A switch is one of the devices
that really does operate on

90
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:30.730
one of those different layers.

91
00:04:30.730 --> 00:04:35.240
A switch operates on layer
two of the OSI model.

92
00:04:35.240 --> 00:04:37.650
The data link layer of that model.

93
00:04:37.650 --> 00:04:40.530
And that is actually a key concept for us.

94
00:04:40.530 --> 00:04:43.610
And when we talk about that,
that actually gives us that idea,

95
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:46.210
like why does it have to
operate on layer two?

96
00:04:46.210 --> 00:04:50.930
It's because the switch makes its
forwarding decisions as data's coming in.

97
00:04:50.930 --> 00:04:53.460
How does it actually choose
what port to go out of?

98
00:04:53.460 --> 00:04:58.540
It makes its decision of the MAC address
of what that frame actually says

99
00:04:58.540 --> 00:05:00.030
where it's supposed to go.

100
00:05:00.030 --> 00:05:03.260
So that's why we actually have to
understand that a little bit more.

101
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:07.120
Let me show you a picture of the switch
that I'll be using here today to try and

102
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:08.580
make sure that we understand.

103
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:10.500
This is actually Don's switch.

104
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:11.580
>> This one's Don's.

105
00:05:11.580 --> 00:05:15.670
>> So this is a very nice switch here,
and you have the model number here,

106
00:05:15.670 --> 00:05:17.830
which is not super important, but

107
00:05:17.830 --> 00:05:21.780
notice that switches can come
in all many varieties and sizes.

108
00:05:21.780 --> 00:05:25.440
This one's a very nice one
that actually has 48 ports.

109
00:05:25.440 --> 00:05:29.660
Yeah, so this is a very nice switch
that has 48 different ports on them, and

110
00:05:29.660 --> 00:05:33.710
if you actually add them up, there's
16 over here, 16 here, 16 here, and

111
00:05:33.710 --> 00:05:36.560
then you also have these
four other ports here.

112
00:05:36.560 --> 00:05:39.670
So if you add them all up,
there's actually 52 different ports.

113
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:42.610
On this particular switch if you
combine everything together.

114
00:05:42.610 --> 00:05:44.580
So, that's a pretty massive switch,

115
00:05:44.580 --> 00:05:47.830
because that means you can actually
take each one of those ports and

116
00:05:47.830 --> 00:05:53.155
we can plug some devices that's gonna be
a sending device, or a receiving device,

117
00:05:53.155 --> 00:05:57.115
in other words a destination device
into it, and this device can manage it.

118
00:05:57.115 --> 00:06:00.195
Remember that what a hub does it allows
you to plug all of those in, but

119
00:06:00.195 --> 00:06:05.225
when something sends in there,
the other devices hear all that data and

120
00:06:05.225 --> 00:06:07.565
they just decide whether or
not it's actually for them or not.

121
00:06:07.565 --> 00:06:10.015
And if it's not for them,
they simply ignore it.

122
00:06:10.015 --> 00:06:11.960
But it goes out all the other ports.

123
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:15.980
The switch itself though,
here, decides differently.

124
00:06:15.980 --> 00:06:19.760
It says, look, I know what the destination
of that frame's supposed to be,

125
00:06:19.760 --> 00:06:22.170
cuz I look at the destination Mac address.

126
00:06:22.170 --> 00:06:24.900
And when it does that,
it doesn't disturb anybody else.

127
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:28.870
It looks in a table inside it,
so there's again,

128
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:33.850
memory inside of that device that will
allow it to make those types of decisions.

129
00:06:33.850 --> 00:06:36.640
Now the way it makes those decisions,
let me see if I can bring up my

130
00:06:36.640 --> 00:06:41.980
simple diagram instead, that will
kind of help us out, is right here.

131
00:06:41.980 --> 00:06:44.400
So this is just a more simplified diagram,

132
00:06:44.400 --> 00:06:46.960
it's something that we can
actually use to help us out.

133
00:06:46.960 --> 00:06:52.360
So the key concept in the function
of how a switch does what it does,

134
00:06:52.360 --> 00:06:53.880
Is you have to remember
a couple of things.

135
00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:57.100
One, it really does,
it wants to connect two ports together.

136
00:06:57.100 --> 00:06:58.680
That's really what it's hoping to do.

137
00:07:00.200 --> 00:07:02.480
Two, the thing that it does that off of,

138
00:07:02.480 --> 00:07:04.720
is based on what we'll
call the MAC address.

139
00:07:04.720 --> 00:07:06.380
Now this actually leads
us to a good point.

140
00:07:06.380 --> 00:07:08.610
A little bit backward,
but a good point here.

141
00:07:08.610 --> 00:07:11.310
Where in the world does
it get the MAC address

142
00:07:11.310 --> 00:07:14.740
of any machine that's sending
data into that device?

143
00:07:14.740 --> 00:07:16.770
Well, the Mac address on my PC,

144
00:07:16.770 --> 00:07:22.160
on anybody's computer, is normally
attached to the network adapter.

145
00:07:22.160 --> 00:07:25.960
So the cable that you normally
plug your computer into,

146
00:07:25.960 --> 00:07:29.300
usually on that device is what
we call that hardware address.

147
00:07:29.300 --> 00:07:31.280
Sometimes you hear the term
physical address, and

148
00:07:31.280 --> 00:07:33.280
that's what they normally
say in Microsoft.

149
00:07:33.280 --> 00:07:35.940
Everywhere else around the world,
we call it MAC address,

150
00:07:35.940 --> 00:07:38.200
a media access control address as well.

151
00:07:38.200 --> 00:07:40.960
So you will hear different terminology for
this stuff, but

152
00:07:40.960 --> 00:07:44.240
just kinda realize that that's
the address that he's taking a look at.

153
00:07:44.240 --> 00:07:48.499
When data sent from a device then,
it's gonna have a source MAC address,

154
00:07:48.499 --> 00:07:51.397
it's gonna have a destination
MAC address on it.

155
00:07:51.397 --> 00:07:54.685
So it actually knows that it's
supposed to come from this machine and

156
00:07:54.685 --> 00:07:56.448
it's destined for somewhere else.

157
00:07:56.448 --> 00:07:57.873
Well, when we send data, and

158
00:07:57.873 --> 00:08:00.908
let's say that my device is plugged
in here on port number one.

159
00:08:00.908 --> 00:08:04.106
When I send data internally
into that switch,

160
00:08:04.106 --> 00:08:09.170
this is where the switch makes
a decision based on the MAC address.

161
00:08:09.170 --> 00:08:12.900
And that's why it's no longer a layer
1 device, which a hub would be.

162
00:08:12.900 --> 00:08:16.100
A hub just says, look, when you send
data in, I'm gonna forward it out.

163
00:08:16.100 --> 00:08:19.070
But a switch says, hey,
when you send data in,

164
00:08:19.070 --> 00:08:22.710
I'm gonna take a look at
the destination MAC address as well.

165
00:08:22.710 --> 00:08:25.510
And then I'm going to look it
up in the table that I have, and

166
00:08:25.510 --> 00:08:26.840
if it's listed in there,

167
00:08:26.840 --> 00:08:31.760
I will forward it out to the port that
matches what that MAC address says it is.

168
00:08:31.760 --> 00:08:33.440
So over here on the left hand side,

169
00:08:33.440 --> 00:08:36.660
the basic functionality
that a switch does for us.

170
00:08:36.660 --> 00:08:40.580
It actually makes three decisions,
okay, of what to do.

171
00:08:40.580 --> 00:08:43.060
And that is pretty much the key.

172
00:08:43.060 --> 00:08:46.690
When a switch gets data that
comes into that device, it says,

173
00:08:46.690 --> 00:08:48.240
look, I can forward it out.

174
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:49.810
If I can find the MAC address and

175
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:52.920
what port it's actually on,
let me forward it out on port number 3.

176
00:08:52.920 --> 00:08:54.830
Makes very good sense.

177
00:08:54.830 --> 00:08:58.170
Notice that it can also do it
what we call flooding data.

178
00:08:58.170 --> 00:08:59.560
And what is that about?

179
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:04.580
If data comes in to port number 1 and
it's actually saying, look,

180
00:09:04.580 --> 00:09:08.440
I don't know where that MAC address is,
in other words, the switch says, I look at
