00:32:50.300 --> 00:32:52.070
But I only have one physical switch?

620
00:32:52.070 --> 00:32:53.510
Well I don't just sit there and go, sorry,

621
00:32:53.510 --> 00:32:55.610
well you're gonna have to deal
with the excess of traffic.

622
00:32:55.610 --> 00:32:58.250
Instead we can go in there,
we can configure different VLANs for

623
00:32:58.250 --> 00:33:01.240
them, and that way their traffic
is not seen by anybody else,

624
00:33:01.240 --> 00:33:03.420
even though they're on
the same physical switch.

625
00:33:03.420 --> 00:33:07.820
Or, if we are adding in new departments
and they already are preconfigured on

626
00:33:07.820 --> 00:33:11.600
their switch to do whatever they want to,
well we simply link them up.

627
00:33:11.600 --> 00:33:12.850
And then we can actually go ahead and
say, hey,

628
00:33:12.850 --> 00:33:16.670
look, your VLAN's now gonna be
recognized across my switch as well.

629
00:33:16.670 --> 00:33:19.250
And that's fine, cuz then we can
add in whatever we want to, so

630
00:33:19.250 --> 00:33:21.070
it makes management much easier.

631
00:33:21.070 --> 00:33:24.770
The key here though is remember,
this can only be done on managed switches.

632
00:33:24.770 --> 00:33:26.740
You're not gonna be able to take
a little eight port switch that

633
00:33:26.740 --> 00:33:29.840
you can't get access to and
try and do VLANs on them.

634
00:33:29.840 --> 00:33:30.930
They're not gonna let you do it.

635
00:33:30.930 --> 00:33:33.500
>> Yep, all right, Ronnie,
I'm taking a look at our clock here.

636
00:33:33.500 --> 00:33:36.690
Even though we have a whole lot more to
talk about when it comes to switches,

637
00:33:36.690 --> 00:33:39.010
we have no more time left on this episode.

638
00:33:39.010 --> 00:33:41.170
Looks like we're gonna have to
do a part two but [CROSSTALK]

639
00:33:41.170 --> 00:33:41.810
>> Who would have guessed?

640
00:33:41.810 --> 00:33:43.910
Yeah, I mean, who would have guessed
that we would do a part two?

641
00:33:43.910 --> 00:33:44.860
[LAUGH]
>> It's our favorite thing.

642
00:33:44.860 --> 00:33:46.950
So hopefully we'll see you guys there.

643
00:33:46.950 --> 00:33:50.220
Ronnie, thank you for these demonstrations
and we will see you in part two as well.

644
00:33:50.220 --> 00:33:51.570
>> We will.
>> Hopefully we'll see you there.

645
00:33:51.570 --> 00:33:52.349
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

646
00:33:52.349 --> 00:33:54.940
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

647
00:33:54.940 --> 00:33:55.600
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

648
00:33:55.600 --> 00:33:56.806
>> And we'll see you next time.

649
00:33:56.806 --> 00:34:03.100
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue detailing the workings of network switches. Here they move into more complex topics like Layer2 and Layer3 switching, security options, switching types or methods, and MAC Table propagation.
episodes.title: Understanding Switches Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.930
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.930 --> 00:00:11.321
All right.

3
00:00:11.321 --> 00:00:11.881
Greetings everyone.

4
00:00:11.881 --> 00:00:14.960
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.960 --> 00:00:19.090
I'm your host Daniel Lowery,
joining me yet again is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.090 --> 00:00:19.620
How's it going today Ronnie?

7
00:00:19.620 --> 00:00:23.156
>> It is going great today we
are continuing to take a look at MTA,

8
00:00:23.156 --> 00:00:27.790
the Microsoft Technology Associate,
getting ready for that exam 98366.

9
00:00:27.790 --> 00:00:31.150
The Networking Fundamentals exam.

10
00:00:31.150 --> 00:00:34.880
So if you are preparing for
that exam you are in the right place.

11
00:00:34.880 --> 00:00:38.410
We are taking a look more
at the switches again.

12
00:00:38.410 --> 00:00:41.788
We already had a part one to this
little mini series that we've had.

13
00:00:41.788 --> 00:00:45.020
Where we talked about the basic
functionality of what switches are, and

14
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:47.600
of course how they work, just briefly.

15
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:51.130
But we also need to take a look at some of
these other things that we have to know

16
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:53.670
about switches,
if we're going to be working with them.

17
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:57.740
And there is no doubt that as you
enter into the world of IT and

18
00:00:57.740 --> 00:01:00.000
as you become a network technician.

19
00:01:00.000 --> 00:01:02.960
Switches are going to be that, the heart
of a lot of the things that you see.

20
00:01:02.960 --> 00:01:06.460
The nice thing about it though
is that the majority of it.

21
00:01:06.460 --> 00:01:09.400
If somebody else is handling it,
you really don't have to worry about it.

22
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:13.490
It's usually one of those devices
that you just have to set and forget.

23
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:14.980
And then it works perfectly.

24
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:18.220
But as a technician, though,
it shouldn't scare you.

25
00:01:18.220 --> 00:01:19.410
It should be something that you go, okay,

26
00:01:19.410 --> 00:01:21.640
I understand at least
the basic functionalities.

27
00:01:21.640 --> 00:01:24.970
And that's what we really want to get
into when we start taking a look at

28
00:01:24.970 --> 00:01:26.180
understanding switches today.

29
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:26.780
>> Yeah, that's right.

30
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:27.680
Switches are not scary.

31
00:01:27.680 --> 00:01:29.550
Actually, I find them quite fun and
soothing.

32
00:01:29.550 --> 00:01:30.878
Because you get to hammer away at them,

33
00:01:30.878 --> 00:01:33.533
make them do stuff that you want them to
do and it's really cool cuz it looks like

34
00:01:33.533 --> 00:01:35.157
you know a whole lot of
stuff about networking.

35
00:01:35.157 --> 00:01:38.068
Because, well if you're messing
with a switch you probably

36
00:01:38.068 --> 00:01:40.930
at least know a little bit, and
it makes our networks work.

37
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:44.310
So it's something that,
it's kind of a necessary evil and

38
00:01:44.310 --> 00:01:47.162
a necessary fun evil,
at least in my estimation.

39
00:01:47.162 --> 00:01:49.866
I really enjoy switching, so
Ronnie let's just cut to the chase,

40
00:01:49.866 --> 00:01:51.034
and move right back into it.

41
00:01:51.034 --> 00:01:53.781
We talked about a lot of different
type of switching technologies.

42
00:01:53.781 --> 00:01:56.330
Where we went over speeds,
and things like that.

43
00:01:56.330 --> 00:01:59.630
And, then we got to VLANs,
which is all so very, very awesome.

44
00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:00.870
But, where else can we go with switching?

45
00:02:00.870 --> 00:02:01.670
What else can we do?

46
00:02:01.670 --> 00:02:04.714
>> Well, there's actually a couple of
different types of switches you're more

47
00:02:04.714 --> 00:02:06.340
than likely to see in today's networks.

48
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:10.690
The earliest switches only really
operated and functioned at layer two.

49
00:02:10.690 --> 00:02:14.107
Remember, that's actually being able to
forward data based on the MAC address

50
00:02:14.107 --> 00:02:15.800
itself, which is a layer two address.

51
00:02:15.800 --> 00:02:17.035
So that when data comes in,

52
00:02:17.035 --> 00:02:20.870
it forwards it out the port that the MAC
address is actually associated with.

53
00:02:20.870 --> 00:02:23.300
That's perfectly fine, and it works well.

54
00:02:23.300 --> 00:02:26.950
But, what if you actually do
have a couple of different IP

55
00:02:26.950 --> 00:02:32.160
networks inside of your own local area
network as well so, I shouldn't say that.

56
00:02:32.160 --> 00:02:36.150
You have multiple local area networks
that you're actually responsible for.

57
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:39.260
Well to be able to communicate
between those local area networks

58
00:02:39.260 --> 00:02:43.100
we also need to be able to route
data in between them, and so

59
00:02:43.100 --> 00:02:46.100
we also need what we
call a router to do that.

60
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:49.660
And that was normally a separate device
that then you wend send from your

61
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:50.710
switch, right?

62
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:52.280
So your PC connected to that switch,

63
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:55.222
the switch would then be connected
to the router some place.

64
00:02:55.222 --> 00:02:58.420
And then that router would be connect
to another switch on the other side for

65
00:02:58.420 --> 00:03:00.760
you to send data back and forth on.

66
00:03:00.760 --> 00:03:02.080
Well, when you have something like that,

67
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.500
that works perfectly fine, but
it did require an extra device.

68
00:03:06.500 --> 00:03:10.800
Some smaller networks, actually,
that were out there said look,

69
00:03:10.800 --> 00:03:12.190
that's a lot of money to spend.

70
00:03:12.190 --> 00:03:16.960
We spend two different devices
on a fairly small network,

71
00:03:16.960 --> 00:03:18.890
is there something else that we can do?

72
00:03:18.890 --> 00:03:21.650
Well of course vendors started
coming up with what they called

73
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:23.990
layer three switches.

74
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:26.010
Now if you do remember
that in the OSI model,

75
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:30.700
we have talked about the idea
of layer two and layer three.

76
00:03:30.700 --> 00:03:35.300
Layer three is where we can have IP
addressing and also routers too.

77
00:03:35.300 --> 00:03:38.062
What they did is they
took a single device,

78
00:03:38.062 --> 00:03:41.070
and they integrated it
in to switches as well.

79
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.170
So sometimes what you'll hear as
the term is a layer three switch, or

80
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:47.000
you'll also hear the term
multi-layer switch.

81
00:03:47.000 --> 00:03:51.789
So let me show you an example of a layer
two switch right here on my screen, okay.

82
00:03:51.789 --> 00:03:54.167
So, if you were to look at
a layer two switch, and

83
00:03:54.167 --> 00:03:56.434
you have to ignore the label over here,
okay.

84
00:03:56.434 --> 00:04:01.080
If you were to look at a layer two switch,
this is what it would look like, okay?

85
00:04:01.080 --> 00:04:04.070
Now Daniel, let me show you
a picture of a layer three switch.

86
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:06.730
If you were to ignore the label
right here and you were to look for

87
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:10.480
a layer three switch, this is what a layer
three switch would look like as well.

88
00:04:10.480 --> 00:04:13.590
So yeah, I know you're probably like,
oh that wasn't funny, Ronnie!

89
00:04:13.590 --> 00:04:15.480
It really was.

90
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:16.540
What?
is it the same?

91
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:17.840
It can be, right?

92
00:04:17.840 --> 00:04:20.810
So you can't judge it on its appearance.

93
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:23.840
So what you have to do if you're really
interested in trying to distinguish

94
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:26.090
whether it's a layer two or
layer three switch.

95
00:04:26.090 --> 00:04:28.630
Is you have to take a look
at the model number itself.

96
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:30.910
And then go and
find documentation on that.

97
00:04:30.910 --> 00:04:33.610
You can't just look at a single switch and
go, oh yeah, no,

98
00:04:33.610 --> 00:04:37.020
if I take a look at that port,
that proves it's a layer three switch.

99
00:04:37.020 --> 00:04:38.125
Maybe Don could but.

100
00:04:38.125 --> 00:04:39.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> But no, I'm joking.

101
00:04:39.670 --> 00:04:44.520
But overall though,
they look in appearance identical.

102
00:04:44.520 --> 00:04:49.530
The big difference is what's internal,
inside, of that switch itself.

103
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:52.520
So when we have a layer of switch,
three switch.

104
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:55.800
It can not only do
the layer two switching but

105
00:04:55.800 --> 00:04:59.700
it can also handle the layer
three routing as well.

106
00:04:59.700 --> 00:05:03.300
So that means that we can actually
run the configuration for routers and

107
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:07.480
switches on that same device and
it can handle it too.

108
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:12.440
So you're actually starting to see,
we've seen a movement of,

109
00:05:12.440 --> 00:05:15.050
it says 2,003, I would say.

110
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:16.720
So maybe I'm a little bit behind.

111
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:18.495
Maybe I'm not a really good doctor.

112
00:05:18.495 --> 00:05:20.150
[LAUGH]
>> Now here's a good question, Ronnie.

113
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:20.710
>> Yeah.

114
00:05:20.710 --> 00:05:23.450
>> Is it a router with a built in switch?

115
00:05:23.450 --> 00:05:25.090
Sort of a switch with a built in router.

116
00:05:25.090 --> 00:05:28.530
>> You know,
that's actually a good question, Daniel.

117
00:05:28.530 --> 00:05:29.577
I don't know.
Is it the chicken or

118
00:05:29.577 --> 00:05:31.357
the egg that really came in here?

119
00:05:31.357 --> 00:05:33.651
>> Exactly.
>> But more than likely, it was for

120
00:05:33.651 --> 00:05:37.360
smaller or
small to medium businesses, right?

121
00:05:37.360 --> 00:05:38.334
So don't get me wrong.

122
00:05:38.334 --> 00:05:42.030
You can run these on large businesses,
but usually that's the market this was

123
00:05:42.030 --> 00:05:44.280
designed for,
was that market that said look.

124
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:47.051
And I've already spent a couple of
thousand dollars on this switch,

125
00:05:47.051 --> 00:05:51.190
and now you're telling me I need a router
for another couple of thousand dollars?

126
00:05:51.190 --> 00:05:52.690
I really don't want to do that.

127
00:05:52.690 --> 00:05:54.742
So what did they do?
They made a cheaper combined device

128
00:05:54.742 --> 00:05:59.360
together, which might have been right
there in the middle right, $3,000 or so.

129
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:00.672
Somewhere around there,

130
00:06:00.672 --> 00:06:03.960
that really did kind of combine
both of those elements together.

131
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:06.430
So that we can actually do
that all on one machine.

132
00:06:06.430 --> 00:06:09.910
And you think about that,
saves on electricity.

133
00:06:09.910 --> 00:06:12.860
And also with the configuration here,
it really actually saves on

134
00:06:12.860 --> 00:06:17.000
the cost of developing the device when
they can cram all of that into one device.

135
00:06:17.000 --> 00:06:18.250
And now you keep your customer so

136
00:06:18.250 --> 00:06:23.140
somebody else saying you mean that company
was able to do it but yours wasn't?

137
00:06:23.140 --> 00:06:26.060
So you do have a lot of
market forces driving this.

138
00:06:26.060 --> 00:06:29.680
But this is more often is what you'll
see is layer three switches inside of

139
00:06:29.680 --> 00:06:30.280
networks today.

140
00:06:30.280 --> 00:06:32.760
And that's because it can do both and

141
00:06:32.760 --> 00:06:35.700
you don't have to worry about
actually adding in a separate device.

142
00:06:35.700 --> 00:06:38.310
Now, is a separate device
still necessary sometimes?

143
00:06:38.310 --> 00:06:39.790
Yeah, you better believe it.

144
00:06:39.790 --> 00:06:44.610
If you need dedicated routers because you
have a lot of routing network that goes on

145
00:06:44.610 --> 00:06:46.610
well then yes, go ahead and do that.

146
00:06:46.610 --> 00:06:49.140
Will a layer three switch also
work with a router in place?

147
00:06:49.140 --> 00:06:50.046
It definitely will.

148
00:06:50.046 --> 00:06:52.229
So it really depends on
the capabilities and

149
00:06:52.229 --> 00:06:56.130
what you need that router to do if you
actually choose to buy a separate router.

150
00:06:56.130 --> 00:07:00.554
But most small businesses to medium
businesses size a layer three switch will

151
00:07:00.554 --> 00:07:05.480
do both functions and will work perfectly
fine, and it really is kind of a dream.

152
00:07:05.480 --> 00:07:09.210
Because on one device you really
have two devices kind of crammed in.

153
00:07:09.210 --> 00:07:12.260
So that's why you hear that either
the term layer three switch, or

154
00:07:12.260 --> 00:07:14.700
the term multi-layer switch
is what you also hear.

155
00:07:14.700 --> 00:07:15.480
>> That's right.

156
00:07:15.480 --> 00:07:19.150
Now with a managed switch as well,
it also gives us some

157
00:07:19.150 --> 00:07:22.410
other great functionality when it
comes down to security, right?

158
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:23.640
Security is the big topic of the day.

159
00:07:23.640 --> 00:07:25.760
You gotta make sure that
your network is secure.

160
00:07:25.760 --> 00:07:27.220
You can't just leave
it out in the wind for

161
00:07:27.220 --> 00:07:31.380
any hacker or malfeasance that's out
there trying to gain access to your data.

162
00:07:31.380 --> 00:07:33.110
We have to stop those jokers.

163
00:07:33.110 --> 00:07:36.620
Well, switch was actually for
a while one of the ways in which they

164
00:07:36.620 --> 00:07:41.860
could gain access to our network and
even our data if we allowed them to.

165
00:07:41.860 --> 00:07:45.160
But mana switches today, they have
a lot of security features built in and

166
00:07:45.160 --> 00:07:48.190
we could use them to stop many
of those attacks right Ronnie.

167
00:07:48.190 --> 00:07:50.509
>> There's no doubt about
that from the outside.

168
00:07:50.509 --> 00:07:52.936
There's a couple of things that
we had to worry about, right.

169
00:07:52.936 --> 00:07:57.633
If somebody was able to physically gain
access to that console port, okay.

170
00:07:57.633 --> 00:08:01.236
They could bring a cable in and they
could gain access to it, a lot of times,

171
00:08:01.236 --> 00:08:05.100
right away, that meant that they
could actually control the switch.

172
00:08:05.100 --> 00:08:08.770
So one of the neat features inside
of the way that the switch operates

173
00:08:08.770 --> 00:08:13.040
on it's operating system is that they
give you the ability to control access

174
00:08:13.040 --> 00:08:16.510
to the switch itself even
from the console port.

175
00:08:16.510 --> 00:08:22.060
And that means you can lock down that port
to make you ask, or to make it ask you for

176
00:08:22.060 --> 00:08:27.880
a password if you want to actually gain
access to it from that, using that cable.

177
00:08:27.880 --> 00:08:31.130
So, this is some of those prevention
methods that you have to have in

178
00:08:31.130 --> 00:08:32.220
place, right.

179
00:08:32.220 --> 00:08:34.810
So even though the console port,
by default everything is set up and

180
00:08:34.810 --> 00:08:35.800
ready to go.

181
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:39.490
You know, you just plug it in and you're
ready to configure it and you're fine.

182
00:08:39.490 --> 00:08:43.040
Well it's never a recommendation that
you take a switch right out of the box,

183
00:08:43.040 --> 00:08:44.840
plug it in and make it work.

184
00:08:44.840 --> 00:08:45.580
Now will it?

185
00:08:45.580 --> 00:08:46.310
Yes.

186
00:08:46.310 --> 00:08:49.820
Switches are one of those
unusually amazing devices.

187
00:08:49.820 --> 00:08:53.410
As much as they can do, and
as much security as we can add into it.

188
00:08:54.470 --> 00:08:57.100
When you buy one, let's say for
example from Cisco,

189
00:08:57.100 --> 00:09:01.240
all you need to do is take it out of
its crate, plug power into it and

190
00:09:01.240 --> 00:09:05.190
then once the light settled down,
you start plugging computer ports into it.

191
00:09:05.190 --> 00:09:06.410
It'll start doing the switching.

192
00:09:06.410 --> 00:09:08.260
No questions asked, nothing.

193
00:09:08.260 --> 00:09:11.640
They work exactly like a regular
old unmanaged switch will work.

194
00:09:11.640 --> 00:09:13.090
And you don't have to worry about it.

195
00:09:13.090 --> 00:09:14.990
It will function perfectly fine.

196
00:09:14.990 --> 00:09:16.940
The problem is if I have
that 48-port switch and

197
00:09:16.940 --> 00:09:20.330

00:20:57.830 --> 00:20:58.810
Well, there has to be

422
00:21:00.080 --> 00:21:05.460
enough bandwidth inside on the motherboard
to handle those connections.

423
00:21:05.460 --> 00:21:08.610
Well, there's not a single motherboard,
I don't care what device that you get,

424
00:21:08.610 --> 00:21:13.920
there's not a motherboard that says,
yes I will support 4,800 megabits

425
00:21:13.920 --> 00:21:16.490
back playing speed,
especially on something like this.

426
00:21:16.490 --> 00:21:20.320
What they do is I say, look,
here's how much I can support at one time

427
00:21:20.320 --> 00:21:24.220
before we're gonna have to start kind of
saying, look, slow down a little bit and

428
00:21:24.220 --> 00:21:25.320
make it work.

429
00:21:25.320 --> 00:21:27.190
So back plane speed is about that,

430
00:21:27.190 --> 00:21:29.840
it's how much shared bandwidth
is really out there.

431
00:21:29.840 --> 00:21:34.500
So on these devices you might end up
seeing where it's like a 32-gigabit back

432
00:21:34.500 --> 00:21:38.440
plane or a 128-gigabit back plane,
whatever it might be.

433
00:21:38.440 --> 00:21:42.840
And that allows you to know that hey after
a certain amount of ports when you have

434
00:21:42.840 --> 00:21:44.890
all these devices trying
to connect together.

435
00:21:44.890 --> 00:21:46.510
It's gonna slow down just briefly.

436
00:21:46.510 --> 00:21:50.660
Now when I say that it doesn't
really anymore because

437
00:21:50.660 --> 00:21:52.820
of the technology that's
actually involved.

438
00:21:52.820 --> 00:21:55.950
In what we're about to talk about
about the switching types as well.

439
00:21:55.950 --> 00:21:58.910
Switches operate insanely fast.

440
00:21:58.910 --> 00:22:02.290
When I mean that I mean it operates
at the speed of thought, and

441
00:22:02.290 --> 00:22:04.740
I really mean that in the way it does it.

442
00:22:04.740 --> 00:22:07.590
And it's because it's based
on something we calls ASICs.

443
00:22:07.590 --> 00:22:11.790
ASIC stands for
application specific integrated circuitry.

444
00:22:11.790 --> 00:22:16.130
Whereas a lot of things like on a router,
when it has to make a decision

445
00:22:16.130 --> 00:22:19.670
it has to go to the CPU and say,
what's your decision going to be?

446
00:22:19.670 --> 00:22:23.360
The way that every single port
on that 48 port switch works,

447
00:22:23.360 --> 00:22:27.720
is that all of it's decision making is
based on the hardware on that port and

448
00:22:27.720 --> 00:22:31.600
it is an integrated specific
circuit is what it's done.

449
00:22:31.600 --> 00:22:34.200
So it makes that forwarding, flooding and

450
00:22:34.200 --> 00:22:39.010
of course the filtering decision
right there on that port.

451
00:22:39.010 --> 00:22:43.070
So it doesn't have to go to the CPU
to handle a lot of the other things.

452
00:22:43.070 --> 00:22:46.970
The CPU is designed to handle
the control aspect of what happens but

453
00:22:46.970 --> 00:22:50.520
all of the data forwarding
decisions are based on the ASIC,

454
00:22:50.520 --> 00:22:55.210
which means the backplane is not so
essential if it makes a direct connection.

455
00:22:55.210 --> 00:22:59.840
So, backplane speed is all about that,
when you start hearing that terminology.

456
00:22:59.840 --> 00:23:04.950
It's how much the motherboard
handle at one time.

457
00:23:04.950 --> 00:23:07.850
Now, when we start about
switching types though,

458
00:23:07.850 --> 00:23:10.570
this also goes into that backplane speed.

459
00:23:10.570 --> 00:23:13.710
Because it really depends on
the type of switch you get.

460
00:23:13.710 --> 00:23:16.040
The more expensive ones of course,

461
00:23:16.040 --> 00:23:19.320
are actually the ones that you really
do want because of what they do.

462
00:23:19.320 --> 00:23:22.610
The cheaper ones can work faster, but

463
00:23:22.610 --> 00:23:25.910
it might not give you all
the functionality that you're expecting.

464
00:23:25.910 --> 00:23:29.120
So there's really three switching
types that we want to actually be

465
00:23:29.120 --> 00:23:31.240
able to talk about, okay?

466
00:23:31.240 --> 00:23:36.240
So if you buy a switch and it says hey,
this is a fragment free switch, and

467
00:23:36.240 --> 00:23:39.520
you'll hear that term,
what in the world does that mean?

468
00:23:39.520 --> 00:23:43.885
Well, what they found out is that data can
corrupt as you send it and you can imagine

469
00:23:43.885 --> 00:23:47.575
the data can corrupt as you send it
faster across different devices.

470
00:23:47.575 --> 00:23:51.480
So what they found out is after
the scan in millions and millions,

471
00:23:51.480 --> 00:23:56.237
maybe in billions of packets, is that they
found out that the data if it corrupts

472
00:23:56.237 --> 00:24:00.573
going across the switch It corrupts
during the first 64 bytes of data.

473
00:24:00.573 --> 00:24:03.360
So after examining that,
they started realizing something.

474
00:24:03.360 --> 00:24:07.240
If there's corruption,
it doesn't tend to happen after that.

475
00:24:07.240 --> 00:24:12.380
So what they do is that they send data
into a port and fragment free says,

476
00:24:12.380 --> 00:24:17.190
I can examine the first 64 bits of data or
bytes of data, excuse me.

477
00:24:17.190 --> 00:24:20.870
The first 64 bytes of data, and if there's
no corruption, I will go ahead and

478
00:24:20.870 --> 00:24:22.780
begin the forwarding process.

479
00:24:22.780 --> 00:24:25.750
And then that actually
makes it work a lot faster.

480
00:24:25.750 --> 00:24:26.280
Okay?

481
00:24:26.280 --> 00:24:27.940
So that's the way it goes.

482
00:24:27.940 --> 00:24:30.970
But then there's also what we call cut and
through.

483
00:24:30.970 --> 00:24:31.670
Okay?

484
00:24:31.670 --> 00:24:35.460
Cut and through sits there and
says, look, here's what I'll do.

485
00:24:36.720 --> 00:24:40.940
Daniel, if you'll send me this all I need
to do is see the destination MAC address.

486
00:24:40.940 --> 00:24:44.290
If I get the destination MAC address,
I'm sending it through.

487
00:24:44.290 --> 00:24:45.350
That's all it takes.

488
00:24:45.350 --> 00:24:46.980
It doesn't examine any more.

489
00:24:46.980 --> 00:24:49.520
It doesn't sit there and
go there may be fragmentation.

490
00:24:49.520 --> 00:24:51.820
But what it says is if I can
get it over there fast, and

491
00:24:51.820 --> 00:24:53.920
then if that device
needs me to re-send it,

492
00:24:53.920 --> 00:24:58.300
I'll send it faster than having to examine
the first 64 bytes and then send it on.

493
00:24:58.300 --> 00:25:02.230
So, it's actually taking that bet that
more than likely the majority of these

494
00:25:02.230 --> 00:25:05.310
packets are not going to
be fragmented at all.

495
00:25:05.310 --> 00:25:08.730
So if I get 90% of the packets
through without any fragmentation,

496
00:25:08.730 --> 00:25:12.070
the 10% that I have to
resend is no real big deal.

497
00:25:12.070 --> 00:25:12.790
Okay?

498
00:25:12.790 --> 00:25:15.000
So, that one, as good as that is,

499
00:25:15.000 --> 00:25:19.700
the problem that we have there depends on
the sensitivity of our data and how we

500
00:25:19.700 --> 00:25:23.640
treat our data as well, if we're actually
working inside of a center that says,

501
00:25:23.640 --> 00:25:28.180
look we need for the data to remain,
to not be corrupted at all, and

502
00:25:28.180 --> 00:25:30.920
to not worry about that we're not
going to use anything like that.

503
00:25:30.920 --> 00:25:33.780
If we're only looking for high speed,
we don't mind the idea that

504
00:25:33.780 --> 00:25:37.140
data corruption and then having
to resend that, then we're fine.

505
00:25:37.140 --> 00:25:40.620
The more expensive of these is
the final one we're talking about here,

506
00:25:40.620 --> 00:25:42.440
which is the store and forward.

507
00:25:42.440 --> 00:25:45.350
The store and
forward says look send me the frame.

508
00:25:45.350 --> 00:25:48.250
I don't care how big that frame is
the maximum size can be about 15

509
00:25:48.250 --> 00:25:49.150
hundred bites here.

510
00:25:49.150 --> 00:25:50.680
Send me the whole frame.

511
00:25:50.680 --> 00:25:52.620
I will examine that frame and

512
00:25:52.620 --> 00:25:56.290
if everything is good,
then I will forward it on.

513
00:25:56.290 --> 00:26:00.100
So by doing this, every single port
has that ability to do it, and

514
00:26:00.100 --> 00:26:02.000
this does operate a little bit slower.

515
00:26:02.000 --> 00:26:06.390
When I say slower, I mean half a thought
behind what these other two can do.

516
00:26:06.390 --> 00:26:10.090
When it operates that slower, but
it actually insures that when it receives

517
00:26:10.090 --> 00:26:14.030
that frame on that port, everything
is good before it forwards it on.

518
00:26:14.030 --> 00:26:16.850
So in other words,
there should not be any fragmentation or

519
00:26:16.850 --> 00:26:20.370
any corruption in the data when
it actually goes into the port.

520
00:26:20.370 --> 00:26:22.770
And when it leaves the port as well.

521
00:26:22.770 --> 00:26:27.470
So, there's a little bit of technicality
involved in this switch here and

522
00:26:27.470 --> 00:26:29.670
a little bit of overkill.

523
00:26:29.670 --> 00:26:32.650
I hate to say it, it's on the exam

>> Yeah, they're definitely upping

This is not introductory material.

This is how switches work,
it's not just the basics of it.

528
00:26:49.090 --> 00:26:53.330
>> Yeah, no I learned this when I
started studying from my CCNA, seven,

00:26:53.330 --> 00:26:54.420
ten years ago.

00:26:54.420 --> 00:26:57.150
So wasn't that I would like empty it,
but when I saw it I was like,

531
00:26:57.150 --> 00:26:58.610
well we got to cover it.

532
00:26:58.610 --> 00:27:00.010
So, we at least need to know the basics.

533
00:27:00.010 --> 00:27:03.210
Now, did I really kind of
give you the whole run down?

534
00:27:03.210 --> 00:27:06.750
No, by far, but at least the description
of it so you do have that.

535
00:27:06.750 --> 00:27:08.020
Remember those term, right?

536
00:27:08.020 --> 00:27:11.320
Cut in through, fragment free [LAUGH] and

537
00:27:11.320 --> 00:27:15.750
storm ford, got to remember those and once
we do that we're fine and perfect to go.

538
00:27:15.750 --> 00:27:16.490
>> That's right.

539
00:27:16.490 --> 00:27:18.920
Now, the last thing we
need to cover is well,

540
00:27:18.920 --> 00:27:21.460
one of the biggest topics when
it comes to switching it.

541
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:25.132
How does the switch know that when
it receives data in port one and

542
00:27:25.132 --> 00:27:28.940
that it's destined, and
that's from our own computer, right?

543
00:27:28.940 --> 00:27:33.045
That computer might be
IP address 192.168.2.45,

544
00:27:33.045 --> 00:27:36.242
and it wants to send to
maybe to Ryan's computer.

545
00:27:36.242 --> 00:27:40.585
He's 192.168.1.55, right?

546
00:27:40.585 --> 00:27:46.235
How does it know that Ronny's plugged into
port 23 and I'm plugged into port 22,

547
00:27:46.235 --> 00:27:50.160
and get that data to go there and
not to everybody else.

548
00:27:50.160 --> 00:27:52.999
Well, that's where the Mac
table comes in to play,

549
00:27:52.999 --> 00:27:57.255
basically a database of whose connected
to what and so they can do that on a fly,

550
00:27:57.255 --> 00:28:00.239
Ron your here to give us
a little more detail than that.

551
00:28:00.239 --> 00:28:01.380
>> Right.
When a switch,

552
00:28:01.380 --> 00:28:03.967
when you first plug in
devices to the switch,

553
00:28:03.967 --> 00:28:09.250
the switch learns Mac addresses based off
the source that's actually in the frame.

554
00:28:09.250 --> 00:28:12.500
So when your computer actually
communicates, it's going to have

555
00:28:12.500 --> 00:28:16.310
a destination address, it's also
going to have a source Mac address.

556
00:28:16.310 --> 00:28:20.280
What gets entered in to the Mac address
table is only the source Mac address.

557
00:28:20.280 --> 00:28:23.570
So if I'm plugged in to port 22
like Daniel's describing, you know,

558
00:28:23.570 --> 00:28:27.160
take a look and, oh look, here's this
source here's who's sending it, and

559
00:28:27.160 --> 00:28:30.460
then it attaches it in
that table to port 22.

560
00:28:30.460 --> 00:28:34.830
And then when it actually sends it
through to Daniel's computer which is

561
00:28:34.830 --> 00:28:37.990
the destination, when Daniel's
computer replies back and goes,

562
00:28:37.990 --> 00:28:41.480
hey this is from port 23 and
Here's Daniele's Mac address and

563
00:28:41.480 --> 00:28:45.380
we'll attach it there, and
now we have that established in the table.

564
00:28:45.380 --> 00:28:48.310
The reason why that's important
is it doesn't have to go out and

565
00:28:48.310 --> 00:28:51.920
figure out what that Mac address is now,
it just simply looks it up in table.

566
00:28:51.920 --> 00:28:54.180
The first time takes
a little bit of time like,

567
00:28:54.180 --> 00:28:58.290
I say again, now your talking about two
thoughts behind what we're talking about.

568
00:28:58.290 --> 00:29:00.090
It really doesn't take any time at all.

569
00:29:00.090 --> 00:29:03.290
But once it starts learning it, it starts
populating that mac address table.

570
00:29:03.290 --> 00:29:04.660
Let me show you that here.

571
00:29:04.660 --> 00:29:08.210
So here it is I'm back on this
switch that we're seeing here.

572
00:29:08.210 --> 00:29:11.910
And so if I go into this,
let me get back out here.

573
00:29:11.910 --> 00:29:15.550
And let me do one more that way
I don't get anybody confused.

574
00:29:15.550 --> 00:29:22.720
All I have to do is type show
mac address dash table, and you

575
00:29:22.720 --> 00:29:26.580
can see right here that there are actually
several different types of addresses.

576
00:29:26.580 --> 00:29:29.560
All of these static CPUs that
you're seeing right here,

577
00:29:29.560 --> 00:29:34.600
these are the Mac addresses of the port's
themselves, is what you're seeing, okay?

578
00:29:34.600 --> 00:29:38.370
So it's actually listed as cpu,
you're actually seeing that Mac address.

579
00:29:38.370 --> 00:29:41.770
When you see the ones that
are listed as dynamic,

580
00:29:41.770 --> 00:29:46.150
those are the ones when they connect and
they start sending packets back and forth.

581
00:29:46.150 --> 00:29:49.350
When you see dynamic this is
saying that the switch learned

582
00:29:49.350 --> 00:29:54.080
this from the source
address of what came in.

583
00:29:54.080 --> 00:29:58.908
And you see this on Gig,
this is Gig ethernet port zero/two.

584
00:29:58.908 --> 00:30:04.224
And you can also see one on
fast ethernet zero/six and

585
00:30:04.224 --> 00:30:07.340
two and nine and two again.

586
00:30:07.340 --> 00:30:10.940
So, on this two port,
right, this Gig two port.

587
00:30:10.940 --> 00:30:14.760
Notice that multiple MAC addresses
can be assigned to a single port.

588
00:30:14.760 --> 00:30:18.630
So if you keep sending data that way, it
actually says look, if you're looking for

589
00:30:18.630 --> 00:30:21.840
one of these other devices, yeah,
you can forward it out me, and

590
00:30:21.840 --> 00:30:23.350
it will actually get there.

591
00:30:23.350 --> 00:30:26.660
So it really does help us, because now
we're not having to communicate with

592
00:30:26.660 --> 00:30:28.450
the other side to verify it's over there.

593
00:30:28.450 --> 00:30:31.720
The Mac address table says it's over
there, and I know exactly what port and

594
00:30:31.720 --> 00:30:35.390
send out of and this is also
part of what makes it so fast.

595
00:30:35.390 --> 00:30:39.020
So if it doesn't know at the beginning,
that's what happens.

596
00:30:39.020 --> 00:30:43.090
By having this right here at the switch,
it makes the switch work so much faster

597
00:30:43.090 --> 00:30:46.900
along with the A six that we just talked
about, this is what gives us the lightning

598
00:30:46.900 --> 00:30:50.370
speeds inside of our network in
comparison to using things like routers.

599
00:30:50.370 --> 00:30:51.010
>> That's right.

600
00:30:51.010 --> 00:30:54.010
And this is basically the difference
between it and a hub.

601
00:30:54.010 --> 00:30:57.790
If you've built a small network before,
maybe you used a hub, a very small device.

602
00:30:57.790 --> 00:31:01.101
They look very similar to
the same size switches itself.

603
00:31:01.101 --> 00:31:04.744
And the only real difference is
that with a hub, you put in data,

604
00:31:04.744 --> 00:31:06.378
it pops it out of every port.

605
00:31:06.378 --> 00:31:09.870
No matter how many times you send that
data, it just shoves it out of every port

606
00:31:09.870 --> 00:31:13.410
and says whoever this is destined for,
you might want to snatch that up.

607
00:31:13.410 --> 00:31:14.910
Everybody else will just drop it.

608
00:31:14.910 --> 00:31:19.510
Where the switch knows that it goes
from this port to that port, and

609
00:31:19.510 --> 00:31:22.820
only if it doesn't know where
a device is that you've requested

610
00:31:22.820 --> 00:31:24.180
does it flood it out of every port.

611
00:31:24.180 --> 00:31:27.986
Otherwise it just says all right,
I know that's look at my Mac table here.

612
00:31:27.986 --> 00:31:30.708
That's destined for port 27,
and out port 27 it goes.

613
00:31:30.708 --> 00:31:35.587
Having that Mac table is
the intelligence really that separates

614
00:31:35.587 --> 00:31:39.937
a switch from a hub,
making them two different devices.

615
00:31:39.937 --> 00:31:41.098
>> And that is correct.

They detail how a router is able to learn about different networks using Dynamic Routing, or how you can set a route manually using Static routes. They also cover the topics of transmission speeds and default routes.

the directly connected routes.

00:12:00.370 --> 00:12:03.680
Now when I see the letter C it
tells me up here in the codes,

228
00:12:03.680 --> 00:12:06.350
in the legend,
that that is a connected route.

229
00:12:06.350 --> 00:12:10.870
So routers will automatically, at the very
beginning, learn of those routes that

230
00:12:10.870 --> 00:12:13.220
it's directly connected to or
the networks that it's connected to.

231
00:12:13.220 --> 00:12:17.080
And then you can see where it actually
reports it off of that interface.

232
00:12:17.080 --> 00:12:20.890
So you see that there's a couple
of them for us right here.

233
00:12:20.890 --> 00:12:25.660
When we start talking about how it learns,
so it knows how to do that, and

234
00:12:25.660 --> 00:12:29.860
when it can actually do something like
that, we can then turn on routing

235
00:12:29.860 --> 00:12:35.120
protocols and the routing protocols that
are shared between different routers,

236
00:12:35.120 --> 00:12:39.240
what they can do is, they can start
teaching each other routes as well.

237
00:12:39.240 --> 00:12:42.160
So, when you see
the letter O over here and

238
00:12:42.160 --> 00:12:46.440
the letter D,
these are two different routing protocols.

239
00:12:46.440 --> 00:12:52.430
One is for a routing protocol called
EIGRP and the other one is for OSPF.

240
00:12:52.430 --> 00:12:57.950
These routes were actually on different
routers that this router is connected to,

241
00:12:57.950 --> 00:13:02.170
and those routers send that information
to populate this router right here.

242
00:13:02.170 --> 00:13:04.812
And so now as data is
actually being populated for

243
00:13:04.812 --> 00:13:07.847
all of these different routes
that are available to us.

244
00:13:07.847 --> 00:13:12.836
Well that means that any data that comes
into this router regardless of any

245
00:13:12.836 --> 00:13:17.824
of those three ports, what can happen
is that if it's coming in let's say

246
00:13:17.824 --> 00:13:20.890
on port 0/0 which is that T1 connection.

247
00:13:20.890 --> 00:13:24.559
If it comes in there and
it's actually destined for

248
00:13:24.559 --> 00:13:28.850
let's say the 12 network hit, 192.168.12.

249
00:13:28.850 --> 00:13:31.180
Well it knows that it's
directly connected to it and

250
00:13:31.180 --> 00:13:35.190
it will send that data out
a fast ethernet zero slash zero.

251
00:13:35.190 --> 00:13:38.720
But what about other routes
that's not directly connected?

252
00:13:38.720 --> 00:13:41.598
So let's take for
a example the 22 network down here.

253
00:13:41.598 --> 00:13:46.550
22.22.22.22 is connected down here.

254
00:13:46.550 --> 00:13:50.450
Well, if I have data that comes
in from that serial connection,

255
00:13:50.450 --> 00:13:54.670
it will come and it will match
against this route at the bottom.

256
00:13:54.670 --> 00:13:59.390
And we'll take a look and it says look,
this is how I learned about that route and

257
00:13:59.390 --> 00:14:01.530
this is where I actually sent it from.

258
00:14:01.530 --> 00:14:04.650
So instead it will forward
data out there as well.

259
00:14:04.650 --> 00:14:08.040
So dynamic routing tables
are really the way to go.

260
00:14:08.040 --> 00:14:11.600
Especially if networks are constantly
changing, because if not,

261
00:14:11.600 --> 00:14:15.060
I have to go in there and
manually change that as well.

262
00:14:15.060 --> 00:14:19.810
So when we talk about learning routes,
dynamic routing protocols will do it,

263
00:14:19.810 --> 00:14:25.390
but we can also statically
assign a route as well.

264
00:14:25.390 --> 00:14:26.240
Now I wanna do that so

265
00:14:26.240 --> 00:14:29.690
that we can take a look at
the difference when we start seeing it.

266
00:14:29.690 --> 00:14:31.880
So, this routing table is fairly typical.

267
00:14:31.880 --> 00:14:34.560
It tells us the destination of the route.

268
00:14:34.560 --> 00:14:38.120
It also tells us what interface
is gonna send it out.

269
00:14:38.120 --> 00:14:42.100
But then you also what we call different
metrics that are also involved

270
00:14:42.100 --> 00:14:43.200
in this too.

271
00:14:43.200 --> 00:14:45.780
Now, the metrics are actually based off of

272
00:14:45.780 --> 00:14:50.210
how they calculate what's the best
possible route in the routing table.

273
00:14:50.210 --> 00:14:53.180
Or what's that best possible route
to that destination, I should say.

274
00:14:53.180 --> 00:14:56.340
And that actually leads me to something
I probably should have led with.

275
00:14:56.340 --> 00:14:59.140
The only types of routes that
get into this routing table

276
00:14:59.140 --> 00:15:03.950
are what we call the best route that's
available according to the metric.

277
00:15:03.950 --> 00:15:05.030
And the reason why that's important,

278
00:15:05.030 --> 00:15:08.210
remember that there can be multiple
paths to a single destination.

279
00:15:08.210 --> 00:15:11.700
But not all of them are actually
what we call the best route, so

280
00:15:11.700 --> 00:15:15.040
usually the route with the lowest metric
is the one that gets entered into your

281
00:15:15.040 --> 00:15:16.760
routing table as well.

282
00:15:16.760 --> 00:15:20.100
So there are a lot of considerations
that have to be done, but

283
00:15:20.100 --> 00:15:24.710
here's a great example of what can be
done without me having to do anything.

284
00:15:24.710 --> 00:15:26.890
Except for turn on the routing protocol.

285
00:15:26.890 --> 00:15:31.229
So I had two separate routers that had all
these routes available and all I had to

286
00:15:31.229 --> 00:15:35.723
do with this particular router here is
just say, I want you to learn OSPF routes.

287
00:15:35.723 --> 00:15:37.889
I want you to learn EIGRP routes.

288
00:15:37.889 --> 00:15:42.093
And in just a minute or so of time, maybe
not even that long, it went ahead and

289
00:15:42.093 --> 00:15:44.280
was able to retrieve all these routes.

290
00:15:44.280 --> 00:15:47.120
Or was sent all these routes and
that means now this router can

291
00:15:47.120 --> 00:15:51.310
effectively route all these routes
toward its ultimate destination.

292
00:15:51.310 --> 00:15:53.170
Very cool,
without me having to do anything.

293
00:15:53.170 --> 00:15:56.920
>> Yeah, it's definitely the way to fly,
the dynamic routing protocols.

294
00:15:56.920 --> 00:15:59.334
They are awesome.
Like Ronnie said They're gonna learn those

295
00:15:59.334 --> 00:16:02.474
routes for you, instead of you
having to try to figure out, okay,

296
00:16:02.474 --> 00:16:05.910
well here's another route that I've
got to put into the routing table.

297
00:16:05.910 --> 00:16:07.644
And then you manually configure those.

298
00:16:07.644 --> 00:16:12.101
Not that you don't ever do that,
that's the idea of static routing is,

299
00:16:12.101 --> 00:16:16.790
sometimes I do want to say, this is
how I want you to get to this network.

300
00:16:16.790 --> 00:16:19.552
And I know that path, and
this is how it needs to be.

301
00:16:19.552 --> 00:16:22.353
But for the most part we're going to
networks that we don't really know

302
00:16:22.353 --> 00:16:23.400
anything about.

303
00:16:23.400 --> 00:16:26.480
That's why we allow those dynamic
protocols to work for us, and

304
00:16:26.480 --> 00:16:27.570
they don't learn every route.

305
00:16:27.570 --> 00:16:31.621
They learn the best routes, otherwise
we'd have a myriad of routes inside

306
00:16:31.621 --> 00:16:35.561
of a router, that would grow to
exponential size and it would be insane.

307
00:16:35.561 --> 00:16:39.460
And a little too much for even our routers
to be to handle, to be honest with you.

308
00:16:39.460 --> 00:16:42.703
You'd need super high-end
equipment to be able to handle

309
00:16:42.703 --> 00:16:44.430
those size of routing tables.

310
00:16:44.430 --> 00:16:48.809
So we allow the dynamic protocols to say,
hey, here's the best route for

311
00:16:48.809 --> 00:16:51.644
you to get using this
type of routing protocol.

312
00:16:51.644 --> 00:16:55.460
So it does a lot of the work for us,
makes our job a whole lot easier.

313
00:16:55.460 --> 00:16:57.660
Cuz then all we have to do is say okay,

314
00:16:57.660 --> 00:17:01.910
I'm gonna turn on that routing protocol
and give it the networks that I know of.

315
00:17:01.910 --> 00:17:06.157
Allow it to start communicating with
other routers using the same protocol and

316
00:17:06.157 --> 00:17:07.323
populate its table.

317
00:17:07.323 --> 00:17:11.440
I just sit back and relax, maybe watch
a little ITProTV, you know how it is.

318
00:17:11.440 --> 00:17:14.419
And enjoy my day instead of having
to do all that stuff manually.

319
00:17:14.419 --> 00:17:17.380
That can be a configuration nightmare,
right Ronnie?

320
00:17:17.380 --> 00:17:20.430
>> It really can, but it's actually
something you might also see.

321
00:17:20.430 --> 00:17:22.170
So I wanted to show you that as well.

322
00:17:22.170 --> 00:17:24.951
I just went in and set up a static
route inside of this router, so

323
00:17:24.951 --> 00:17:28.223
that we could take advantage of it and
see what it actually looks like too.

324
00:17:28.223 --> 00:17:32.571
So on my router,
I configured a static route.

325
00:17:32.571 --> 00:17:35.250
And when you take a look at this,
I went ahead and copied it.

326
00:17:35.250 --> 00:17:38.930
Let me set it so that we can actually
see it right here, is this route.

327
00:17:38.930 --> 00:17:39.910
And they have the letter s,

328
00:17:39.910 --> 00:17:44.110
which if you take a look at the legend
up above, it says static route.

329
00:17:44.110 --> 00:17:47.515
So if I want to manually type in routes,
I can.

330
00:17:47.515 --> 00:17:49.965
So routers can accept whether or
not we type them in,

331
00:17:49.965 --> 00:17:52.650
or whether we learn them
dynamically to do so.

332
00:17:52.650 --> 00:17:56.950
But when it comes down to two routes
that are identical, if it's a dynamic

333
00:17:56.950 --> 00:18:02.070
routing protocol that sent it in, if it's
a static routing protocol that sent it in.

334
00:18:02.070 --> 00:18:06.730
Well, what you would do then, is you
would compare these values right here.

335
00:18:06.730 --> 00:18:09.560
And those values actually
will say which one normally

336
00:18:09.560 --> 00:18:11.010
gets entered into the routing table.

337
00:18:11.010 --> 00:18:12.650
Now if you're looking like, well Ronnie,

338
00:18:12.650 --> 00:18:17.510
you just showed OSPF and this one
actually is still in the routing table.

339
00:18:17.510 --> 00:18:21.850
Well notice that the numbers here at the
end, the prefix link, or the subnet mask,

340
00:18:21.850 --> 00:18:25.641
is different, which means that it
sees them as two different networks.

341
00:18:25.641 --> 00:18:28.700
If they were identical networks,
that would be different.

342
00:18:28.700 --> 00:18:32.890
But notice that this one is actually
routing for the entire 2.2.2 network,

343
00:18:32.890 --> 00:18:37.850
whereas this one's routing for
a single individual device itself.

344
00:18:37.850 --> 00:18:43.140
So we can see static routes appear,
to be able to get access there.

345
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:48.475
Now the other issue that we have, though,
is that sometimes, what if a route

346
00:18:48.475 --> 00:18:53.991
is not in this routing table and my router
actually still needs to forward it on.

347
00:18:53.991 --> 00:18:55.800
Well, that's a problem at this point.

348
00:18:55.800 --> 00:19:00.800
Because if it doesn't actually appear in
the routing table, it has no place to

349
00:19:00.800 --> 00:19:05.753
forward it on to, and so that packet
will die right there at that connection.

350
00:19:05.753 --> 00:19:07.048
So that can be a problem,

351
00:19:07.048 --> 00:19:11.270
especially when you want to make sure that
data actually gets off of the network.

352
00:19:11.270 --> 00:19:15.561
Now I have another router, though, if I
can actually bring that one up here for

353
00:19:15.561 --> 00:19:16.480
a brief second.

354
00:19:16.480 --> 00:19:17.553
Well, if I can find it.

355
00:19:17.553 --> 00:19:19.320
Let's see if I can find that other router.

356
00:19:19.320 --> 00:19:20.290
Router two, there we go.

357
00:19:21.830 --> 00:19:27.733
And on this particular router,
do show ip route.

358
00:19:31.025 --> 00:19:35.241
This one is a little bit different,
but what you see here,

359
00:19:35.241 --> 00:19:40.839
is where it says Gateway of last
resort is set to 192.168.12.1,

360
00:19:40.839 --> 00:19:44.303
which is pointing to
router one's IP address.

361
00:19:44.303 --> 00:19:49.153
And this is for any network that
actually begins with 0.0.0.0.

362
00:19:49.153 --> 00:19:53.774
Well, that 0.0.0.0 is what
we call a default route.

363
00:19:53.774 --> 00:19:57.848
And that's saying if it doesn't match
anything in this routing table,

364
00:19:57.848 --> 00:20:01.813
go ahead and forward it to, well,
router one, is what it's saying.

365
00:20:01.813 --> 00:20:05.794
And down here at the bottom, you can
see that I manually configured that.

366
00:20:05.794 --> 00:20:08.970
Cuz it has not only the static, which
means somebody manually configured it.

367
00:20:08.970 --> 00:20:13.075
It has the asterisk, which means
this is set as a default route.

368
00:20:13.075 --> 00:20:17.539
If it doesn't match anything else on the
routing table, then we're gonna forward it

369
00:20:17.539 --> 00:20:20.773
on to router one, and
that way it will also take care of it too.

370
00:20:20.773 --> 00:20:23.854
So, routers are really
smart devices that can

371
00:20:23.854 --> 00:20:28.320
help us to be able to forward
a tremendous amount of data.

372
00:20:28.320 --> 00:20:32.710
Even to networks that we are not directly
connected to, by issuing things like that,

373
00:20:32.710 --> 00:20:35.860
and allowing the routers to take care
of it on the rest of its pathway.

374
00:20:35.860 --> 00:20:36.730
Very neat stuff.

375
00:20:36.730 --> 00:20:37.950
>> Yeah, routers are no joke.

376
00:20:37.950 --> 00:20:39.833
They definitely have a lot
of smarts behind them.

377
00:20:39.833 --> 00:20:40.847
As you can see,

378
00:20:40.847 --> 00:20:45.763
being able to even determine what is
the best path to take is something that I

379
00:20:45.763 --> 00:20:47.560
would hate to have that job
>> [LAUGH]

380
00:20:47.560 --> 00:20:48.420
>> That is for sure.

381
00:20:48.420 --> 00:20:50.810
I'm glad that routers do that for us.

382
00:20:50.810 --> 00:20:52.390
Now running,
I'm taking a look at our time,

383
00:20:52.390 --> 00:20:55.090
we do have a few more topics
that we need to go over.

384
00:20:55.090 --> 00:20:57.380
Probably take up at least another episode.

385
00:20:57.380 --> 00:21:00.779
So I think this is probably a good spot
for us to go ahead and take a part two.

386
00:21:00.779 --> 00:21:03.880
Is there anything you'd like to
add before we close this down?

387
00:21:03.880 --> 00:21:05.930
>> Well,
just don't get overwhelmed by this.

388
00:21:05.930 --> 00:21:08.100
We are showing you a lot of information.

389
00:21:08.100 --> 00:21:09.910
But remember the basics here, right?

390
00:21:09.910 --> 00:21:12.040
That routers will build a routing table.

391
00:21:12.040 --> 00:21:14.460
They'll build it either if
I type in the routes or

392
00:21:14.460 --> 00:21:16.930
I turn on routing
protocol to make it work.

393
00:21:16.930 --> 00:21:19.020
It will end up working for you.

394
00:21:19.020 --> 00:21:20.850
The good thing is,
all we have to do is plug it in.

395
00:21:20.850 --> 00:21:23.540
So, we might be going
a little bit overboard.

396
00:21:23.540 --> 00:21:24.710
These are actually called out.

397
00:21:24.710 --> 00:21:26.750
So, you do wanna take a look again.

398
00:21:26.750 --> 00:21:28.820
Watch this episode a couple of times.

399
00:21:28.820 --> 00:21:30.520
Take a look at the routes
that we're showing.

400
00:21:30.520 --> 00:21:32.560
And then, just try to let it soak in.

401
00:21:32.560 --> 00:21:33.480
So, make sure you do.

402
00:21:33.480 --> 00:21:36.220
Just take a little bit of a breather.

403
00:21:36.220 --> 00:21:39.734
We're getting a little bit deeper
than what we would normally think.

404
00:21:39.734 --> 00:21:41.157
But that's what we have to do.

405
00:21:41.157 --> 00:21:44.770
>> Yeah, they don't want you to
be able to configure a router.

406
00:21:44.770 --> 00:21:47.610
But they do want you to understand what
is going on inside of the routers.

407
00:21:47.610 --> 00:21:50.330
And that's what, hopefully,
we're helping you guys out with.

408
00:21:50.330 --> 00:21:52.135
And hopefully we will
see in that part two.

409
00:21:52.135 --> 00:21:54.053
Its gotta lot a good
information in there as well.

410
00:21:54.053 --> 00:21:56.120
We'll be making that for
you very, very soon.

411
00:21:56.120 --> 00:21:57.390
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

412
00:21:57.390 --> 00:21:59.644
Thanks for watching,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

413
00:21:59.644 --> 00:22:00.395
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

414
00:22:00.395 --> 00:22:01.938
>> And we'll see you next time.

415
00:22:01.938 --> 00:22:07.830
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining network routers moving specifically into the topic of Network Address Translation(NAT) which allows multiple devices to share a single internet connection. They then show you how to use Windows Server 2008 R2 as a router for you network.
episodes.title: Understanding Routers Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.158
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.158 --> 00:00:11.041
All right.

3
00:00:11.041 --> 00:00:11.891
Greetings, everyone.

4
00:00:11.891 --> 00:00:14.750
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:16.040
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:16.040 --> 00:00:18.760
Joining me today is none other than Mr.
Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:18.760 --> 00:00:19.660
How's it going Ronnie?

8
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:20.634
>> It's going great today.

9
00:00:20.634 --> 00:00:25.235
It's another great day to be right
here as we prepare to take at the MTA,

10
00:00:25.235 --> 00:00:28.853
the Microsoft Technology Associate
exam 98366.

11
00:00:28.853 --> 00:00:33.718
If you're there to get your networking
fundamentals down with that MTA,

12
00:00:33.718 --> 00:00:35.610
well this is the place to be.

13
00:00:35.610 --> 00:00:39.974
We've already been taking a look at
understanding routers, trying to make sure

14
00:00:39.974 --> 00:00:43.580
that we have a solid grasp on what
a router does and the basics here.

15
00:00:43.580 --> 00:00:46.840
Remember that it actually really does
help us to build a routing table

16
00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:49.330
which allows data to be
able to be forwarded to,

17
00:00:49.330 --> 00:00:52.460
well, even devices that it's
not directly connected to.

18
00:00:52.460 --> 00:00:55.680
We've also already taken a look at
switches in previous episodes too.

19
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:58.520
So make sure you do check
those episodes out as well.

20
00:00:58.520 --> 00:01:02.900
But we still have a little bit of, well,
routing technology that we need to at

21
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:05.940
least understand so that we can
actually get a grasp of that routers

22
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:09.070
don't just do that, they can actually
do just a little bit more as well.

23
00:01:09.070 --> 00:01:11.590
>> Yeah we got just like Ronnie said,
a little bit more to cover.

24
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:13.130
Un poquito as they say.

25
00:01:14.190 --> 00:01:17.500
Well, what Ronnie's talking about,
what we have left really.

26
00:01:17.500 --> 00:01:18.870
It's actually a really cool feature.

27
00:01:18.870 --> 00:01:23.180
Now, this is something that may be
happening actually on your home systems.

28
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:24.890
You probably don't realize it if it is,
and

29
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:28.740
that's cool because it's doing
something for you that is awesome.

30
00:01:28.740 --> 00:01:32.400
And the fact is that, you have an Internet
connection at home, I'm sure if you're

31
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:36.300
watching this, then it's probably very
helpful for you to be able to do that.

32
00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:41.170
But you probably have more than one device
connected to that Internet connection.

33
00:01:41.170 --> 00:01:43.970
Well, how does the when
you go to ITPro.TV,

34
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:48.270
how do they know to send it back to
the laptop you're sitting on and

35
00:01:48.270 --> 00:01:50.710
not your the-
>> Desktop.

36
00:01:50.710 --> 00:01:52.890
>> Yeah,
the desktop sitting in the other office,

37
00:01:52.890 --> 00:01:54.120
how's it know not to send it to there?

38
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:56.659
How does it know which
device to send it to?

39
00:01:56.659 --> 00:01:58.308
And that's what we're going to do here.

40
00:01:58.308 --> 00:01:59.690
That's what we're going
to kind of explain.

41
00:01:59.690 --> 00:02:03.790
How we can use one connection for
multiple devices.

42
00:02:03.790 --> 00:02:07.270
It's really, really cool and
it actually helped keep IPv4

43
00:02:07.270 --> 00:02:10.460
keep its nose above water for
a little while longer than it should have.

44
00:02:10.460 --> 00:02:11.350
But we really like it.

45
00:02:11.350 --> 00:02:12.060
It's an enjoyable thing.

46
00:02:12.060 --> 00:02:13.450
It's something we need to know about.

47
00:02:13.450 --> 00:02:15.380
And it's called NAT, right Ronnie?

48
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:17.630
>> Yep.
When we start taking a look at NAT,

49
00:02:17.630 --> 00:02:20.280
we talk about network address translation.

50
00:02:20.280 --> 00:02:21.520
So there's another one of those acronyms.

51
00:02:21.520 --> 00:02:23.900
So remember, if you're getting
into this field, get used to them.

52
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:25.720
They are not going anywhere.

53
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:29.150
So acronyms are the language
that we speak in IT.

54
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:33.917
Network address translation primarily
was designed to do exactly what

55
00:02:33.917 --> 00:02:37.333
Daniel described here,
which was really to try and

56
00:02:37.333 --> 00:02:42.434
slow down the depletion of the IP version
for addresses out on the Internet.

57
00:02:42.434 --> 00:02:45.138
Now, how does it do
something that like that?

58
00:02:45.138 --> 00:02:49.626
Well, what it actually began to do, along
with some the other technologies that

59
00:02:49.626 --> 00:02:52.596
we've talked about before,
it actually allows us,

60
00:02:52.596 --> 00:02:57.610
instead of the signing let's say an entire
Class C addressed to let's say Daniel.

61
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:01.950
That gives him about 254 IP addresses
that are valid on the Internet.

62
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:05.250
Well instead ISPs can
give him one address.

63
00:03:05.250 --> 00:03:11.260
Well what if Daniel has 1,000 users or
1,000 devices on his network and

64
00:03:11.260 --> 00:03:14.480
he's only got one IP address
that's valid on the Internet.

65
00:03:14.480 --> 00:03:16.960
Well that becomes much more challenging.

66
00:03:16.960 --> 00:03:21.010
Well, internally though,
Daniel can use those private IP addresses,

67
00:03:21.010 --> 00:03:23.550
the ones that are not
allowed on the Internet, and

68
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:28.010
he can actually do all the networking
internally the way that he chooses to do.

69
00:03:28.010 --> 00:03:33.390
But now when he trys to connect outside of
the Internet though well, what happens is,

70
00:03:33.390 --> 00:03:37.900
that we need the technology that
allows all those internal addresses,

71
00:03:37.900 --> 00:03:42.690
to get translated in to one or
a few addresses instead.

72
00:03:42.690 --> 00:03:49.110
And that will then allow 1,000 devices to
use one or just a few different addresses,

73
00:03:49.110 --> 00:03:52.170
depending on the way that you
actually have it set up to do that.

74
00:03:52.170 --> 00:03:55.510
And so when that actually gets out to the
Internet, if you only have one address,

75
00:03:55.510 --> 00:03:59.350
what your network actually looks
like is an incredibly busy,

76
00:03:59.350 --> 00:04:02.710
busy computer that is
constantly sending data.

77
00:04:02.710 --> 00:04:04.515
So, let me show you just a brief diagram.

78
00:04:04.515 --> 00:04:07.575
And then we'll take a look at it
from the router perspective as well,

79
00:04:07.575 --> 00:04:10.105
in how that might end up looking out here.

80
00:04:10.105 --> 00:04:12.726
So let's say that over here
on the left hand side.

81
00:04:12.726 --> 00:04:16.986
This is my network,
the 192.168.12.0 network.

82
00:04:16.986 --> 00:04:23.535
Well if that is my network, there's a
possibility of 254 hosts on that network.

83
00:04:23.535 --> 00:04:26.070
And then, I have my router, and

84
00:04:26.070 --> 00:04:28.690
I'm connected out here to
the Internet at some point.

85
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:32.500
The cloud is actually representation
of that Internet connection.

86
00:04:32.500 --> 00:04:35.440
Now that's true and
I have a connection like that.

87
00:04:35.440 --> 00:04:36.980
Now that's perfectly fine but

88
00:04:36.980 --> 00:04:41.850
what if I am only given one IP address
when I actually go out and do that?

89
00:04:41.850 --> 00:04:43.730
So let's say that I only have one.

90
00:04:43.730 --> 00:04:48.543
Well those 254 computers need to be able
to use that one IP address to connect and

91
00:04:48.543 --> 00:04:51.494
communicate wherever
they're actually going.

92
00:04:51.494 --> 00:04:54.477
Now at this end I just have 3.3.3.3.

93
00:04:54.477 --> 00:04:57.210
I just made up these addresses
to kind of help us out.

94
00:04:57.210 --> 00:04:59.250
So as it goes across the Internet,

95
00:04:59.250 --> 00:05:02.780
all of the data coming from
this network over here,

96
00:05:02.780 --> 00:05:07.780
it really looks like it's actually going
to come from this IP address right here.

97
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:11.680
So regardless of what device is actually
inside that network, it actually looks

98
00:05:11.680 --> 00:05:16.830
like it's coming from this one
interface and that's what happens.

99
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:18.570
But it also works backward then,

100
00:05:18.570 --> 00:05:23.810
all the traffic externally is doing
what Daniel was also describing earlier.

101
00:05:23.810 --> 00:05:28.760
If there's only one out of those 254
computers and it's returning it back to

102
00:05:28.760 --> 00:05:33.360
this IP address, well how does it know
which computer made that request?

103
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:38.710
And that is because inside of the router,
it keeps a track of those links and

104
00:05:38.710 --> 00:05:41.850
then it says, all right,
this is actually coming back from here.

105
00:05:41.850 --> 00:05:45.910
And this actually belongs to
this one IP address inside.

106
00:05:45.910 --> 00:05:48.700
So this has to be set up on the router.

107
00:05:48.700 --> 00:05:51.230
And it's actually not a super
difficult configuration.

108
00:05:51.230 --> 00:05:53.890
But it is beyond the scope of
what we're talking about now.

109
00:05:53.890 --> 00:05:56.438
It's just so that we understand
that this is what happens.

110
00:05:56.438 --> 00:05:59.620
This is why we do have that
ability to do something like that.

111
00:05:59.620 --> 00:06:02.710
That's what we call overloading
a single address, right?

112
00:06:02.710 --> 00:06:05.580
So, when you do have multiple
addresses internally, and

113
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:07.380
then using one external address.

114
00:06:07.380 --> 00:06:10.960
That is something you may hear
the term NAT overload a lot of times.

115
00:06:10.960 --> 00:06:13.780
Or we just call it port
address translation.

116
00:06:13.780 --> 00:06:15.820
That's, by far, the most typical one.

117
00:06:15.820 --> 00:06:21.270
There is the ability to also do what
we call a Static NAT address, instead.

118
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:25.250
So what I might have for my company is
that I might have gotten from my ISP,

119
00:06:25.250 --> 00:06:27.760
let's say 8 or 16 or

120
00:06:27.760 --> 00:06:32.020
32 different IP addresses that
I can use out on the Internet.

121
00:06:32.020 --> 00:06:36.080
Well, what I might have internally
is let's say a web server.

122
00:06:36.080 --> 00:06:39.240
And I need the public to get
access to the web server but

123
00:06:39.240 --> 00:06:41.820
I have it internally on my own network.

124
00:06:41.820 --> 00:06:47.240
Well what I can do instead of assigning
that one PC a public IP address.

125
00:06:47.240 --> 00:06:49.580
I can just map it instead.

126
00:06:49.580 --> 00:06:53.660
And that way only that one machine
gets to use that one IP address so

127
00:06:53.660 --> 00:06:56.010
that when you connect you connect
through that IP address and

128
00:06:56.010 --> 00:06:58.440
it all goes to that one machine as well.

129
00:06:58.440 --> 00:07:00.860
There's also a way that
you can do just a few.

130
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:04.700
If you wanted to take those 8 or
16 of them and divvy them up and

131
00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:06.950
do that you can do that, as well.

132
00:07:06.950 --> 00:07:08.000
Now when you do something like that,

133
00:07:08.000 --> 00:07:11.560
it actually limits you to about
eight connections if you had eight.

134
00:07:11.560 --> 00:07:14.995
So eight connections at a time and
that meant that if you had a ninth,

135
00:07:14.995 --> 00:07:18.395
then one of those eight would have to drop
off before they could make a connection.

136
00:07:18.395 --> 00:07:21.995
But, by far, the one that you and
I are going to end up seeing though

137
00:07:21.995 --> 00:07:26.365
is going to be that port address
translation or what we call NAT Overload.

138
00:07:26.365 --> 00:07:29.550
All of the addresses
are translated into one address.

139
00:07:29.550 --> 00:07:32.900
So I do have an example to
kind of show you right here.

140
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:37.370
Okay, let me see if I can bring up that
router that I want to bring up here.

141
00:07:37.370 --> 00:07:40.248
Let me see if I can actually
find the right one.

142
00:07:42.847 --> 00:07:44.910
Oh there we go, router one,
that's the one that I was looking for.

143
00:07:44.910 --> 00:07:46.900
I don't see all the ones that we have.

144
00:07:46.900 --> 00:07:49.810
Now this router is set up to be that way.

145
00:07:49.810 --> 00:07:51.986
That on the one side of the router right,

146
00:07:51.986 --> 00:07:56.220
is my internal network on the other side
is set up to connect to someplace else.

147
00:07:56.220 --> 00:07:59.440
So this is the router
that is set up to handle.

148
00:07:59.440 --> 00:08:00.650
Now, when we do something like this,
right?

149
00:08:00.650 --> 00:08:03.457
I don't really have to
configure much more here but

150
00:08:03.457 --> 00:08:07.000
I do need to generate traffic
to make nat end up working.

151
00:08:07.000 --> 00:08:10.170
So what I'm going to do is,
if I can find that connection again,

152
00:08:10.170 --> 00:08:11.780
let me go back over here.

153
00:08:13.180 --> 00:08:15.793
And then I need to actually
bring up router two.

154
00:08:15.793 --> 00:08:19.195
And so router two,
if it's going to connect outside.

155
00:08:19.195 --> 00:08:21.238
Let's say to that 3.3.3.3.

156
00:08:21.238 --> 00:08:25.898
Well I can just go ahead and ping that,
and that way, we generate some traffic,

157
00:08:25.898 --> 00:08:31.396
and I know that there's actually another
device over there that's 33.33.33.3,

158
00:08:31.396 --> 00:08:34.800
and I can also do that,
and send that outbound.

159
00:08:34.800 --> 00:08:40.005
Now if I do that, and
then I switch back over to router one,

160
00:08:40.005 --> 00:08:46.390
if I haven't waited too long,
I can do a show IP nat translations.

161
00:08:46.390 --> 00:08:51.660
And then you can see where both of
those links it right, by sending

162
00:08:51.660 --> 00:08:57.320
out just a ping from that one IP address,
it got translated into 13.1 even though

163
00:08:57.320 --> 00:09:02.000
I was on router two, which had a 12.2
address and that's where you see this.

164
00:09:02.000 --> 00:09:05.810
And then it actually got out to
the other machines that I sent it to.

165
00:09:05.810 --> 00:09:09.730
These other machines, when they send it
back, they're sending it to this global

166
00:09:09.730 --> 00:09:13.750
address, which will then
translate it back inside as well.

167
00:09:13.750 --> 00:09:18.130
So this happens all the time with just
about every network that's out there.

168
00:09:18.130 --> 00:09:21.260
Now, this is a small little,
tiny example but

169
00:09:21.260 --> 00:09:24.390
if you were actually to see this live
it would be constantly filling up.

170
00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:27.560
The screen would be rolling is what
you would normally have inside of

171
00:09:27.560 --> 00:09:28.690
a regular network.

172
00:09:28.690 --> 00:09:31.340
So, these devices can be
set up to handle that and

173
00:09:31.340 --> 00:09:34.810
that's normally where you
do see it set up to do so.

174
00:09:34.810 --> 00:09:36.800
Why?
Because we don't really need to see

175
00:09:36.800 --> 00:09:37.900
every single one.

176
00:09:37.900 --> 00:09:40.160
We just need to know it's
actually working and happening.

177
00:09:40.160 --> 00:09:44.150
And so, a router is a great place for it
because normally what happens on routers

00:09:44.150 --> 00:09:45.880

179
00:09:45.880 --> 00:09:50.210
You normally set it and forget it unless
you actually have to add in a new route or

180
00:09:50.210 --> 00:09:52.110
there's something wrong with the machine.

181
00:09:52.110 --> 00:09:53.800
So this is a perfect place for it.

182
00:09:53.800 --> 00:09:55.840
>> Yeah, let the router do the job, right?

183
00:09:55.840 --> 00:09:56.668
That's what it's there for.

184
00:09:56.668 --> 00:10:00.604
To take that load off of us not to have
to do a bunch administrative things.

185
00:10:00.604 --> 00:10:03.226
Now Ronnie I'm looking at
your configuration there,

186
00:10:03.226 --> 00:10:06.310
it's got the addresses and
it has a colon and a number.

187
00:10:06.310 --> 00:10:10.090
I understand the IP address,
we covered that, but what's that colon and

00:10:10.090 --> 00:10:10.720
number all about?

189
00:10:10.720 --> 00:10:11.720
>> All right, So

190
00:10:11.720 --> 00:10:15.600
yeah let's just bring that up again
I just kind of took it away, but

191
00:10:15.600 --> 00:10:19.220
if we bring that up we can actually see
what Daniel's actually talking about too.

192
00:10:19.220 --> 00:10:22.030
When we do this port address translation,

193
00:10:22.030 --> 00:10:25.940
there's a number that's actually assigned
to keep that traffic separated out.

194
00:10:25.940 --> 00:10:29.450
And this number is generated
at the router itself so

195
00:10:29.450 --> 00:10:33.390
that when we do have even let's say the
same machine goes out to try and connect.

196
00:10:33.390 --> 00:10:36.930
Not only using,
let's say a web traffic, right?

197
00:10:36.930 --> 00:10:39.530
If I'm also connecting
out there to use email.

198
00:10:39.530 --> 00:10:41.120
If I'm doing something else.

199
00:10:41.120 --> 00:10:44.640
All of that traffic has to be kept
separated as it comes back in.

200
00:10:44.640 --> 00:10:48.720
So I may have one IP address internally,
but then I'm actually connecting five,

201
00:10:48.720 --> 00:10:50.450
six, seven different times.

202
00:10:50.450 --> 00:10:54.650
And then also, I may actually open up

203
00:10:54.650 --> 00:10:57.300
So what it does is it actually
helps to distinguish that.

204
00:10:57.300 --> 00:11:00.010
And when they add in that
little number after the colon,

205
00:11:00.010 --> 00:11:04.680
that is actually the nat address
translation port number.

206
00:11:04.680 --> 00:11:11.190
And it can generate up to 65,535
of them when it actually needs to.

207
00:11:11.190 --> 00:11:14.730
So, normally you do see it actually
start to generate and pop up there.

208
00:11:14.730 --> 00:11:17.950
And then after awhile when nobody
actually is using it again,

209
00:11:17.950 --> 00:11:20.920
the entire table will clear out and
then it will start all over.

210
00:11:20.920 --> 00:11:23.740
But it's always filling up in
a regular network translation.

211
00:11:23.740 --> 00:11:25.480
Here with two things it's not gonna do it.

212
00:11:25.480 --> 00:11:27.080
And I'm gonna try and run that again.

00:11:27.080 --> 00:11:30.090
You notice it's actually gone now,
because it doesn't need it so

214
00:11:30.090 --> 00:11:31.810
why keep it in the table here?

215
00:11:31.810 --> 00:11:33.320
But that's what that colon's about.

216
00:11:33.320 --> 00:11:34.790
>> Awesome, so that's really cool.

217
00:11:34.790 --> 00:11:37.090
So I've got a bunch of machines
on my internal network,

218
00:11:37.090 --> 00:11:42.700
I only have one actual routable IP address

00:11:42.700 --> 00:11:43.730
All it does is says, all right,

00:11:43.730 --> 00:11:47.780
well you've got this inside address
I'm gonna add this port number to it.

221
00:11:47.780 --> 00:11:52.330
I'm gonna close all that up inside

222
00:11:52.330 --> 00:11:53.490
I'm gonna send that to
where it needs to go.

223
00:11:53.490 --> 00:11:57.660
When it comes back, that little number
lets me know which one of the devices

224
00:11:57.660 --> 00:12:01.110
on my network it's destined for,

225
00:12:01.110 --> 00:12:02.500
It's a very cool process, Ronnie.

00:12:02.500 --> 00:12:06.148

without you and me having to try and

00:12:06.148 --> 00:12:08.974

00:12:08.974 --> 00:12:09.842
The configurations and

00:12:09.842 --> 00:12:12.538
the way that they normally design these

230
00:12:12.538 --> 00:12:14.990
In other words,
smarter people than you and me, and

00:12:14.990 --> 00:12:16.786
I'm not saying you're not a genius.

00:12:16.786 --> 00:12:19.379
But in other words, people that actually

00:12:19.379 --> 00:12:20.363

00:12:20.363 --> 00:12:24.465
They make it work thousands, if not

00:12:24.465 --> 00:12:29.190

00:12:53.480 --> 00:12:58.210
More than likely this idea

00:12:58.210 --> 00:13:00.850
it's not a side road, it's not a tangent.

00:13:00.850 --> 00:13:02.510
It really is a part of networking.

00:13:02.510 --> 00:13:06.770
Now, the funny thing about nat right,

00:13:06.770 --> 00:13:08.620
That was 20, 30 years ago.

It wasn't designed to be permanent.
