00:24:15.070 --> 00:24:17.703
It'd be nice if it actually just said,
okay, as soon as I get a response,

488
00:24:17.703 --> 00:24:18.901
I'm gonna send something back.

489
00:24:18.901 --> 00:24:20.897
But that's the nature of RIP.

490
00:24:20.897 --> 00:24:22.800
It's not very fast.

491
00:24:22.800 --> 00:24:24.418
It can take as long as it wants to, and

492
00:24:24.418 --> 00:24:27.150
there's nothing you're gonna
do to say speed up, speed up.

493
00:24:27.150 --> 00:24:28.540
It's not gonna work.

494
00:24:28.540 --> 00:24:29.949
It's just going to do this thing.

495
00:24:29.949 --> 00:24:34.038
But in probably about 10 or 15 minutes it
actually will have exchanged routes with

496
00:24:34.038 --> 00:24:37.010
the other routers turned on on
the other side of this thing.

497
00:24:37.010 --> 00:24:40.120
>> Yeah, it sounds like they should
call it the really independent protocol,

498
00:24:40.120 --> 00:24:42.541
cuz I don't listen to you,
I do what I want, right?

499
00:24:42.541 --> 00:24:43.239
[LAUGH]
>> That is true,

500
00:24:43.239 --> 00:24:45.359
it does route by rumor that way,
sure enough.

501
00:24:45.359 --> 00:24:47.960
>> All right, well, Ronnie,
thanks for those cool demonstrations.

502
00:24:47.960 --> 00:24:52.280
Obviously, things that we need to know
about routers, why, how they work.

503
00:24:52.280 --> 00:24:56.110
And then that Microsoft actually has
a solution in case you need it and

504
00:24:56.110 --> 00:24:58.510
you don't have a hardware
device sitting around.

505
00:24:58.510 --> 00:25:00.960
If somethings goes down,
you can implement that solution.

506
00:25:00.960 --> 00:25:01.750
Very, very cool.

507
00:25:01.750 --> 00:25:02.730
Thank you for that.

508
00:25:02.730 --> 00:25:03.900
Thank you guys for watching.

509
00:25:03.900 --> 00:25:06.210
We're gonna to go ahead and
call it a day for this episode.

510
00:25:06.210 --> 00:25:09.155
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrey.

511
00:25:09.155 --> 00:25:09.934
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

512
00:25:09.934 --> 00:25:10.840
>> And we'll see you next time.

513
00:25:10.840 --> 00:25:17.590
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the different wired and wireless media types used to connect end devices to a network. They detail the specifics of both copper and fiber cabling including transmission speeds and cable lengths. Then they move into wireless standards and their corresponding speeds, distances, and even security methods.
episodes.title: Understanding Media Types
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.429
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.429 --> 00:00:09.040
All right, greetings everyone,

3
00:00:09.040 --> 00:00:13.902
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:13.902 --> 00:00:14.639
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:14.639 --> 00:00:18.079
Joining me in the studio today is
my good friend and colleague, and

6
00:00:18.079 --> 00:00:22.030
the man that knows just about
everything about this Microsoft exam.

7
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:23.080
Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:23.080 --> 00:00:24.690
How's it going today Ronnie?

9
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:25.500
>> It's going great.

10
00:00:25.500 --> 00:00:28.120
It's another great day to be right
here as we continue to take a look

11
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:31.200
at the MTA
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

12
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:33.650
Getting ready for that exam 9836.

13
00:00:33.650 --> 00:00:37.380
The networking fundamentals exam
is what we're talking about.

14
00:00:37.380 --> 00:00:41.300
And so today we are moving
beyond switches and routers.

15
00:00:41.300 --> 00:00:43.190
These are kind of
the mainstays that you and

16
00:00:43.190 --> 00:00:46.560
I are gonna end up seeing if
we're dealing with networking.

17
00:00:46.560 --> 00:00:50.750
Those two components are probably the big
ones that we've actually had to address.

18
00:00:50.750 --> 00:00:54.870
But as important as those are,
as important as that is,

19
00:00:54.870 --> 00:00:59.090
I should say, we actually also have to
discuss how we connect to those devices,

20
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:02.760
which normally has to deal with some type
of media when we start dealing with that.

21
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:04.210
And that's when we start
talking about cabling,

22
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:07.080
and we actually have to start talking
about even just more than that.

23
00:01:07.080 --> 00:01:07.800
Cuz it seems like well,

24
00:01:07.800 --> 00:01:11.990
I'll just take a piece of wire and plug it
in and I should be ready to go, Daniel.

25
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:14.800
But the problem is there's
a lot more to that, isn't it?

26
00:01:14.800 --> 00:01:15.760
>> Yeah, there is a lot more.

27
00:01:15.760 --> 00:01:18.488
At first I thought he meant
news media outlets, the media.

28
00:01:18.488 --> 00:01:19.210
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

29
00:01:19.210 --> 00:01:20.200
>> But it's not that kind of media.

30
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:21.180
No, ladies and gentlemen.

31
00:01:21.180 --> 00:01:24.690
It is the physical media that
connects the devices together.

32
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:27.980
Now, like Ronnie said,
it can be as simple as oh, it's the wire.

33
00:01:27.980 --> 00:01:29.190
That's what we're talking about.

34
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:31.960
Yes, that is exactly
what we're talking about.

35
00:01:31.960 --> 00:01:34.450
But what about the wire makes it special?

36
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:38.620
Why do we use this wire versus that wire,
this connector versus that connector.

37
00:01:38.620 --> 00:01:41.810
Why is all this different, and
how does it work together?

38
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:44.590
That's what we wanna know, and
even into the wireless technology,

39
00:01:44.590 --> 00:01:46.670
well there is no wire,
they just connect magically.

40
00:01:46.670 --> 00:01:48.150
That's at least, that's what I was told.

41
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:50.060
Apparently there is some
technology behind it.

42
00:01:50.060 --> 00:01:54.500
Which Ronnie is so gracefully decided
to show today and teach us all about.

43
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:57.160
Ronnie, let's start with
the wired specifications and

44
00:01:57.160 --> 00:01:58.020
work our way through that.

45
00:01:58.020 --> 00:02:00.660
>> Yeah, so when we start
taking a look at the idea what,

46
00:02:00.660 --> 00:02:03.550
sometimes you hear the term bounded media
>> We usually just say cabling.

47
00:02:03.550 --> 00:02:05.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what we normally call it,

48
00:02:05.580 --> 00:02:06.550
some type of cabling.

49
00:02:06.550 --> 00:02:10.640
Now, when we start dealing with cabling,
in networking the most prolific

50
00:02:10.640 --> 00:02:14.270
cabling that you're going to see
is some type of copper cabling.

51
00:02:14.270 --> 00:02:16.890
And usually the wire's going
to look something like this.

52
00:02:16.890 --> 00:02:19.310
It's going to have two connectors,
one on each end.

53
00:02:19.310 --> 00:02:20.970
I don't want to unravel the whole thing.

54
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:23.710
But you tend to have these two connectors,
and inside,

55
00:02:23.710 --> 00:02:26.070
of course,
you have a certain length of cable.

56
00:02:26.070 --> 00:02:28.360
Now, these specific connectors
that we're talking about here,

57
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:31.650
these are also the most prolific
type of connectors that you'll see.

58
00:02:31.650 --> 00:02:34.850
On the back of every computer and
just about every device, router, switch,

59
00:02:34.850 --> 00:02:39.390
whatever, it's gonna have a very
standardized type of jack in them

60
00:02:39.390 --> 00:02:40.570
that will accept this connector.

61
00:02:40.570 --> 00:02:45.060
And this is what we call an RJ45
connector, is what we call it.

62
00:02:45.060 --> 00:02:46.460
So, with this RJ45,

63
00:02:46.460 --> 00:02:51.310
it allows you to have eight little
separate wires inside of them.

64
00:02:51.310 --> 00:02:54.460
So what it can do is actually
allow you to transmit data and

65
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:58.380
also receive data as well,
and usually at the same time.

66
00:02:58.380 --> 00:03:02.510
So these cables are by far the most
prolific ones that you'll end up seeing.

67
00:03:02.510 --> 00:03:06.240
Now, the other one that I also have right
here, I'm trying to make sure I grab

68
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:10.730
the right one, is also one that
will look more like this one here.

69
00:03:10.730 --> 00:03:14.350
Now, this is a different type of cabling.

70
00:03:14.350 --> 00:03:16.580
Whereas the other one that
we talked about here,

71
00:03:16.580 --> 00:03:19.480
this allows us to connect to
just about every single machine.

72
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:22.450
This one could if they have
the right network adaptor.

73
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.650
The big difference between both of
these is that this one uses copper and

74
00:03:26.650 --> 00:03:30.080
the reason why is that we're gonna
transmit some type of electrical signal

75
00:03:30.080 --> 00:03:31.700
down this one.

76
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:35.810
This one right here though is
what we call a fiber optic cable.

77
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:38.520
So, each of these ends,
these are a little bit different, and

78
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:42.510
they can be the exact same, but these
ends are actually designed to when you

79
00:03:42.510 --> 00:03:47.460
plug into that device to be able to
transmit light impulses down one wire and

80
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:50.370
also to receive light
impulses on the other wire.

81
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:52.180
And so these cables,

82
00:03:52.180 --> 00:03:56.320
even though they really help us to do the
same things, they are actually different.

83
00:03:56.320 --> 00:03:59.000
They do provide a little
bit of differences

84
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:01.960
in terms of distance that
we can run these cables.

85
00:04:01.960 --> 00:04:06.770
Also, the speed that we can actually
send data down those cables as well and,

86
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:09.930
of course,
they do different things, you know,

87
00:04:09.930 --> 00:04:14.300
in the way that we transmit
the data signals down them as well.

88
00:04:14.300 --> 00:04:16.390
So, when we start taking a look though,

89
00:04:16.390 --> 00:04:19.580
one of the easiest things to forget
about something like this is

90
00:04:19.580 --> 00:04:22.530
where in the world do all these
things belong on the OSI model?

91
00:04:22.530 --> 00:04:25.410
Now you might think, oh no,
not that OSI model again,

92
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:28.390
he mentioned that in like six or
seven shows now, at least.

93
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:31.720
If you think about it, probably
every show that we've actually done,

94
00:04:31.720 --> 00:04:35.810
we've mentioned that but this is one of
the most important concepts that we have.

95
00:04:35.810 --> 00:04:40.390
So Daniel, if you were to think about
both of these here, and you were to take

96
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:45.650
a guess, do you think that they
are actually on the same OSI layer?

97
00:04:45.650 --> 00:04:46.930
>> That would be my guess.

98
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:50.360
I would say that they are both layer
one devices because they are physical.

99
00:04:50.360 --> 00:04:51.250
I can hold them.

100
00:04:51.250 --> 00:04:53.040
That's about it.

101
00:04:53.040 --> 00:04:55.825
They don't do anything
other than carry a signal.

102
00:04:55.825 --> 00:04:58.640
>> And that's exactly
the way to think about this.

103
00:04:58.640 --> 00:05:01.640
So even though fiber optic
sounds much more exotic.

104
00:05:01.640 --> 00:05:02.851
Ooh, very European!

105
00:05:02.851 --> 00:05:10.333
[LAUGH] [CROSSTALK] When you hear
the term fiber optic, it's neat, right?

106
00:05:10.333 --> 00:05:13.030
You go, man, fiber optic,
that sounds cool.

107
00:05:13.030 --> 00:05:16.630
And you hear the term wire, [LAUGH]
you kind of don't get the same feel.

108
00:05:16.630 --> 00:05:18.840
But they both do exactly what Daniel said.

109
00:05:18.840 --> 00:05:20.680
They're not there to inspect the traffic.

110
00:05:20.680 --> 00:05:24.480
They're not there to look and see,
is this traffic worthy of fibre optic?

111
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:26.620
Or is it only worthy of
a copper cable here.

112
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:30.000
The only thing that they're designed
to do is actually carry that data.

113
00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:33.360
And so when we start talking
on that OSI model, right?

114
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:34.800
That seven layer model.

115
00:05:34.800 --> 00:05:39.120
We are now talking about that layer one,
which is the physical layer.

116
00:05:39.120 --> 00:05:43.400
Now, the big difference, though,
between both of these is fairly simple.

117
00:05:43.400 --> 00:05:45.590
This one uses electrical signal, and

118
00:05:45.590 --> 00:05:50.960
this one uses some sort of light
impulse to carry that data along.

119
00:05:50.960 --> 00:05:54.440
So if we were to compare them and
it's actually fairly easy.

120
00:05:54.440 --> 00:05:59.120
I'm gonna make it easy on you Daniel,
light and electricity.

121
00:05:59.120 --> 00:06:02.782
Which one do you think
travels faster in data terms?

122
00:06:02.782 --> 00:06:04.960
>> You know,
I only made it through the third grade but

123
00:06:04.960 --> 00:06:09.051
one of the last things I remember is
light is a pretty quick substance.

124
00:06:09.051 --> 00:06:10.480
>> [LAUGH] It is.

125
00:06:10.480 --> 00:06:13.590
>> I mean maybe even the quickest
substance as I recall.

126
00:06:13.590 --> 00:06:16.030
>> Yeah it's one of the fastest
things that we can deal with.

127
00:06:16.030 --> 00:06:19.560
>> So when we start talking about just
generally delivering data from one

128
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:24.090
point to the other, it is generally
accepted that light is going to be faster.

129
00:06:24.090 --> 00:06:28.530
So usually this is what everybody
would love to run in their homes.

130
00:06:28.530 --> 00:06:31.870
Think about it, If I actually had
a connection going to my home for

131
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:34.580
my ISP to come in where I
can get Internet access.

132
00:06:34.580 --> 00:06:36.627
Do I want fiber or
do I want a regular cable signal?

133
00:06:36.627 --> 00:06:40.560
Everybody on the planet will tell you no,
fiber optic is the way to go.

134
00:06:40.560 --> 00:06:44.890
You can transmit a lot more
on this type of cable and

135
00:06:44.890 --> 00:06:49.350
it also gives you a lot more speed
if everything is actually right.

136
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:54.110
So the comparison of both of these, these
are by far the two that you're gonna see

137
00:06:54.110 --> 00:06:56.760
the most often when you start
dealing with networking.

138
00:06:56.760 --> 00:07:00.030
Now when you're working with
regular computer workstations,

139
00:07:00.030 --> 00:07:01.750
this is probably the one
that you'll see more often.

140
00:07:01.750 --> 00:07:03.760
The reason why, it's more durable.

141
00:07:03.760 --> 00:07:04.360
Right?

142
00:07:04.360 --> 00:07:06.520
So, this is much more flexible.

143
00:07:06.520 --> 00:07:09.830
You can pull on it,
I'm not saying just yank it apart here.

144
00:07:09.830 --> 00:07:11.990
You can pull on it a little bit,
it actually moves around,

145
00:07:11.990 --> 00:07:13.260
it's fairly flexible.

146
00:07:13.260 --> 00:07:16.540
It allows us to actually be able to move
workstations around when we need to.

147
00:07:16.540 --> 00:07:19.820
Without really worrying about
the integrity of the wire too much.

148
00:07:19.820 --> 00:07:20.680
Now don't get me wrong,

149
00:07:20.680 --> 00:07:25.110
if you keep stomping the heel of your
cowboy boots on it, yes, it's gonna break.

150
00:07:25.110 --> 00:07:27.570
But even rolling a chair over it or

151
00:07:27.570 --> 00:07:32.560
so, it might kind of compromise a little
bit but not exactly the worst thing.

152
00:07:33.980 --> 00:07:36.510
Daniel, you roll a rolling chair
over this thing, it's gonna break.

153
00:07:36.510 --> 00:07:38.540
>> Yeah,
you're gonna buy a new one real quick.

154
00:07:38.540 --> 00:07:40.160
>> Yeah.
>> It's a delicate,

155
00:07:40.160 --> 00:07:41.860
delicate piece of equipment right there.

156
00:07:41.860 --> 00:07:43.650
>> And that's what we have to realize too.

157
00:07:43.650 --> 00:07:47.230
So a lot of these cables, and you probably
see I'm holding this one loosely.

158
00:07:47.230 --> 00:07:49.330
I didn't wrap it around like this guy,
right?

159
00:07:49.330 --> 00:07:50.830
Where you see it wrapped around like this.

160
00:07:50.830 --> 00:07:52.770
You notice I'm not doing
that with this thing here.

161
00:07:52.770 --> 00:07:58.336
And that's because this fiber inside,
the one that really does carry the data

162
00:07:58.336 --> 00:08:03.920
signal along it, It is thinner than
a human hair is what we're talking about.

163
00:08:03.920 --> 00:08:08.440
So, it's very easy to break, and so even
though you can wrap it around and they do

164
00:08:08.440 --> 00:08:12.420
put strengthening fibers around it, you
don't wanna be tying a knot in this thing.

165
00:08:12.420 --> 00:08:13.290
Go, okay, no big deal.

166
00:08:13.290 --> 00:08:16.190
You don't wanna crunch it and put into
your pocket or your back pocket and

167
00:08:16.190 --> 00:08:17.170
walk around with it.

168
00:08:17.170 --> 00:08:19.270
You do want to make
sure it's fairly loose.

169
00:08:19.270 --> 00:08:21.790
That it can actually hold
whatever shape it needs to.

170
00:08:21.790 --> 00:08:24.980
And this one is not really good and
designed for things like workstations and

171
00:08:24.980 --> 00:08:29.990
PCs and laptops, and the reason why is
because as you continue to move it around

172
00:08:29.990 --> 00:08:32.570
that's where you're going to start
damaging it, so normally where you see

173
00:08:32.570 --> 00:08:36.470
something like this is going to be
inside of a server closet somewhere.

174
00:08:36.470 --> 00:08:39.840
So you are working in a big organization
and they have that room locked up, and

175
00:08:39.840 --> 00:08:43.490
you go, man, what are all those little
tiny cables going between those devices?

176
00:08:43.490 --> 00:08:44.860
Lot of times it's gonna be right here,

177
00:08:44.860 --> 00:08:48.950
as a cable that looks like this
is what we're talking about.

178
00:08:48.950 --> 00:08:54.410
So just trying to distinguish them is
something that we really need to do too.

179
00:08:54.410 --> 00:08:58.880
Now, we can talk about other things as
well when we start dealing with this

180
00:08:58.880 --> 00:08:59.720
too, okay?

181
00:08:59.720 --> 00:09:02.380
So let's spend a little bit of time on
fiber optics as I'm still holding in my

182
00:09:02.380 --> 00:09:04.830
hand that's probably the easiest
one to think about here.

183
00:09:04.830 --> 00:09:09.710
So with the fiber optic cable, well even
though this cable is relatively short,

184
00:09:09.710 --> 00:09:14.950
I can send a fiber optic signal down these
cables, depending on their specifications,

185
00:09:14.950 --> 00:09:16.170
a good distance.

186
00:09:16.170 --> 00:09:17.370
Now when I say that,

187
00:09:17.370 --> 00:09:21.490
some of them are rated to carry
them up to hundreds of meters.

188
00:09:21.490 --> 00:09:23.680
Now, that's pretty good, right?

189
00:09:23.680 --> 00:09:25.450
That's 300 feet, maybe longer and stuff.

190
00:09:25.450 --> 00:09:27.400
So yeah, that's a pretty good distance.

191
00:09:27.400 --> 00:09:32.260
But some of them can actually be run to
miles, and even the longest specification

192
00:09:32.260 --> 00:09:39.000
for this thing can be run up to like 27,
28 miles long on a single run.

193
00:09:39.000 --> 00:09:39.590
Now, when you do that,

194
00:09:39.590 --> 00:09:42.390
that means that the light source
that we got is super powerful.

195
00:09:42.390 --> 00:09:46.130
So you heed that warning very well,
do not look directly at the laser.

196
00:09:46.130 --> 00:09:48.180
That one you don't even
wanna come close to look,

197
00:09:48.180 --> 00:09:50.740
it might burn a hole right to
your head if you did that.

198
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:54.120
But that's what you're looking at,

>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

645
00:33:23.570 --> 00:33:24.863
>> We'll see you next time.

646
00:33:24.863 --> 00:33:31.130
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don dissect a common computer network and explore the different elements that allow system to communicate. Don uses Wireshark to demonstrate the difference between regular network traffic and encrypted network traffic. He also shows how using a VPN can be used to encrypt traffic.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.636
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.636 --> 00:00:12.135
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:12.135 --> 00:00:15.330
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.330 --> 00:00:19.235
I'm your host Daniel Lowrey, joining me in
the studio today is none other than Mr.

5
00:00:19.235 --> 00:00:19.870
Don Pezet.

6
00:00:19.870 --> 00:00:21.090
How's it going today Don?

7
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:23.038
>> It is going great Daniel,
thanks for having me on the show.

8
00:00:23.038 --> 00:00:26.411
And I'm kind of excited to jump in here,
because this is the MTA for

9
00:00:26.411 --> 00:00:27.979
Network Infrastructure, and

10
00:00:27.979 --> 00:00:31.730
you guys know networking is one of my
kind of favorite topics to jump into.

11
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:35.250
And it's always neat to get in here and
talk about some of the basics and

12
00:00:35.250 --> 00:00:38.070
fundamentals that are so
important to understand.

13
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:40.560
Because everything else we learn
kind of builds on top of these.

14
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:45.030
We got a good show lined up covering
lots of networking stuff, it's exciting.

15
00:00:45.030 --> 00:00:48.150
>> Yeah without these networking
fundamentals you're not gonna get very far

16
00:00:48.150 --> 00:00:49.410
in your networking career.

17
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:51.120
So you're gonna see these a lot,

18
00:00:51.120 --> 00:00:54.280
even as you become ingrained
as a network administrator.

19
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:57.710
These are foundational knowledge
that you're gonna rely upon over and

20
00:00:57.710 --> 00:00:58.300
over and over again.

21
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:01.290
So it's great that Microsoft
calls these out on their exam.

22
00:01:01.290 --> 00:01:03.390
They wanna make sure that you
know that kind of stuff and

23
00:01:03.390 --> 00:01:04.530
Don you're gonna help us out today.

24
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:08.780
You're gonna kind of take us through some
of the infrastructure that is built in

25
00:01:08.780 --> 00:01:09.390
to networks.

26
00:01:09.390 --> 00:01:10.810
Correct?
>> Absolutely.

27
00:01:10.810 --> 00:01:12.280
Now, when we're dealing with networks,

28
00:01:12.280 --> 00:01:14.470
there's several different
types of networks out there.

29
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:17.450
There's a lot of terminology and
things that we need to be aware of.

30
00:01:17.450 --> 00:01:19.190
So lets start really high level.

31
00:01:19.190 --> 00:01:22.970
When I say a network,
what the heck am I talking about?

32
00:01:22.970 --> 00:01:25.620
Well, there's actually,
I'm gonna say four.

33
00:01:25.620 --> 00:01:27.510
There's four different types of networks.

34
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:30.700
There's actually any number of
networks that are out there, but

35
00:01:30.700 --> 00:01:33.100
according to Microsoft, there
are four that we need to be aware of.

36
00:01:33.100 --> 00:01:34.930
I guess that's a better way to look at it.

37
00:01:34.930 --> 00:01:36.970
The first network type that
they're talking about is

38
00:01:36.970 --> 00:01:38.260
what's called the Internet.

39
00:01:38.260 --> 00:01:41.830
The Internet is really important, and you
guys know that because if you're watching

40
00:01:41.830 --> 00:01:45.420
this video right now, the odds are that
you're watching it via the Internet.

41
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:46.395
>> We like the internet here.

42
00:01:46.395 --> 00:01:49.290
[LAUGH]
>> If the Internet didn't exist, we would,

43
00:01:49.290 --> 00:01:54.290
well, we'd either be out of business or
we'd be mailing DVDs to people, I guess.

44
00:01:54.290 --> 00:01:55.420
I don't know, something.

45
00:01:55.420 --> 00:01:58.870
But the Internet is the world's
largest network, right?

46
00:01:58.870 --> 00:02:03.290
It connects computers and
servers all over the planet to each other.

47
00:02:03.290 --> 00:02:05.961
There is no network
larger than the Internet.

48
00:02:05.961 --> 00:02:08.911
So when a lot of people say,
hey the network is down,

49
00:02:08.911 --> 00:02:11.730
they might be talking about
their own network, or

50
00:02:11.730 --> 00:02:16.041
they might be talking about this world
wide network, which is rarely down.

51
00:02:16.041 --> 00:02:19.382
So that is one example of a network,
Internet.

52
00:02:19.382 --> 00:02:24.430
But there's some similar terms that go
along with that, right, like an intranet.

53
00:02:24.430 --> 00:02:26.900
Well, what's an intranet?

54
00:02:26.900 --> 00:02:28.025
We've got Internet.

55
00:02:28.025 --> 00:02:32.560
Well, internet, if you break that term
apart right, inter, which comes from,

56
00:02:32.560 --> 00:02:37.290
I'll pretend to be smarter, the latin root
of, it'd be like the ESPN spelling bee,

57
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:37.968
and [LAUGH].

58
00:02:37.968 --> 00:02:41.775
So it means to go in between things,
right, but

59
00:02:41.775 --> 00:02:44.930
intra means to stay within something.

60
00:02:44.930 --> 00:02:49.590
So an intranet is a network
within your own organization.

61
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.820
And so there's many companies that
maintain their own network and

62
00:02:52.820 --> 00:02:56.810
have their own web servers that
are just for their own employees.

63
00:02:56.810 --> 00:02:58.645
Well Daniel you know, you and
I, we used to work for

64
00:02:58.645 --> 00:03:00.210
an insurance company years ago.

65
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:03.960
And we had an intranet
there that employees,

66
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:06.590
when you came into work in the morning,
that was the first place you went,

67
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:09.220
cuz company news, information,
it was all there.

68
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:11.569
You could not access
that from the Internet.

69
00:03:11.569 --> 00:03:14.996
>> Now there were great forums and
applications that people with inside of

70
00:03:14.996 --> 00:03:18.782
our business needed to access, and
we didn't want that to be public, right.

71
00:03:18.782 --> 00:03:23.074
That's not something that Joe on the
street needs to be diving into some sort

72
00:03:23.074 --> 00:03:25.100
of accounting information.

73
00:03:25.100 --> 00:03:28.200
We keep that internal, but they can
access it through their browser, and

74
00:03:28.200 --> 00:03:29.570
a lot of cool stuff like that.

75
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:31.160
That was our intranet.

76
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:34.975
It was internal to only our business,
and it works really well.

77
00:03:34.975 --> 00:03:35.860
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and

78
00:03:35.860 --> 00:03:38.600
you'll hear another name used for
that from time to time or

79
00:03:38.600 --> 00:03:43.580
even more often now, which is just a LAN,
a local area network.

80
00:03:43.580 --> 00:03:47.340
A local area network is a network
that's well, local to you.

81
00:03:47.340 --> 00:03:48.540
>> In your area.

82
00:03:48.540 --> 00:03:51.350
>> Yeah,
you have the word in its own definition.

83
00:03:51.350 --> 00:03:55.940
Basically another way to look at
it is the network that you own.

84
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:58.450
If you have more than one computer in
your network, like Daniel has a laptop.

85
00:03:58.450 --> 00:04:00.330
I've got a laptop and
we need them to talk.

86
00:04:00.330 --> 00:04:03.570
Well, we have wireless access points,
and switches,

87
00:04:03.570 --> 00:04:07.970
and network cables that we bought, that
our company owns that's private to us.

88
00:04:07.970 --> 00:04:09.930
That's our local area network.

89
00:04:09.930 --> 00:04:13.380
You could also call that our intranet,
because it's services and

90
00:04:13.380 --> 00:04:16.340
resources that are, again,
on our network that we control,

91
00:04:16.340 --> 00:04:19.150
that are private,
if we choose for them to be.

92
00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:23.960
But we access the Internet, which is
that public network that's out there.

93
00:04:23.960 --> 00:04:28.520
So, a intranet is often gonna be on
your LAN, your local area network.

94
00:04:28.520 --> 00:04:32.710
The Internet is considered a WAN or
wide area network.

95
00:04:32.710 --> 00:04:34.250
So this is where things
start to get confusing,

96
00:04:34.250 --> 00:04:37.380
cuz you have these kind of
interchangeable terms, right.

97
00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:39.420
But if you're gonna bring
up a web server and

98
00:04:39.420 --> 00:04:42.000
make it available to
the world on the Internet.

99
00:04:42.000 --> 00:04:43.640
Well, that's an Internet server, right?

100
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:44.361
It's public.

101
00:04:44.361 --> 00:04:46.296
But if you want it to be just private for

102
00:04:46.296 --> 00:04:50.239
your own people it's gonna be on your
LAN and that's your intranet, right?

103
00:04:50.239 --> 00:04:52.030
It's within your network.

104
00:04:52.030 --> 00:04:54.350
So those are a couple different terms.

105
00:04:54.350 --> 00:04:58.820
And then there's one more that
Microsoft calls out, which is extranet.

106
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:03.350
An extranet is one of those slightly
annoying terms because it's a hybrid.

107
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:07.150
It's kind of in between Internet and
intranet, right?

108
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:08.440
And you see these a lot.

109
00:05:08.440 --> 00:05:09.550
Let me give you an example.

110
00:05:10.810 --> 00:05:12.830
You know, really, your bank.

111
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:17.190
When you do online banking you
go to your bank's website and

112
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:21.290
ask you for your username and password, or
dual factor, multi-factor authentication,

113
00:05:21.290 --> 00:05:23.520
whatever it is to get into their website.

114
00:05:23.520 --> 00:05:26.590
And once you're in,
you're accessing resources.

115
00:05:26.590 --> 00:05:31.141
Now these are resources that you access
via the Internet, but they're private.

116
00:05:31.141 --> 00:05:32.047
Not just anybody can go,
I can't go to the website and

117
00:05:32.047 --> 00:05:32.686
view your account balance, right.

118
00:05:32.686 --> 00:05:36.493
Maybe you can.

119
00:05:36.493 --> 00:05:39.720
[LAUGH]
>> There are some people who [CROSSTALK]

120
00:05:39.720 --> 00:05:40.313
on that.

121
00:05:40.313 --> 00:05:44.820
The average person, the non law
breaker cannot access that resource.

122
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:50.425
So it's public, and yet it's private at
the same, and businesses do this a lot.

123
00:05:50.425 --> 00:05:54.045
They make resources available to other
business partners all right, and

124
00:05:54.045 --> 00:05:56.365
that's called an extranet.

125
00:05:56.365 --> 00:06:01.265
So an extranet kind of bridges the gap
in between an Internet and an intranet.

126
00:06:01.265 --> 00:06:03.245
Not every company has an extranet,

127
00:06:03.245 --> 00:06:07.185
not everybody needs one, but
plenty of places do and make use of it.

128
00:06:07.185 --> 00:06:11.690
So if it's a private site,
or private resource

129
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:16.340
that just happens to be available via
the Internet, that becomes an extranet.

130
00:06:16.340 --> 00:06:18.020
Right, bridging that gap.

131
00:06:18.020 --> 00:06:19.600
So, Internet is public.

132
00:06:20.650 --> 00:06:23.180
Intranet is private.

133
00:06:23.180 --> 00:06:25.912
Extranet is kind of in between.

134
00:06:25.912 --> 00:06:27.375
And then, you've got your WAN and
your LAN.

135
00:06:27.375 --> 00:06:31.508
Your wide area network, which is usually
Internet and your local area network,

136
00:06:31.508 --> 00:06:34.070
which is your internal,
your private network.

137
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:37.620
Now, I say the WAN, the wide area network,
is usually private.

138
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:38.970
It doesn't have to be.

139
00:06:38.970 --> 00:06:40.220
Really large organizations,

140
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:43.810
they might choose to purchase
connections between their locations.

141
00:06:43.810 --> 00:06:48.400
So, for example, if you're a bank,
and you've got bank branches all over,

142
00:06:48.400 --> 00:06:50.940
you could use the Internet to
connect your branches together, but

143
00:06:50.940 --> 00:06:53.260
the internet's not really trustworthy,
is it?

144
00:06:53.260 --> 00:06:57.020
So you might call up an internet
service provider, or AT&T, or

145
00:06:57.020 --> 00:07:02.640
somebody like that, and get private
lines run between your branches.

146
00:07:02.640 --> 00:07:04.500
And when you do that
they're not your lines.

147
00:07:04.500 --> 00:07:05.440
You don't own them.

148
00:07:05.440 --> 00:07:08.000
So it's not technically a LAN anymore,
right?

149
00:07:08.000 --> 00:07:11.910
It's a WAN, it's a world wide, a network
that spans between your locations.

150
00:07:11.910 --> 00:07:15.230
You rent that, or
you lease it from the phone company, and

151
00:07:15.230 --> 00:07:19.650
in those scenarios, what you're doing is,
you're creating a private WAN,

152
00:07:19.650 --> 00:07:22.710
a wide area network that's just for
your business.

153
00:07:22.710 --> 00:07:24.830
It kinda starts to blur the lines there,

154
00:07:24.830 --> 00:07:26.910
so that's why it's important
that we talk about it here.

155
00:07:26.910 --> 00:07:31.450
That's why Microsoft wants us to hit on
that, to make sure that everybody's got

156
00:07:31.450 --> 00:07:35.459
a good understanding of the difference
between Internet, intranet,

157
00:07:35.459 --> 00:07:36.884
extranet, WAN and LAN.

158
00:07:36.884 --> 00:07:39.079
Those five terms right there,
pretty important.

159
00:07:39.079 --> 00:07:41.291
>> Now, Don, that WAN business, you know,

160
00:07:41.291 --> 00:07:45.117
having those leased lines that
are private dedicated to me sounds great.

161
00:07:45.117 --> 00:07:48.096
It also sounds like it
might be very expensive.

162
00:07:48.096 --> 00:07:49.257
>> It certainly is right?

163
00:07:49.257 --> 00:07:52.218
So, when it comes to getting connectivity.

164
00:07:52.218 --> 00:07:54.542
And we're gonna talk about these in
another episode a little bit later.

165
00:07:54.542 --> 00:07:58.279
If you're at home and you wanna
get Internet access for your home,

166
00:07:58.279 --> 00:08:03.650
you can get things like cable, and DSL,
high speed, broadband, you can get those.

167
00:08:03.650 --> 00:08:05.584
And it's 50, 60 bucks a month.

168
00:08:05.584 --> 00:08:06.668
It's not terribly expensive.

169
00:08:06.668 --> 00:08:09.580
For those of you that are in Europe,
you have it even better than us.

170
00:08:09.580 --> 00:08:11.410
It'll be 20 euros a month.

171
00:08:11.410 --> 00:08:12.840
It's a lot less expensive.

172
00:08:12.840 --> 00:08:16.580
But even in either continent,

173
00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:20.740
if you wanna step up to one of these
dedicated lines, these lease lines,

174
00:08:20.740 --> 00:08:24.840
they're usually hundreds,
even thousands of dollars per month.

175
00:08:24.840 --> 00:08:26.510
They're not inexpensive.

176
00:08:26.510 --> 00:08:28.240
>> That's a little out of my price range,
Don.

177
00:08:28.240 --> 00:08:30.560
>> But then they're very reliable,
very stable,

178
00:08:30.560 --> 00:08:32.840
you can get a lot of bandwidth on them,
there's a lot of benefits.

179
00:08:32.840 --> 00:08:35.460
And they're really designed for
businesses, not designed for home users,

180
00:08:35.460 --> 00:08:39.130
because you don't need that
level of connectivity at home.

181
00:08:39.130 --> 00:08:42.000
So, those are some of the different
types of networks that are out there.

182
00:08:42.000 --> 00:08:47.340
Now, one of the things I mentioned
was that we could use the Internet

183
00:08:47.340 --> 00:08:49.930
to connect our offices instead
of doing a lease line, right?

184
00:08:49.930 --> 00:08:54.060
Daniel said lease lines are super mega
expensive, so I'm not gonna use that for

185
00:08:54.060 --> 00:08:54.740
my home.

186
00:08:54.740 --> 00:08:56.420
But for a business I might.

187
00:08:56.420 --> 00:08:58.240
But, what if I have a small business?

188
00:08:58.240 --> 00:08:59.880
And I'm not sitting on a ton of cash.

189
00:08:59.880 --> 00:09:03.130
And so, I wanna use the Internet,
but I want to use it safely.

190
00:09:03.130 --> 00:09:06.272
That's where we have
things like VPNs come in.

191
00:09:06.272 --> 00:09:09.437
A VPN is a virtual private network.

192
00:09:09.437 --> 00:09:14.295
And what a virtual private network does,
is instead of just taking your data and

193
00:09:14.295 --> 00:09:19.009
sending it out there to the Internet,
it takes your data and it encrypts it and

194
00:09:19.009 --> 00:09:21.560
it sends it across the Internet.

195
00:09:21.560 --> 00:09:23.790
And that way, if somebody were
to intercept it in transit,

196
00:09:23.790 --> 00:09:24.510
what are they gonna see?

197
00:09:24.510 --> 00:09:28.870
They're gonna see encrypted data,
it's just garbled mess and that's it.

198
00:09:28.870 --> 00:09:34.200
But, when it reaches the other end
of that tunnel, wherever it's going,

199
00:09:34.200 --> 00:09:38.070
the data gets decrypted and
you access that resource just fine.

200
00:09:38.070 --> 00:09:42.310
Virtual private networks are something
that we can lay on top of the Internet

201
00:09:42.310 --> 00:09:46.310
to turn it into an intranet or
a private LAN.

202
00:09:46.310 --> 00:09:49.360
We can start to get those advantages
without having to go out and

203
00:09:49.360 --> 00:09:51.330
lease a line from the phone company.

204
00:09:51.330 --> 00:09:53.660
So, you're starting to see less and
less of that.

205
00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:56.510
Less and less of people going and
leasing lines, and

206
00:09:56.510 --> 00:10:01.430
instead they're just using broadband,
DSL, internet connections that

207
00:10:01.430 --> 00:10:05.680
dump them right into the public Internet,
because they can use VPNs to secure it.

208
00:10:05.680 --> 00:10:10.440
Now, if you've never used a VPN before,
let me give you a quick demonstration so

209
00:10:10.440 --> 00:10:12.800
you kinda see what that's like, all right?

210
00:10:12.800 --> 00:10:17.490
So, I've got a machine set up here and
if I just fire up a web browser,

211
00:10:17.490 --> 00:10:22.380
I have a little webpage that is just
a quick kinda test page that I can use.

212
00:10:22.380 --> 00:10:23.303
All right.
And so

213
00:10:23.303 --> 00:10:28.437
I'm browsing here to
itpro.tv/test/index.html.

214
00:10:28.437 --> 00:10:31.450
And when I go to that website,
I'm just getting a test page, right?

215
00:10:31.450 --> 00:10:34.710
So it says test page,
this is a test page created by Don Pezet.

216
00:10:34.710 --> 00:10:37.200
Well when I did that,
I browsed out to the Internet, right?

217
00:10:37.200 --> 00:10:39.997
This server is out there on the Internet,
and

218
00:10:39.997 --> 00:10:43.979
I browsed to it and my data was
sent unencrypted on the Internet.

219
00:10:43.979 --> 00:10:48.175
If there's an attacker out there on
the Internet, they can intercept this, and

220
00:10:48.175 --> 00:10:51.520
they'll be able to read it because
it's in plain text, right?

221
00:10:51.520 --> 00:10:54.062
There's no protection on this.

222
00:10:54.062 --> 00:10:58.100
If I had a leased line, that went from my
building directly to wherever this web

223
00:10:58.100 --> 00:11:00.852
server is,
then I'd be the only person on that line,

224
00:11:00.852 --> 00:11:05.030
nobody would be able to intercept
that traffic, it would be safe.

225
00:11:05.030 --> 00:11:08.320
And so if you want the best security,
a leased line will give it to you.

226

There's TLS, the Transport Layer Security.

And actually my VPN I think is actually

00:18:18.770 --> 00:18:19.760

guest or public networks.

454
00:21:43.960 --> 00:21:46.860
And so it's filtering my traffic,
all right?

455
00:21:46.860 --> 00:21:48.920
Now, what is it doing?

456
00:21:48.920 --> 00:21:53.060
Well, if I go back to my start screen,
when I typed in firewall.

457
00:21:53.060 --> 00:21:53.945
I guess I have to spell it right.

458
00:21:53.945 --> 00:21:54.445
There we go.

459
00:21:54.445 --> 00:21:57.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> That the second thing was allow an app

460
00:21:57.110 --> 00:21:59.240
through the firewall,
check firewall status.

461
00:21:59.240 --> 00:22:01.940
But there's also,
if I search a little bit differently,

462
00:22:01.940 --> 00:22:06.170
if I search for Windows firewall with.

463
00:22:06.170 --> 00:22:09.250
You'll find the Windows firewall
with advanced security.

464
00:22:09.250 --> 00:22:11.350
It will turn up eventually.

465
00:22:11.350 --> 00:22:14.290
Well, actually we can get to
it from the other screen.

466
00:22:14.290 --> 00:22:16.380
It will turn up, I guess,
if I wait patiently and long enough.

467
00:22:16.380 --> 00:22:18.070
Did I spell it?
I must have spelled something wrong.

468
00:22:18.070 --> 00:22:20.860
All right, well, if I go back here,
right from this screen,

469
00:22:20.860 --> 00:22:23.450
you can just go to Advanced Settings,
and it'll take you to the same place.

470
00:22:23.450 --> 00:22:26.130
And, in your firewall
are basically a list of rules.

471
00:22:26.130 --> 00:22:28.930
Traffic that it will allow to
come into your computer, and

472
00:22:28.930 --> 00:22:30.780
traffic that it allows to
go out of your computer.

473
00:22:30.780 --> 00:22:33.600
So you have inbound and outbound rules.

474
00:22:33.600 --> 00:22:35.840
And these can get really specific,

475
00:22:35.840 --> 00:22:39.240
down to the individual port number,
what's allowed to pass.

476
00:22:39.240 --> 00:22:44.680
And Microsoft has set a lot of defaults up
in here that hopefully meet your needs but

477
00:22:44.680 --> 00:22:47.960
you might need to tweak to adjust to
allow some software to pass through or

478
00:22:47.960 --> 00:22:49.540
some software to be stopped.

479
00:22:49.540 --> 00:22:51.330
Based on what it is that you need.

480
00:22:51.330 --> 00:22:52.760
So there's a ton of rules in it.

481
00:22:52.760 --> 00:22:54.440
There's hundreds of rules in here,

482
00:22:54.440 --> 00:22:58.130
all dictating what's allowed to be
communicated through your systems.

483
00:22:58.130 --> 00:23:01.640
I definitely have to have Bing,
food, and drink communicating, so

484
00:23:01.640 --> 00:23:03.700
they've got that turned on for
me which is nice.

485
00:23:03.700 --> 00:23:07.090
But you'll see there's other things
that might be blocked or whatever.

486
00:23:07.090 --> 00:23:09.410
These are the default
that they've created.

487
00:23:09.410 --> 00:23:10.480
>> So in here we go in.

488
00:23:10.480 --> 00:23:11.820
If I need to open up a rule,

489
00:23:11.820 --> 00:23:15.300
I have a program that specifically
tries to access my computer.

490
00:23:15.300 --> 00:23:19.120
I'm getting some kind of denied message
usually or it's just not working.

491
00:23:19.120 --> 00:23:20.820
A lot of times the firewall
can be blocking it.

492
00:23:20.820 --> 00:23:22.920
That's a good thing that
means it's working.

493
00:23:22.920 --> 00:23:24.440
We need to go into those
advanced settings.

494
00:23:24.440 --> 00:23:27.500
Find out where we need to open or
close something out so

495
00:23:27.500 --> 00:23:29.242
that we can allow that
program to work correctly.

496
00:23:29.242 --> 00:23:33.220
>> Yep, and while I was on that firewall
screen, let me go back to that,

497
00:23:33.220 --> 00:23:36.300
you guys might have noticed this where
it says private networks and guest or

498
00:23:36.300 --> 00:23:37.380
public networks, all right?

499
00:23:37.380 --> 00:23:38.470
What's that all about?

500
00:23:38.470 --> 00:23:41.670
Well, in your firewall you have
what are called security zones.

501
00:23:41.670 --> 00:23:46.320
A zone is basically a network that
you either trust or you don't trust.

502
00:23:46.320 --> 00:23:50.510
If you trust the network you might
allow a lot of communications over it.

503
00:23:50.510 --> 00:23:53.880
But if you don't trust the network,
you wanna lock things down, so

504
00:23:53.880 --> 00:23:57.940
maybe on my laptop when I go home,
I wanna share folders and printers and

505
00:23:57.940 --> 00:24:01.120
let other people access them, but
when I go to the coffee shop and

506
00:24:01.120 --> 00:24:04.160
sit down and used their shared internet,
I don't wanna share my files and

507
00:24:04.160 --> 00:24:05.870
folders with anybody on that network.

508
00:24:05.870 --> 00:24:10.920
So I trust my home network, I don't
trust my coffee shop network, right?

509
00:24:10.920 --> 00:24:13.370
So these are security zones.

510
00:24:13.370 --> 00:24:17.360
Every time you plug into a new network,
it's going to ask us,

511
00:24:17.360 --> 00:24:20.680
is this a private network or
is this a public network?

512
00:24:20.680 --> 00:24:24.690
Is it your home or your work or
an untrusted network?

513
00:24:24.690 --> 00:24:28.070
It's asking us so
it knows what rules to apply.

514
00:24:28.070 --> 00:24:31.470
When I went into the advance settings and
pulled up that list of rules,

515
00:24:31.470 --> 00:24:34.570
you might have noticed how some
were grayed out, some were green.

516
00:24:35.700 --> 00:24:41.500
In the rules, you have a little section
where it tells you the profile.

517
00:24:41.500 --> 00:24:46.250
And some of the rules apply to all
profiles, some of the rules apply to

518
00:24:46.250 --> 00:24:51.400
private or public or domain, or all three,
and so you'll see mixtures there.

519
00:24:51.400 --> 00:24:54.630
And when you're on a private network,
one that's trusted, you'll allow

520
00:24:54.630 --> 00:24:58.480
a lot more access, than when you're on
a public network, which is not trusted.

521
00:24:58.480 --> 00:25:01.400
So you'll see those kind of
variations as you go through here.

522
00:25:01.400 --> 00:25:03.550
And there's just certain things that are
allowed and certain things that aren't,

523
00:25:03.550 --> 00:25:04.670
depending on that network.

524
00:25:05.820 --> 00:25:08.260
Well, Don, that's pretty cool
stuff to be able to say, hey,

525
00:25:08.260 --> 00:25:09.890
you know what,
I'm on a network I can trust.

526
00:25:09.890 --> 00:25:12.252
I know Don is not gonna
try to attack my computer.

527
00:25:12.252 --> 00:25:14.089
You're not gonna try to
attack my computer, right?

528
00:25:14.089 --> 00:25:16.445
>> Okay, yeah, there's Don Pezet for you.

529
00:25:16.445 --> 00:25:18.014
>> [LAUGH]
>> But no, in reality,

530
00:25:18.014 --> 00:25:20.874
if we're on the same network,
we're in a work environment,

531
00:25:20.874 --> 00:25:24.229
he needs to be able to trust my computer,
I need to be able to trust his, so

532
00:25:24.229 --> 00:25:25.830
we put it on that private network.

533
00:25:25.830 --> 00:25:28.910
It says, hey look, we know each other,
everything's fine.

534
00:25:28.910 --> 00:25:30.900
Go ahead and allow that more access.

535
00:25:30.900 --> 00:25:32.150
You're out in the public there.

536
00:25:32.150 --> 00:25:34.670
Like we said,
that Internet's the wild, wild west.

537
00:25:34.670 --> 00:25:36.570
You start getting out to
places you don't know,

538
00:25:36.570 --> 00:25:39.430
people you don't know and
they're all connecting together.

539
00:25:39.430 --> 00:25:42.580
You want to throw up a little bit more
shielding than you normally would

540
00:25:42.580 --> 00:25:45.650
inside of a nice trusted private network.

541
00:25:45.650 --> 00:25:48.420
So use your Windows firewall to do that.

542
00:25:48.420 --> 00:25:51.250
>> Absolutely, yeah, and it doesn't
hurt to have a hardware firewall also.

543
00:25:51.250 --> 00:25:52.340
You can use them in combination.

544
00:25:52.340 --> 00:25:53.280
It's a great solution.

545
00:25:53.280 --> 00:25:53.960
>> That's right.

546
00:25:53.960 --> 00:25:56.960
All right, Don, well we've covered a lot
of topics, I know we got some more stuff

547
00:25:56.960 --> 00:26:00.730
to do, but as for this episode,
do we need to cover anything else?

548
00:26:00.730 --> 00:26:03.220
No, we definitely have some other networks
topics we need to get to, but for

549
00:26:03.220 --> 00:26:04.790
this one, it's a good spot for
us to wrap this one up.

550
00:26:04.790 --> 00:26:05.700
>> All right.
Well everyone,

551
00:26:05.700 --> 00:26:07.010
thanks for watching the show today.

552
00:26:07.010 --> 00:26:08.170
We really appreciate that.

553
00:26:08.170 --> 00:26:11.490
Don, thanks for those demonstrations
always awesome, as usual.

554
00:26:11.490 --> 00:26:13.710
We're going go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

555
00:26:13.710 --> 00:26:15.730
I've been you host, Daniel Lowery.

556
00:26:15.730 --> 00:26:16.590
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

557
00:26:16.590 --> 00:26:23.620
>> And we'll see you next time.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don explain the difference between external and internal IP addresses and how a user can determine which one he or she is on. Don breaks down how a dial-up modem works as well as DSL. He also explains the difference between the various leased line options available. He finally shows how wireless network speeds stack up against each standard.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.845
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.845 --> 00:00:11.511
>> All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11.511 --> 00:00:14.630
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.630 --> 00:00:15.840
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:15.840 --> 00:00:19.550
Joining me today is none other than my
good friend, colleague Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:19.550 --> 00:00:20.810
How's it going today, Don?

7
00:00:20.810 --> 00:00:21.592
>> It is going great, Daniel.

8
00:00:21.592 --> 00:00:22.829
Glad to be back on the show and

9
00:00:22.829 --> 00:00:25.805
ready to continue talking about
some of our network fundamentals.

10
00:00:25.805 --> 00:00:26.400
>> Mm-hm.
>> Today,

11
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:29.020
we're gonna be looking at a pretty
important topic which is really just

12
00:00:29.020 --> 00:00:32.680
kind of comparing some of
the different elements inside of a LAN

13
00:00:32.680 --> 00:00:33.860
versus a WAN, right?

14
00:00:33.860 --> 00:00:35.970
A local area network versus
a wide area network.

15
00:00:35.970 --> 00:00:39.450
And let's just start with LANs,
local area network.

16
00:00:39.450 --> 00:00:40.600
And I know in the last episode,

17
00:00:40.600 --> 00:00:43.600
I mentioned how a LAN is
really a network that you own.

18
00:00:43.600 --> 00:00:47.960
That you own all the different pieces
of it, and it's all under your control.

19
00:00:47.960 --> 00:00:50.730
Versus a WAN, which is a network
that you typically rent,

20
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:54.950
that somebody else controls and
you gain access to it through them.

21
00:00:54.950 --> 00:00:56.730
That's kind of our different there.

22
00:00:56.730 --> 00:01:00.520
But, there's obviously a lot more to
it than just who's paying the bill.

23
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:05.280
So when we talk about a LAN, there's a lot
of different pieces that kind of fall into

24
00:01:05.280 --> 00:01:07.650
that, and it's most basic.

25
00:01:07.650 --> 00:01:09.440
We usually think it's just
a couple of devices cuz

26
00:01:09.440 --> 00:01:10.790
modern day networks are so simple.

27
00:01:10.790 --> 00:01:17.330
At my home, my LAN is a wireless
internet router and my laptop.

28
00:01:17.330 --> 00:01:18.890
Thats my local area network, right?

29
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:21.180
If you have other devices on the network
they may fall into that, right?

30
00:01:21.180 --> 00:01:23.900
What are some of the other things
we have at home, do you know?

31
00:01:23.900 --> 00:01:26.515
>> Oh, weve got tablets,
were got wired or

32
00:01:26.515 --> 00:01:31.575
wireless printers, things of that nature,
router or cable modem those as well.

33
00:01:31.575 --> 00:01:36.955
Anything that is basically attached to
each other inside of what we own right?

34
00:01:36.955 --> 00:01:41.630
Again, it boils to the actual devices
that we own that are connected together.

35
00:01:41.630 --> 00:01:45.520
>> Yeah, and more and more, we need
those devices to be connected, right?

36
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:47.300
So if you were to walk
into my house right now,

37
00:01:47.300 --> 00:01:50.730
I'm sure one of my kids is
watching Netflix on a Roku.

38
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:53.190
And that little box is
connected out to the Internet.

39
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:58.610
Or my wife is using her laptop, or
our network printer is doing an update.

40
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:00.150
They all reach out to the Internet,

41
00:02:00.150 --> 00:02:03.170
which starts to blur that
line between WAN and LAN.

42
00:02:03.170 --> 00:02:05.720
But on the LAN side,
the devices you have control over.

43
00:02:05.720 --> 00:02:07.040
You can do what you need to.

44
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:12.660
Now, you might have devices that are kind
of in between that local network and

45
00:02:12.660 --> 00:02:13.810
the remote side, right?

46
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:16.490
For example if you're a business,
you might have a web server.

47
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:18.770
And the web server is on your network.

48
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:22.400
So it's considered a land device, but
you're allowing people on the internet to

49
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:25.240
get to that server, and
that's dangerous, right?

50
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:27.220
Because people on the internet can
do all sorts of bad things, so

51
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:29.210
you don't want them coming
inside of your network.

52
00:02:29.210 --> 00:02:34.190
So oftentimes on our LAN, you might
have a special little area called a DMZ,

53
00:02:34.190 --> 00:02:36.270
which is short of demilitarized zone.

54
00:02:36.270 --> 00:02:39.710
It's basically like a quarantine zone,
where you put servers and

55
00:02:39.710 --> 00:02:43.460
other resources that you want
to expose to the Internet.

56
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:47.290
And that way if somebody breaks into those
servers, and they compromise your DMZ.

57
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:49.270
They're stuck in that little area, and

58
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:51.860
they can't get into the rest
of your local area network.

59
00:02:51.860 --> 00:02:53.610
So your local area network may have that.

60
00:02:53.610 --> 00:02:55.640
Now at a home,
you're not going to have that.

61
00:02:55.640 --> 00:02:56.970
I don't have that on my home.

62
00:02:56.970 --> 00:02:58.472
Daniel, do you use DMZ at your place?

63
00:02:58.472 --> 00:03:00.408
>> No, no DMZ's at my house.

64
00:03:00.408 --> 00:03:02.260
I'm standard network.

65
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:05.150
>> But if your a small business or
a large business, you may.

66
00:03:05.150 --> 00:03:07.810
And more and more people are going to
the Cloud for these type of things.

67
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:10.990
So you put your webserver on a Cloud
system, and it's not on your LAN anymore.

68
00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:13.120
So you may or
may not have that DMZ type of environment.

69
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:15.490
But, that is a kind of
special element that we find.

70
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:19.910
Now, one of the easiest ways to spot
whether you're on a local area network or

71
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:22.620
on the internet is your IP address.

72
00:03:22.620 --> 00:03:24.580
Now, I know we already had
the episode on IP addressing.

73
00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:27.760
Most of you guys have already seen that so
we don't need to rehash those too much.

74
00:03:27.760 --> 00:03:34.080
But remember that on a local area network,
you're going to be using private IPs.

75
00:03:34.080 --> 00:03:37.635
Now, IP addresses are controlled
by the IANA which is

76
00:03:37.635 --> 00:03:40.566
the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority.

77
00:03:40.566 --> 00:03:42.660
I had to cheat,
I've got their webpage pulled up here.

78
00:03:42.660 --> 00:03:45.540
If you have a board and
wanna learn it, it's IANA.org.

79
00:03:45.540 --> 00:03:48.570
These are the guys who control
addressing across the world.

80
00:03:48.570 --> 00:03:53.850
And most IP addresses are public addresses
that have to be registered with the IANA.

81
00:03:53.850 --> 00:03:57.370
Now, each continent is
controlled by different entity,

82
00:03:57.370 --> 00:04:01.080
and the IANA is the worldwide
body that governs all of them.

83
00:04:01.080 --> 00:04:04.770
So if I need addresses and I called
the IANA, they're not gonna help me.

84
00:04:04.770 --> 00:04:07.270
They're gonna refer me to the one for
North America.

85
00:04:07.270 --> 00:04:10.060
And here in North America,
we have the ARIN,

86
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:12.760
the American Registry for
Internet Numbers.

87
00:04:12.760 --> 00:04:15.950
And I can go to them and
get addresses for public networks,

88
00:04:15.950 --> 00:04:17.900
networks that are on the Internet.

89
00:04:17.900 --> 00:04:22.540
But if I'm on my local network,
there's private IPs that are available for

90
00:04:22.540 --> 00:04:23.440
us to use.

91
00:04:23.440 --> 00:04:27.540
There is an IEEE standard,
or it's an RFC actually.

92
00:04:27.540 --> 00:04:28.420
So there's RFC,

93
00:04:28.420 --> 00:04:33.460
RFC 1918 that defines certain IP
addresses to use on a local area network.

94
00:04:33.460 --> 00:04:39.010
And you are more than likely using these
on your own network at home or at work.

95
00:04:39.010 --> 00:04:40.620
These are very common.

96
00:04:40.620 --> 00:04:43.010
And it's because we don't have
to go out and register them, and

97
00:04:43.010 --> 00:04:44.830
they're not out there on the Internet and
all that.

98
00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:49.010
So you can recognize RFC
1919 addresses because

99
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:52.480
they always start with the same numbers.

100
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:57.670
So there's addresses that start with
10.something.something.something, right?

101
00:04:57.670 --> 00:05:02.000
So if I do an IP configure here and I see
my address, well it doesn't start with 10.

102
00:05:02.000 --> 00:05:03.920
But if you see 10.

103
00:05:03.920 --> 00:05:05.260
that's a private IP.

104
00:05:05.260 --> 00:05:07.400
You're more than likely on
a local area network or

105
00:05:07.400 --> 00:05:11.330
a misconfigured WAN, normally a LAN.

106
00:05:11.330 --> 00:05:15.710
There's also 172.16,
all the way through 172.31.

107
00:05:15.710 --> 00:05:19.340
Those are also private IPs, right?

108
00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:24.598
So if you see 172.16, 172.17,
172.18 all the way to 172.31.

109
00:05:24.598 --> 00:05:26.358
All right.

110
00:05:26.358 --> 00:05:30.190
And then, there's 192.168.

111
00:05:30.190 --> 00:05:34.630
If your address starts with 192.168,
that's the last of the private ranges and

112
00:05:34.630 --> 00:05:36.640
that means you're on a LAN.

113
00:05:36.640 --> 00:05:39.830
Those private ranges are not
allowed to talk on the Internet.

114
00:05:39.830 --> 00:05:44.260
If you go to the Internet with one of
these IPs, your data just gets dropped.

115
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:46.140
Your Internet service
provider won't allow it.

116
00:05:46.140 --> 00:05:49.870
So when we go to the Internet,
we typically change our IP in transit.

117
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:52.810
We use what's called
Network Address Translation, or NAT.

118
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:56.744
And it changes us, so
if I were to go out to a site like.

119
00:05:58.590 --> 00:06:00.551
We'll use good old IPmonkey.

120
00:06:00.551 --> 00:06:03.570
And if I go to IPmonkey,
it'll tell me what my IP address is.

121
00:06:03.570 --> 00:06:08.876
And I'll see that my IP address,
I just saw it, it was 192.168.something,

122
00:06:08.876 --> 00:06:12.970

00:06:12.970 --> 00:06:17.850
My router is sitting between my LAN and
the WAN, and it's changing my IP

00:06:17.850 --> 00:06:21.200
address in transit so that I'm allowed
to function out there on the internet.

125
00:06:21.200 --> 00:06:22.700
And that's important, right?

126
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:26.090
We need to be able to change those
addresses as we move through.

127
00:06:26.090 --> 00:06:30.900
Okay, so that's kinda the easy way
to identify if you're on a LAN.

128
00:06:30.900 --> 00:06:35.620
There's a lot of different things there,
but LANs can be a lot more complex.

129
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:41.630
On a lot of networks, like on mine here,
I'm on the 192.168.41 network.

00:06:41.630 --> 00:06:46.380
Anybody else here in the building that's
on the 192.168.41 network can see me.

131
00:06:46.380 --> 00:06:47.860
And I can see them.

132
00:06:47.860 --> 00:06:49.890
But what if I need more than one network?

133
00:06:49.890 --> 00:06:52.780
Well, you can deploy separate switches,
and separate routers and

134
00:06:52.780 --> 00:06:54.720

135
00:06:54.720 --> 00:06:59.321
Or, we could take one network and divide
it up into a what a lot of businesses and

136
00:06:59.321 --> 00:07:02.350
employers call VLANs or
virtual local area networks.

137
00:07:02.350 --> 00:07:06.880
Where you take one LAN, and you divide
it into multiple virtual networks.

138
00:07:06.880 --> 00:07:08.750
A lot of business switches support this.

139
00:07:08.750 --> 00:07:12.360
You might have a 48 port switch that
all your computers plug in to, and

140
00:07:12.360 --> 00:07:15.049

make it one network.

141
00:07:16.070 --> 00:07:18.080
And the next twelve ports make
them another network, and

142
00:07:18.080 --> 00:07:20.710
the, the third set of twelve ports,
you're a third network.

143
00:07:20.710 --> 00:07:22.640
And now, you divide up into
three separate networks.

144
00:07:22.640 --> 00:07:24.190
Now, why would I do that?

145
00:07:24.190 --> 00:07:26.220
Why would I want to separate those out?

146
00:07:26.220 --> 00:07:29.780
Well, I might have employees
with different levels of access.

147
00:07:29.780 --> 00:07:34.700
I might have executives who are moving
payroll data or something, and

148
00:07:34.700 --> 00:07:38.200
I don't other employees to have access to
that, so I start splitting my network up.

149
00:07:38.200 --> 00:07:41.950
So LANs can actually get a little
complexed if you want them to be.

150
00:07:41.950 --> 00:07:44.620
Most people, though, your local area
network is going to be fairly simple.

151
00:07:44.620 --> 00:07:47.390
>> Yeah, and then that's where
the subnet mask comes into play,

152
00:07:47.390 --> 00:07:49.730

153
00:07:49.730 --> 00:07:53.320
That way I know if Don is one VLAN,
I'm on a different one.

00:07:53.320 --> 00:07:54.892
How do I know if I'm on a different VLAN?

155
00:07:54.892 --> 00:07:58.224
Well, I look at his or
my IP address and see a sub-net mask.

156
00:07:58.224 --> 00:08:00.139
It tells me what network I'm on.

00:14:31.130 --> 00:14:32.930
With DSL,

Not much different, but

And what a DSLAM does is it grabs your

You can get some pretty

transition to a leased line.

00:16:51.597 --> 00:16:54.390
And we talked about leased
lines in the first episode.

350
00:16:54.390 --> 00:16:57.130
Let's take a look at those a little more.

351
00:16:57.130 --> 00:17:00.350
There's a number of different
types of leased lines, but

352
00:17:00.350 --> 00:17:04.000
the one that Microsoft
calls out are the DSOs.

353
00:17:04.000 --> 00:17:06.280
And they don't actually call them
DSOs in the exam objectives.

354
00:17:06.280 --> 00:17:09.820
In the exam objectives they call it T1,
E1, T3, E3.

355
00:17:11.170 --> 00:17:13.770
So let's talk a little bit about these.

356
00:17:13.770 --> 00:17:17.570
Before DSL and cable,
back in the dial-up days,

357
00:17:17.570 --> 00:17:21.350
I used to drool over the idea
of having one of these lines.

358
00:17:21.350 --> 00:17:25.392
These were amazing bandwidth at
a time when you couldn't get that.

359
00:17:25.392 --> 00:17:30.275
When 53K was your maximum, you could get
these leased lines that could do hundreds

360
00:17:30.275 --> 00:17:35.110
of megabits of data, and it was just
a dream to even think that was possible.

361
00:17:35.110 --> 00:17:37.610
In today's networks, it's a lot different.

362
00:17:37.610 --> 00:17:42.150
But for businesses, they still use these
because they have an equal upload and

363
00:17:42.150 --> 00:17:44.809
download speed, so
you get reliable bandwidth.

364
00:17:46.040 --> 00:17:52.550
Now the term T1 and E1, T3, E3, they're
referring to a couple of different things.

365
00:17:52.550 --> 00:17:58.080
First off, a leased line is typically
made up of 64 kilobit channels.

366
00:17:58.080 --> 00:18:02.620
So you'll have a channel which is
referred to as a DSL or DS0, and

367
00:18:02.620 --> 00:18:05.640
a DS0 is 64 kilobits.

368
00:18:05.640 --> 00:18:08.780
And when I buy a leased line,
you don't actually buy it outright,

369
00:18:08.780 --> 00:18:11.630
you lease it,
you rent it from a service provider.

370
00:18:11.630 --> 00:18:14.140
You're basically getting
a certain amount of channels.

371
00:18:14.140 --> 00:18:19.450
If you get a T1,
you're getting 24 of those DS0s.

372
00:18:19.450 --> 00:18:25.050
And if you get a T3,
you're getting 672 of those DS0s.

373
00:18:25.050 --> 00:18:29.553
And they're all bonded together,
so that T1 basically gives you 1.5

374
00:18:29.553 --> 00:18:34.130
megabit of data, and
that T3 gives you 44.77 megabit of data.

375
00:18:34.130 --> 00:18:37.520
So at 44 megabit, that's more than
my cable connection right now.

376
00:18:37.520 --> 00:18:41.736
But this is 44 megabit down and
44 megabit up.

377
00:18:41.736 --> 00:18:45.590
You get equal bandwidth and
it's dedicated to you.

378
00:18:45.590 --> 00:18:48.440
My cable connection,
I go to a cable company,

379
00:18:48.440 --> 00:18:52.570
the same one Daniel does, most likely,
and we're in a community.

380
00:18:52.570 --> 00:18:55.260
We share that bandwidth.

381
00:18:55.260 --> 00:18:57.814
So if my neighbor is running
bit torrents like crazy,

382
00:18:57.814 --> 00:19:00.770
that hurts my Internet
connection cuz it's shared.

383
00:19:00.770 --> 00:19:05.486
But on a leased line, that's dedicated
bandwidth, so businesses use these a lot.

384
00:19:05.486 --> 00:19:08.660
Now when they were created,
there was a little bit of a divide.

385
00:19:08.660 --> 00:19:12.124
Here in the United States we have an
organization that define this stuff, and

386
00:19:12.124 --> 00:19:14.112
they define T1s and T3s and how they work.

387
00:19:14.112 --> 00:19:16.640
They really define the DSOs too.

388
00:19:16.640 --> 00:19:20.556
In Europe they have a different
organization that manages that, and

389
00:19:20.556 --> 00:19:23.729
so they created a different
set of nomenclature, and so

390
00:19:23.729 --> 00:19:25.566
they created the E1s and E3s.

391
00:19:25.566 --> 00:19:28.443
The Ts, those are used here in
North America and in Japan,

392
00:19:28.443 --> 00:19:32.783
because the US actually set up most
of the phone infrastructure in Japan.

393
00:19:32.783 --> 00:19:37.315
But the Es, those are used in Europe and
in a lot of other Asian,

394
00:19:37.315 --> 00:19:41.061
even Australia, where European nations
helped to build those networks.

395
00:19:41.061 --> 00:19:45.760
So E1s and E3s, they're still using
those 64K DSOs under the hood.

396
00:19:45.760 --> 00:19:49.710
But an E1 is 2 megabit and E3 is 34
megabit because they have a different

397
00:19:49.710 --> 00:19:52.010
amount of channels inside of them.

398
00:19:52.010 --> 00:19:56.004
These lines are super reliable,
they're dedicated to you, and

399
00:19:56.004 --> 00:19:57.825
they're pretty expensive.

400
00:19:57.825 --> 00:19:59.090
They're pretty expensive.

401
00:20:01.410 --> 00:20:04.890
The price has come down on these things
a lot, but a T1 here in the United States,

402
00:20:04.890 --> 00:20:09.864
in my area at least, will usually run
you between $200 and $300 a month for

403
00:20:09.864 --> 00:20:11.060
1.5 megabit.

404
00:20:11.060 --> 00:20:13.549
Versus Daniel, do you know what
you're paying for 50 megabits?

405
00:20:13.549 --> 00:20:15.849
>> Yeah, I'm paying $67 a month.

406
00:20:15.849 --> 00:20:18.852
>> $67, so significantly less than the T1,

407
00:20:18.852 --> 00:20:22.090
but your upload speed is
maybe 1 megabit on that.

408
00:20:22.090 --> 00:20:23.100
>> [CROSSTALK] Yeah.

409
00:20:23.100 --> 00:20:25.024
>> So it doesn't necessarily equal
out what we can get with some

410
00:20:25.024 --> 00:20:25.713
of these other ones.

411
00:20:25.713 --> 00:20:28.305
A T3, on the other hand,
it can be several hundred,

412
00:20:28.305 --> 00:20:31.550
even several thousand dollars
a month to get that access.

413
00:20:31.550 --> 00:20:34.230
But if you're running a business,
that's what you need.

414
00:20:34.230 --> 00:20:36.403
Now this is slowly being replaced, too,

415
00:20:36.403 --> 00:20:39.269
because now we have something
called Metro Ethernet.

416
00:20:39.269 --> 00:20:43.119
And with Metro Ethernet what they do is
instead of running all of these DSOs,

417
00:20:43.119 --> 00:20:46.427
all of these different channels
to you through the phone system,

418
00:20:46.427 --> 00:20:50.460
instead they can just bury fiber optics
and run it right to your building.

419
00:20:50.460 --> 00:20:53.730
And they can give you a gig
of data on one fiber link.

420
00:20:54.930 --> 00:20:57.750
And if they do that,
it's not having to run a ton of DSOs,

421
00:20:57.750 --> 00:20:59.960
it's not using the phone system,
it's a separate network.

422
00:20:59.960 --> 00:21:02.340
And so Metro E is killing this off.

423
00:21:02.340 --> 00:21:04.289
So that's what we have here at the studio.

424
00:21:04.289 --> 00:21:05.915
I think we're at 80 megabit now.

425
00:21:05.915 --> 00:21:09.810
We have an 80 megabit
connection that's fiber optic.

426
00:21:09.810 --> 00:21:12.260
And I wanna say our bill is, oh, gee,

427
00:21:12.260 --> 00:21:16.620
I don't know, it's something
like $1,100 or $1,200 a month.

428
00:21:16.620 --> 00:21:18.740
Which I know that sounds a like a lot for
a home user, but

429
00:21:18.740 --> 00:21:22.050
for a business considering how we use it,
80 megabit.

430
00:21:22.050 --> 00:21:26.310
I couldn't get a T3 for $1,200 a month,
not here in Gainesville.

431
00:21:26.310 --> 00:21:28.710
Maybe in other cities I might be
able to get one, but not here.

432
00:21:28.710 --> 00:21:33.180
So we get this fiber optic connection, and
if I wanna bump up the bandwidth on that

433
00:21:33.180 --> 00:21:35.550
fiber optic connection,
I can just call our service provider and

434
00:21:35.550 --> 00:21:37.970
they can dial it up right there,
they don't have to run new cable.

435
00:21:37.970 --> 00:21:40.448
But if I get a T3 and
I wanna move its bandwidth up,

436
00:21:40.448 --> 00:21:43.171
I've gotta order another T3 and
bond them together.

437
00:21:43.171 --> 00:21:46.510
And then I gotta keep
adding more DSOs to it.

438
00:21:46.510 --> 00:21:50.370
That's actual cable that has to be run,
and that gets expensive too.

439
00:21:50.370 --> 00:21:53.290
So these lines are becoming less and
less common.

440
00:21:54.560 --> 00:21:56.540
There's other types of
connectivity out there.

441
00:21:56.540 --> 00:22:01.020
Microsoft just hit on those, but
there's things like Frame Relay, MPLS,

442
00:22:01.020 --> 00:22:03.640
ATM, satellite Internet.

443
00:22:03.640 --> 00:22:06.160
There's a lot of other
technologies that are out there.

444
00:22:06.160 --> 00:22:07.120
It just depends on your area.

00:22:08.390 --> 00:22:10.320
You might find that in your area,

00:22:10.320 --> 00:22:11.840
a certain type of connection
is not available.

00:22:11.840 --> 00:22:14.170
So for example, the fiber optic stuff.

Fiber optic connectivity is available here

00:22:17.780 --> 00:22:18.810
I don't know,

00:22:18.810 --> 00:22:23.775

00:22:23.775 --> 00:22:25.095
It's not available.

452
00:22:25.095 --> 00:22:28.105
So it's not always available in your
area and you've got to call around and

453
00:22:28.105 --> 00:22:29.585
see what your options are.

454
00:22:29.585 --> 00:22:32.005
The same thing goes with cable and DSL.

455
00:22:32.005 --> 00:22:35.457
We have another host,
you guys have met him, Ronnie Wong.

That's the only thing

00:22:43.767 --> 00:22:47.108

00:23:11.350 --> 00:23:14.593
But different regions,
different availability, so

00:23:14.593 --> 00:23:16.501
it definitely impacts things.

472
00:23:16.501 --> 00:23:17.006
All right,

473
00:23:17.006 --> 00:23:20.260
now there are some places that will

Think about your cell phones,
where you might have LTE or

475
00:23:24.480 --> 00:23:28.540
3G type communications on it, and
you can gain Internet access that way.

476
00:23:28.540 --> 00:23:29.940
Again, availability is a problem.

477
00:23:29.940 --> 00:23:31.670
You don't have cell
phone towers everywhere,

478
00:23:31.670 --> 00:23:34.610
and those usually have a data cap on them.

479
00:23:34.610 --> 00:23:36.340
So you want to be careful there.

480
00:23:36.340 --> 00:23:40.200
Some connections have a data cap, and
for a home user that might be fine.

481
00:23:40.200 --> 00:23:42.700
For a business, though,
it oftentimes isn't.

00:23:42.700 --> 00:23:44.550
That's another advantage

00:23:44.550 --> 00:23:47.840
The leased lines are more expensive,

It's your line,
that bandwidth is dedicated to you.

00:23:50.070 --> 00:23:52.817
You can use all of it 24 hours a day,

00:23:52.817 --> 00:23:56.090
You can move terabytes of data,
and it's no big deal.

487
00:23:56.090 --> 00:23:57.255
It's your line and you use it.

00:23:57.255 --> 00:24:00.217
So there's pros and
cons with each of these connections.

00:24:00.217 --> 00:24:02.589
Just be aware there's
a lot of choice out there.

320.

00:25:53.540 --> 00:25:54.570
>> Okay.
>> I mentioned wireless.

538
00:25:54.570 --> 00:25:58.580
Now, I said how we're not typically

539
00:25:58.580 --> 00:26:01.650
on the LAN side, the Local Area Network
>> We eat it up.

540
00:26:01.650 --> 00:26:02.480
>> We do, right?

541
00:26:02.480 --> 00:26:03.400
Most people do that.

542
00:26:03.400 --> 00:26:04.900
If you're setting up a network for
your home or

543
00:26:04.900 --> 00:26:09.350
small office, usually you get an internet
connection in, that cable or DSL, and

544
00:26:09.350 --> 00:26:12.890
you plug it right into a wireless router
and that's the last cable you run, right?

545
00:26:12.890 --> 00:26:17.270
The biggest convenience for
a wireless network is not having cables.

546
00:26:17.270 --> 00:26:21.120
So, if you take a house like my house,
my house has a little bit of an A-frame

547
00:26:21.120 --> 00:26:24.350
in the middle and I can't run
cable from one side to the other.

548
00:26:24.350 --> 00:26:26.060
I can run cable on one side of the house.

549
00:26:26.060 --> 00:26:28.850
Or I can run cable on the other side,
but I can't get it to cross in between.

550
00:26:28.850 --> 00:26:32.370
So running a wireless network saves
me from having to run those cables.

551
00:26:32.370 --> 00:26:35.920
That's a really big kind of shining
point for wireless networks.

552
00:26:35.920 --> 00:26:37.970
But it's not all sunshine and rainbows.

553
00:26:37.970 --> 00:26:39.750
When we run a wireless network,

00:26:39.750 --> 00:26:43.710
there's certain negatives that jump
in that can kind of offset that.

555
00:26:43.710 --> 00:26:46.390
The biggest network I mentioned
earlier was reliability, right?

556
00:26:46.390 --> 00:26:50.590
If you have a lot of walls or things or
reflective surfaces, those can all impact

557
00:26:50.590 --> 00:26:54.610
your wireless communications, and that's
something we've gotta keep an eye out for.

558
00:26:54.610 --> 00:26:56.920
But the other part is security, right?

559
00:26:56.920 --> 00:26:59.630
When you're on a wired network, for
somebody to intercept your data,

560
00:26:59.630 --> 00:27:01.950
they'd have to plug into
your wired network.

561
00:27:01.950 --> 00:27:05.470
But on a wireless network, they can sit
outside your house, in your driveway, in

562
00:27:05.470 --> 00:27:09.920
the parking lot out of your building, and
intercept those wireless communications.

563
00:27:09.920 --> 00:27:13.967
So if we decide to deploy a wireless
network, there's a few decisions that we

564
00:27:13.967 --> 00:27:17.951
have to make and one of the big ones is
going to be what type of wireless network

565
00:27:17.951 --> 00:27:22.155
standard we want to use, and what type of
security we want to use on the network.
