575
00:27:48.830 --> 00:27:51.480
And so, let me pull up a little
chart that I made before the show.

576
00:27:51.480 --> 00:27:52.720
So, I've got it right here.

577
00:27:52.720 --> 00:27:55.540
If you go to the store to buy
a wireless router right now,

578
00:27:55.540 --> 00:28:00.860
you're going to see 802.11a,
b, g, n and ac.

579
00:28:00.860 --> 00:28:04.406
AC is not on the exam but
just so you're aware.

580
00:28:04.406 --> 00:28:09.150
802.11g is probably the most affordable
right now, 802.11n is probably

581
00:28:09.150 --> 00:28:13.620
the fastest that easily affordable,
AC is still pretty expensive.

582
00:28:13.620 --> 00:28:16.620
But each one is viable,
you can still run all of them.

583
00:28:16.620 --> 00:28:18.290
But each one has different pros and cons.

584
00:28:18.290 --> 00:28:18.900
All right?

585
00:28:18.900 --> 00:28:22.250
The first thing they pay attention
to are the frequencies, right?

586
00:28:22.250 --> 00:28:27.908
Five gigahertz standards have
a higher speed but a shorter range.

587
00:28:27.908 --> 00:28:33.840
And then 2.4 gigahertz frequencies
have a lower speed but a larger range.

588
00:28:33.840 --> 00:28:36.330
So if you wanna get a further distance,

589
00:28:36.330 --> 00:28:41.090
if you wanna have better penetration
through walls, 2.4 gigahertz is your guy.

590
00:28:41.090 --> 00:28:44.480
But if you want higher speed,
five gigahertz is your guy.

591
00:28:44.480 --> 00:28:48.160
But the further you get from that access
point, the weaker your signal gets and

592
00:28:48.160 --> 00:28:49.750
it doesn't go as far.

593
00:28:49.750 --> 00:28:55.000
So notice how like 802.11a is 54 megabit
and it can go up to 75 feet indoors.

594
00:28:55.000 --> 00:28:59.140
And 802.11b is 11 megabit, but
it can go up to 150 ft indoors.

595
00:28:59.140 --> 00:29:02.320
It goes further because of
the lower frequency signal.

596
00:29:02.320 --> 00:29:04.110
That's a choice we have to make.

597
00:29:04.110 --> 00:29:07.909
Now when you start to get into the higher
standards like 802.11g, which is what

598
00:29:07.909 --> 00:29:12.025
Daniel's running, it's what I'm running at
home, notice that it does 54 megabit, and

599
00:29:12.025 --> 00:29:14.636
it's five gigahertz, but
it gets that longer distance.

600
00:29:14.636 --> 00:29:16.587
Okay now how does it do that?

601
00:29:16.587 --> 00:29:22.020
Well 802.11g actually runs at both 2.4 and
5 gigahertz.

602
00:29:22.020 --> 00:29:26.110
So, it's backwards compatible with
802.11b and you can get further and

603
00:29:26.110 --> 00:29:29.840
you can flip between the signals
to get that greater distance.

604
00:29:29.840 --> 00:29:33.250
But to get the true 54 megabit,
you still have to be close.

605
00:29:33.250 --> 00:29:36.400
And so, you don't really find 802.11a and
b on sale any more.

606
00:29:36.400 --> 00:29:38.800
Right, they've really kinda
moved away from those and

607
00:29:38.800 --> 00:29:40.460
G has kind of become the standard.

608
00:29:40.460 --> 00:29:42.038
It's what you see in the most locations.

609
00:29:42.038 --> 00:29:48.790
But 802.11n, that one's newer,
and boy is it a jump, right?

610
00:29:48.790 --> 00:29:50.250
From 54 megabit up to 600 megabit.

611
00:29:50.250 --> 00:29:53.300
Now in real life, you're probably
gonna get closer to 200 megabit.

612
00:29:53.300 --> 00:29:55.230
You're not usually gonna
get all the way to 600.

613
00:29:55.230 --> 00:29:57.080
But under perfect conditions,

614
00:29:57.080 --> 00:29:59.720
you can get 600 megabit out of it,
and really good distance.

615
00:29:59.720 --> 00:30:04.370
And it is also combining 2.4 and
5 gigahertz to do that.

616
00:30:04.370 --> 00:30:08.110
So, when we go to look at a standard,
which one of these we wanna pick,

617
00:30:08.110 --> 00:30:10.330
usually it's just the fasted
one we can afford, right?

618
00:30:10.330 --> 00:30:12.720
You look at your price point,
you get the fastest one you can do,

619
00:30:12.720 --> 00:30:14.740
but there's other things.

620
00:30:14.740 --> 00:30:17.983
For example, I used to have
a microwave oven that really

621
00:30:17.983 --> 00:30:22.250
interfered with the 2.4 gigahertz network,
that spectrum.

622
00:30:22.250 --> 00:30:23.870
And so I had a choice.

623
00:30:23.870 --> 00:30:26.510
Either get a new microwave, or
when I bought wireless equipment,

624
00:30:26.510 --> 00:30:28.270
get wireless equipment that
could run on five gigahertz.

625
00:30:28.270 --> 00:30:29.590
That's exactly what I did.

626
00:30:29.590 --> 00:30:33.140
Or you might have cordless phones,
or a baby monitor, or

627
00:30:33.140 --> 00:30:35.690
something like that that interferes,
so you wanna make sure that you choose

628
00:30:35.690 --> 00:30:39.880
the wireless technology that's right for
the equipment that you've got.

629
00:30:39.880 --> 00:30:42.230
And then you might have
speed requirements and so

630
00:30:42.230 --> 00:30:44.650
you need to choose the one
that's right for speed.

631
00:30:44.650 --> 00:30:47.110
But after that once you've got it,

632
00:30:47.110 --> 00:30:49.430
there's really not any
difference other than the speed.

633
00:30:49.430 --> 00:30:53.640
You just connect and it's all the same
to you once your connected and working.

634
00:30:53.640 --> 00:30:55.110
So, pay attention to the speed,

635
00:30:55.110 --> 00:30:57.840
pay attention to the distance,
choose appropriately.

636
00:30:57.840 --> 00:31:02.660
>> Now when it comes to wireless, Don,
the big topic is the security, right?

637
00:31:02.660 --> 00:31:07.660
We've all heard the horror stories of
all this encryption's been cracked or

638
00:31:07.660 --> 00:31:11.860
some big entity had a wireless
access point open and

639
00:31:11.860 --> 00:31:15.505
someone got into it, and credit cards
were stolen and all sorts of stuff.

640
00:31:15.505 --> 00:31:17.025
So we have to implement the security.

641
00:31:17.025 --> 00:31:19.325
There's a few types of
security we have available.

642
00:31:19.325 --> 00:31:20.825
Why don't you help us out?

643
00:31:20.825 --> 00:31:22.245
Run us through what we have.

644
00:31:22.245 --> 00:31:24.005
>> All right, so
there's three main types of security.

645
00:31:24.005 --> 00:31:29.195
There's WEP, WPA, and WPA-2, and
most wireless networks should be secured.

646
00:31:29.195 --> 00:31:30.925
In fact,
let me show you here in Windows 8.

647
00:31:30.925 --> 00:31:32.305
So on my Windows 8 machine,

648
00:31:32.305 --> 00:31:36.430
if I wanna connect to a wireless network,
when I pull up my network screen,

649
00:31:36.430 --> 00:31:39.320
it's gonna show me my physical
networks and then my Wi-Fi networks.

650
00:31:39.320 --> 00:31:40.990
And so, I got a couple of
networks listed right here.

651
00:31:40.990 --> 00:31:43.020
And if I scroll down,
I got a few at the bottom.

652
00:31:43.020 --> 00:31:46.050
And see how they have that shield
on them with the exclamation point?

653
00:31:46.050 --> 00:31:48.504
That's telling me these
are un-encrypted networks.

654
00:31:48.504 --> 00:31:49.770
They're non-secure.

655
00:31:49.770 --> 00:31:51.290
If I connect on that,

656
00:31:51.290 --> 00:31:56.170
anybody with a wireless antenna within
100 feet will be able to intercept that.

657
00:31:56.170 --> 00:31:58.657
Well, I've got an exterior
wall 10 feet behind me.

658
00:31:58.657 --> 00:32:00.974
And that means somebody could be
in a car in the parking lot and

659
00:32:00.974 --> 00:32:02.624
they could intercept my communications.

660
00:32:02.624 --> 00:32:03.425
That's bad.

661
00:32:03.425 --> 00:32:07.638
So Windows is warning me not to use
these networks because they're not safe.

662
00:32:07.638 --> 00:32:09.661
But if you go to a coffee shop or
an airport and

663
00:32:09.661 --> 00:32:13.719
they're making public Wi-Fi available,
they're going to use unencrypted networks

664
00:32:13.719 --> 00:32:18.220
like that because it's the only way they
can allow strangers to connect and use it.

665
00:32:18.220 --> 00:32:21.460
But on your private network, like my
ITProTV network, there's no shield.

666
00:32:21.460 --> 00:32:24.660
And that actually means that
I am encrypted, all right.

667
00:32:24.660 --> 00:32:27.480
Now the three encryption standards,
WEP was the original one.

668
00:32:27.480 --> 00:32:30.130
It stands for Wired Equivalent Protocol.

669
00:32:30.130 --> 00:32:32.610
It was supposed to give,
or, no that's right.

670
00:32:32.610 --> 00:32:36.310
It's supposed to give you the same
level of security as if you were wired.

671
00:32:36.310 --> 00:32:39.500
Unfortunately, the encryption was
broken within a year of its release.

672
00:32:39.500 --> 00:32:43.450
So this was back in 1999, so
it's considered completely insecure now.

673
00:32:43.450 --> 00:32:47.830
It takes a hacker about two minutes
to break in and decrypt your data and

674
00:32:47.830 --> 00:32:49.030
it's not safe anymore..

675
00:32:49.030 --> 00:32:53.330
So you shouldn't see WEP on your
network anymore, all right.

676
00:32:53.330 --> 00:32:58.218
WPA, which is WiFi Protected Access
was released later on, okay,

677
00:32:58.218 --> 00:33:02.696
or wireless protected access and
WPA has improved security.

678
00:33:02.696 --> 00:33:07.468
It's switched to using a security
encryption protocol called TKIP that

679
00:33:07.468 --> 00:33:10.220
gave you a stronger level of encryption.

680
00:33:10.220 --> 00:33:14.360
And that was good for a little while,
but there was a theoretical paper that

681
00:33:14.360 --> 00:33:18.900
was put out, again within a year, that
showed how it was possible to break it.

682
00:33:18.900 --> 00:33:22.760
And so before it was broken,
they released WPA2.

683
00:33:22.760 --> 00:33:26.564
And so on every modern system that's
out there, if you're running wireless,

684
00:33:26.564 --> 00:33:27.995
you should be running WPA2.

685
00:33:27.995 --> 00:33:34.480
All right, WPA2 switched to another
encryption algorithm called AESCCMP.

686
00:33:34.480 --> 00:33:38.070
And it is a strong encryption
that has not yet been broken.

687
00:33:38.070 --> 00:33:40.260
All right?
There's some working theories out there,

688
00:33:40.260 --> 00:33:42.760
but nobody's been able to
practically exploit it yet.

689
00:33:42.760 --> 00:33:47.680
So, WPA-2 is safe, it's secure and
when you configure your wireless access

690
00:33:47.680 --> 00:33:49.900
devices, you need to make sure
that's what they're using.

691
00:33:49.900 --> 00:33:52.930
Now, it's not done on the client,
it's done on the router.

692
00:33:52.930 --> 00:33:54.620
Right?
Or the access point.

693
00:33:54.620 --> 00:33:58.341
You go to the wireless access point or
wireless router if that's what you have

694
00:33:58.341 --> 00:34:01.160
and when it asks you to pick
your security, choose WPA2.

695
00:34:01.160 --> 00:34:02.540
That's the one that's the most secure.

696
00:34:02.540 --> 00:34:04.040
That's the one you want to use.

697
00:34:04.040 --> 00:34:06.890
>> You can also connect
two computers together.

698
00:34:06.890 --> 00:34:10.740
And I think they call it ad hoc, but
it's really like a peer to peer network.

699
00:34:10.740 --> 00:34:13.885
>> Yeah, normally you have an access
point, a router that's running wireless or

700
00:34:13.885 --> 00:34:15.215
a dedicated access point.

701
00:34:15.215 --> 00:34:17.295
And that's what's called
infrastructure mode, right.

702
00:34:17.295 --> 00:34:19.755
Your connecting to hardware,
infrastructure.

703
00:34:19.755 --> 00:34:21.785
But if I just wanted to share
a file with your laptop,

704
00:34:21.785 --> 00:34:25.386
Daniel I could build what's called an ad
hoc network, just wireless in-between us.

705
00:34:25.386 --> 00:34:26.260
and communicate it.

706
00:34:26.260 --> 00:34:28.830
And when you do an ad
hoc network like that,

707
00:34:28.830 --> 00:34:30.930
it is up to you to choose that standard.

708
00:34:30.930 --> 00:34:33.650
And so, in Windows, it's got a little
wizard you can run through for

709
00:34:33.650 --> 00:34:36.590
exchanging those files and it will make
sure that it sets that up for you and

710
00:34:36.590 --> 00:34:37.340
you use the right standard.

711
00:34:37.340 --> 00:34:41.910
But just be aware, when you use wireless,
your data is at risk, right?

712
00:34:41.910 --> 00:34:45.290
And there's other devices out there,
like Wi-Fi Bridges.

713
00:34:45.290 --> 00:34:48.570
If you have a device that doesn't support
wireless, like I might have a printer

714
00:34:48.570 --> 00:34:50.930
that has a physical network jack on it,
but no wireless.

715
00:34:50.930 --> 00:34:53.070
You can get a wireless bridge and
stick it on the back of it,

716
00:34:53.070 --> 00:34:57.140
and it'll take its physical network card
and translate it over to the wireless.

717
00:34:57.140 --> 00:35:00.270
So you can make any device
wireless if you want.

718
00:35:00.270 --> 00:35:04.940
Just be aware of the security risks,
and make sure you handle that securely.

719
00:35:04.940 --> 00:35:09.060
And we typically only see those
wireless networks used on LANs,

720
00:35:09.060 --> 00:35:12.440
not on WANs, because on wide area
networks, it just doesn't have the range.

721
00:35:12.440 --> 00:35:16.897
You can't make a wide are network with an
antenna that's only going 300 feet, right?

722
00:35:16.897 --> 00:35:20.240
They need the stuff that goes miles,
like the cell phone antennas.

723
00:35:20.240 --> 00:35:23.780
And they do, the LTE networks, the 3G and

724
00:35:23.780 --> 00:35:28.640
4G communications, those guys,
they can go miles at very high speeds, but

725
00:35:28.640 --> 00:35:30.700
that's not a service that we
can set up ourselves right?

726
00:35:30.700 --> 00:35:34.300
We buy that from the cell phone provider
or whoever and we use that for our access.

727
00:35:34.300 --> 00:35:37.730
>> All right, well good stuff on wireless
here, obviously if you're gonna implement,

728
00:35:37.730 --> 00:35:41.880
that which you most likely are, make sure
you follow the best security practices,

729
00:35:41.880 --> 00:35:42.830
use that WPA2.

730
00:35:42.830 --> 00:35:46.280
I know it sounds scary,
oh I don't know which one to use.

731
00:35:46.280 --> 00:35:49.310
Now hopefully you should know
exactly which one to use.

732
00:35:49.310 --> 00:35:50.700
It's not very difficult to set up.

733
00:35:50.700 --> 00:35:53.760
You get into your wireless router and
you walk through a wizard.

734
00:35:53.760 --> 00:35:55.230
It's very, very simple.

735
00:35:55.230 --> 00:35:58.010
All right, Don, is there anything
else we need to talk about before we

736
00:35:58.010 --> 00:35:59.010
close the show?

737
00:35:59.010 --> 00:36:00.910
>> I think it's a pretty good
spot to wrap this one up.

738
00:36:00.910 --> 00:36:03.540
I do have a little bit more I wanna
talk about on network topologies,

739
00:36:03.540 --> 00:36:05.300
but we can hold that for Part 3.

740
00:36:05.300 --> 00:36:07.090
>> All right, well part three it is.

741
00:36:07.090 --> 00:36:08.020
Hopefully we'll see you there.

742
00:36:08.020 --> 00:36:10.150
As for this show,
we're gonna go and close it down.

743
00:36:10.150 --> 00:36:13.260
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

744
00:36:13.260 --> 00:36:13.870
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

745
00:36:13.870 --> 00:36:17.116
>> And we'll see you next time.

746
00:36:17.116 --> 00:36:21.120
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don compare the various network topologies available. He begins by explaining the legacy type topologies such as physical bus and physical ring. He then moves on to star and hybrid topologies. Don finishes the episode by explaining how collisions work and different methods used to mitigate them.
episodes.title: Network Infrastructure Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.670
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.670 --> 00:00:15.341
All right, greetings everyone, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.341 --> 00:00:16.601
I'm your host, Daniel Lowery.

4
00:00:16.601 --> 00:00:19.893
Joining me yet again today is
my good friend, Mr. Don Pizet.

5
00:00:19.893 --> 00:00:20.849
How's it going Don?

6
00:00:20.849 --> 00:00:21.782
>> It is going great, Daniel.

7
00:00:21.782 --> 00:00:26.901
Glad to be back on the show and here to
wrap up our network infrastructure series.

8
00:00:26.901 --> 00:00:29.179
We've got a little bit to
talk about on this one.

9
00:00:29.179 --> 00:00:33.870
We're gonna start off by talking
about network topologies, okay.

10
00:00:33.870 --> 00:00:38.350
And when I say network topology what I'm
talking about is how your network is

11
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:39.610
actually laid out.

12
00:00:39.610 --> 00:00:41.670
Think of it as like a roadmap.

13
00:00:41.670 --> 00:00:44.055
When you look at a road map,
you see all these roads and

14
00:00:44.055 --> 00:00:45.971
how they can get you
from point a to point b.

15
00:00:45.971 --> 00:00:48.246
Your network topology is the same thing.

16
00:00:48.246 --> 00:00:51.960
Now a lot of us connect to the Internet,
and when you're plugged in the Internet

17
00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:56.080
the network topology is insanely complex,
but fortunately we don't have to run that.

18
00:00:56.080 --> 00:00:57.980
That's what Internet service providers do.

19
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:00.800
So we just have to worry
about our local area network.

20
00:01:00.800 --> 00:01:03.180
Now if you have two or three computers
it's probably no big deal but

21
00:01:03.180 --> 00:01:06.610
if you've got two or three thousand
computers, your network starts to get

22
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:10.580
really complex and understanding
that topology is pretty important.

23
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:14.390
Now over the years network
topologies have changed a lot.

24
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:17.300
So, if you looked at some of
the original networks from the 1970s and

25
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:21.810
1980s, they are a far cry different
from the networks of today,

26
00:01:21.810 --> 00:01:26.440
and the biggest difference is simply
how many computers they can support.

27
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:32.280
Because in the 1970s,
having one computer was pretty special.

28
00:01:32.280 --> 00:01:35.150
Having two computers was unheard of,
right?

29
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:38.140
Versus today where you have
a computer in your pocket and

30
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:41.810
a computer on your wrist and a computer
in your refrigerator and all that.

31
00:01:41.810 --> 00:01:43.600
And so people have tons of computers and

32
00:01:43.600 --> 00:01:46.290
the network has to be designed
to handle that, right?

33
00:01:46.290 --> 00:01:49.770
So let's take a look at some of the
different topologies that we've seen out

34
00:01:49.770 --> 00:01:50.850
there over the years.

35
00:01:50.850 --> 00:01:53.420
Now, let's go all the way back,
to like the 1970s.

36
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:57.740
The original networks were what
were called Bus networks, and

37
00:01:57.740 --> 00:01:59.420
Bus networks worked like this.

38
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:04.250
You basically had a single cable, and
on that cable it had two little caps on

39
00:02:04.250 --> 00:02:09.450
called a terminator, and you would plug
each of your computers in to that cable.

40
00:02:09.450 --> 00:02:13.220
And when computer one sent out a message,
it would just go down to this cable and

41
00:02:13.220 --> 00:02:14.570
go across the line.

42
00:02:14.570 --> 00:02:17.630
As it crossed the line,
everybody else will hear it.

43
00:02:17.630 --> 00:02:20.330
Computer One might be
talking to Computer Four, but

44
00:02:20.330 --> 00:02:22.370
it's actually talking to everybody.

45
00:02:22.370 --> 00:02:25.240
Computer Four just happens to hear it and
can then respond.

46
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:29.280
When Computer Four responds,
everybody hears it, but

47
00:02:29.280 --> 00:02:31.750
it's only destined for Computer One.

48
00:02:31.750 --> 00:02:34.480
You can start to see the problem here as
this network grows and grows and grows.

49
00:02:34.480 --> 00:02:38.280
The more computers you add,
the more people that want to talk and

50
00:02:38.280 --> 00:02:39.600
here's the problem.

51
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:45.830
On a line like this, on a copper line,
only one person can talk at a time.

52
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:48.450
If two people talk,
you get what's called a collision and

53
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:51.070
the data just gets damaged and
that's that, right?

54
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:55.400
So, on a bus based network, you can
really only have a handful of computers.

55
00:02:55.400 --> 00:02:57.590
And back then, in the 1970s,
that was fine, right?

56
00:02:57.590 --> 00:03:02.970
Who was gonna have more than 10 computers
was unheard of, and in the 1980s people

57
00:03:02.970 --> 00:03:06.760
starting to getting more computers and
it starting to becoming a bigger problem.

58
00:03:06.760 --> 00:03:09.850
And so now they starting to
switching to other topologies, for

59
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:12.010
example ring networks.

60
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:17.440
In the 1980s rings were the more common
topology, and they look kind of like this.

61
00:03:17.440 --> 00:03:20.140
And what you had,
you actually had two rings.

62
00:03:20.140 --> 00:03:22.758
You would run your cables
between your computers and

63
00:03:22.758 --> 00:03:24.969
you would basically form a circle, right?

64
00:03:24.969 --> 00:03:28.785
It didn't actually have to be a circle,
it could have all been in a line,

65
00:03:28.785 --> 00:03:32.917
but the cable formed a circle, and one
computer would talk and it would send its

66
00:03:32.917 --> 00:03:36.672
data out on the wire and it would go
around like this until it hit the right

67
00:03:36.672 --> 00:03:40.968
computer, and the right computer could
take that information off the network.

68
00:03:40.968 --> 00:03:43.869
And you didn't have collisions
here because on a ring network

69
00:03:43.869 --> 00:03:46.992
you have this token that was handed
from computer to computer, and

70
00:03:46.992 --> 00:03:50.537
it's kinda like this therapy sessions
where they have the talking stick.

71
00:03:50.537 --> 00:03:54.474
Not that I would do it, and they say that
you can't talk unless you have the talking

72
00:03:54.474 --> 00:03:57.060
stick, so here Daniel,
you have the talking stick.

73
00:03:57.060 --> 00:03:58.156
Tell us your emotions.

74
00:03:58.156 --> 00:04:03.880
>> I feel sad inside today because
I couldn't talk to Don's computer.

75
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:04.711
[LAUGH]
>> Because you

76
00:04:04.711 --> 00:04:05.222
didn't have the talking stick.

77
00:04:05.222 --> 00:04:06.683
>> Because I didn't
have the talking stick.

78
00:04:06.683 --> 00:04:07.796
So, that's how token ring worked.

79
00:04:07.796 --> 00:04:09.990
And it was good and bad, right?

80
00:04:09.990 --> 00:04:11.900
On a positive side,
you didn't have collisions,

81
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:14.630
on a negative side you had to wait for
that stupid token to come around.

82
00:04:14.630 --> 00:04:17.460
And it just wasn't terribly fast.

83
00:04:17.460 --> 00:04:19.580
But it let us have a lot more computers.

84
00:04:19.580 --> 00:04:23.100
So now, you can have 30,
40 computers on that ring.

85
00:04:23.100 --> 00:04:27.320
The only problem is it gets kinda hard to
run that cable the form of circle when you

86
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:31.370
have 30 computers, and
if even one computer gets unplugged,

87
00:04:31.370 --> 00:04:34.460
that ring is now broken and
it doesn't work out so well.

88
00:04:34.460 --> 00:04:37.448
So that's kind of a big challenges
with the ring based network.

89
00:04:37.448 --> 00:04:43.008
So in our modern networks what we
typically have is what's called a star,

90
00:04:43.008 --> 00:04:45.360
and a star works like this.

91
00:04:45.360 --> 00:04:49.720
You have a central device and
things plug into it, right?

92
00:04:49.720 --> 00:04:53.400
Computer 1, 2, 3, 4, they're all plugged
into this switch in this example.

93
00:04:53.400 --> 00:04:57.230
The cool part here is,
if one device loses its connection,

94
00:04:57.230 --> 00:04:59.030
the others are still connected,
they're happy, right?

95
00:04:59.030 --> 00:04:59.890
They don't care.

96
00:04:59.890 --> 00:05:01.790
So we don't need a ring anymore.

97
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:05.710
People can be wherever they need to be,
and we just connect to it, all right?

98
00:05:05.710 --> 00:05:08.840
Now the cool part about this
is I might have one switch and

99
00:05:08.840 --> 00:05:11.750
then plug it into another switch, and
another switch, and another switch.

100
00:05:11.750 --> 00:05:14.160
And the network starts getting bigger and
bigger and bigger and I have more and

101
00:05:14.160 --> 00:05:15.140
more hosts.

102
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:16.920
And so
this is what most of our networks do.

103
00:05:16.920 --> 00:05:20.990
And when we start branching out like that,
we end up in what's kind of called

104
00:05:20.990 --> 00:05:24.640
a hybrid technology,
where you may have many switches involved.

105
00:05:24.640 --> 00:05:27.660
And several computers plugged in each,
you might have hundreds or

106
00:05:27.660 --> 00:05:30.760
even thousands of computers,
and it's now possible.

107
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:32.490
Whereas bus and ring networks,

108
00:05:32.490 --> 00:05:36.460
they just really couldn't handle that
scalability and size, all right.

109
00:05:36.460 --> 00:05:40.320
So this is all what's
called a physical topology.

110
00:05:40.320 --> 00:05:43.180
These are how the cables
are physically run.

111
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:45.450
Now, if I've got 5 switches and

112
00:05:45.450 --> 00:05:49.480
computers are plugged into it,
how many switches do our computers see?

113
00:05:50.820 --> 00:05:51.480
None.

114
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:53.320
Your computers don't even
know the switch is there.

115
00:05:53.320 --> 00:05:55.270
It's basically invisible to the computer.

116
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:59.470
And so when your computer talks,
they don't see that physical topology.

117
00:05:59.470 --> 00:06:02.710
They have what's called
a logical topology.

118
00:06:02.710 --> 00:06:05.440
The logical topology is that this
computer, and this computer, and

119
00:06:05.440 --> 00:06:08.710
this computer, this computer, they all
think they're on the same network.

120
00:06:08.710 --> 00:06:10.600
And if there's a router, and
they want to get out to the internet,

121
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:13.730
they know they can go through that
router to get out to the internet.

122
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:16.732
So they just see one big container.

123
00:06:16.732 --> 00:06:20.560
They don't see all these individual
cables not this individual pieces.

124
00:06:20.560 --> 00:06:26.250
So on the logical side,
they usually see this as an IP subnet.

125
00:06:26.250 --> 00:06:30.430
Remember one of the earlier shows,
I had my Windows 8 machine and

126
00:06:30.430 --> 00:06:31.800
I've said I had my 192.168.141 network.

127
00:06:32.870 --> 00:06:34.300
That's what my computers are.

128
00:06:34.300 --> 00:06:36.610
Right, my computers are on that network.

129
00:06:36.610 --> 00:06:40.050
Anybody not on that network must
be on some other network, so

130
00:06:40.050 --> 00:06:43.080
other logical topology than mine, right?

131
00:06:43.080 --> 00:06:44.680
And I get there through a router.

132
00:06:44.680 --> 00:06:47.760
But on the physical side,
I might be on 192.168.41.

133
00:06:47.760 --> 00:06:50.260
This guy might be on 192.168.42.

134
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:52.020
And this one might be 192.168.43.

135
00:06:52.020 --> 00:06:54.110
And we can't talk to each other.

136
00:06:54.110 --> 00:06:57.160
We don't see each other logically.

137
00:06:57.160 --> 00:06:59.760
But physically,
we're plugged into the same equipment.

138
00:06:59.760 --> 00:07:02.400
So remember that you've got a physical
network and a logical network.

139
00:07:02.400 --> 00:07:05.030
The logical is what your
computers are actually seeing,

140
00:07:05.030 --> 00:07:06.600
the physical side can be very different.

141
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:10.610
So interesting thing that we need
to kind of keep in mind there,

142
00:07:10.610 --> 00:07:12.590
that we do have the physical and
logical side.

143
00:07:12.590 --> 00:07:16.160
Networks today have grown quite a bit,
they get really large.

144
00:07:16.160 --> 00:07:20.890
And again, they can scale to handle
tens of thousands of computers even.

145
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:22.590
And there's some concerns that we have.

146
00:07:22.590 --> 00:07:26.340
One of the big concerns we have
is that on older networks,

147
00:07:26.340 --> 00:07:28.280
you have a lot of collisions, right?

148
00:07:28.280 --> 00:07:30.360
These collisions were kind
of an issue that we had.

149
00:07:30.360 --> 00:07:32.790
If one computer went
to send out a message,

150
00:07:32.790 --> 00:07:36.370
remember how I said on a copper line
on one of these network cables only

151
00:07:36.370 --> 00:07:41.660
one person can talk at a time and if two
people talk at once we get a collision.

152
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:45.190
Well, on a small network when
you have four computers or

153
00:07:45.190 --> 00:07:49.230
whatever, if you get a collision,
what happens?

154
00:07:49.230 --> 00:07:53.640
Well your data gets corrupted, sure that
stinks, but then you just resend the data,

155
00:07:53.640 --> 00:07:55.610
it's not that big of a deal, right?

156
00:07:55.610 --> 00:07:57.860
Or what your computer does is it just.

157
00:07:57.860 --> 00:08:01.140
Waits and listens for
nobody else to talk and then it talks.

158
00:08:01.140 --> 00:08:02.980
Well, if you've only got four people,
that's not so hard.

159
00:08:02.980 --> 00:08:04.580
Remember the talking sticks.

160
00:08:04.580 --> 00:08:05.580
Pass the talking stick around.

161
00:08:05.580 --> 00:08:06.610
There's only four people.

162
00:08:06.610 --> 00:08:08.290
How long can it take?

163
00:08:08.290 --> 00:08:11.020
But if there's 400 people,
it's gonna take a while.

164
00:08:11.020 --> 00:08:13.540
That talking stick to get
back around to me, right?

165
00:08:13.540 --> 00:08:17.810
And I might start to talk at the same
time as somebody else starts to talk, and

166
00:08:17.810 --> 00:08:19.930
then we get a collision.

167
00:08:19.930 --> 00:08:25.130
So in modern networks, we have to
have something to help us with that.

168
00:08:25.130 --> 00:08:28.481
And there's two main forms
of what we have, all right.

169
00:08:28.481 --> 00:08:32.525
The first one is what's called CSMA/CD,
all right.

170
00:08:32.525 --> 00:08:33.663
CSMA.

171
00:08:33.663 --> 00:08:37.600
That's carrier sense multiple access.

172
00:08:37.600 --> 00:08:42.590
When you plug in to a physical switch,
your computer starts doing CSMA,

173
00:08:42.590 --> 00:08:44.050
all right.

174
00:08:44.050 --> 00:08:47.270
Whenever it goes to talk, it doesn't.

175
00:08:47.270 --> 00:08:48.830
It listens first.

176
00:08:48.830 --> 00:08:52.480
It says let me listen on the line and
see if somebody else is talking.

177
00:08:52.480 --> 00:08:55.660
So carrier sense,
I'm gonna listen to the line.

178
00:08:55.660 --> 00:08:57.170
Multiple access.

179
00:08:57.170 --> 00:09:00.040
I'm looking for
somebody else accessing the line.

180
00:09:00.040 --> 00:09:01.492
Do I hear somebody talking?

181
00:09:01.492 --> 00:09:03.258
If I do, I wait.

182
00:09:03.258 --> 00:09:05.200
All right,
you have what is called standoff.

183
00:09:05.200 --> 00:09:08.910
It's a random number that's generated that
says, I'm gonna wait this amount of time.

184
00:09:08.910 --> 00:09:12.060
And it's always random because if
people waited the same amount of time.

185
00:09:12.060 --> 00:09:14.120
Then you might be waiting in
line with somebody else, and

186
00:09:14.120 --> 00:09:16.050
you're kinda synced in time and
you'll never talk.

187
00:09:16.050 --> 00:09:17.450
So it's a bit random.

188
00:09:17.450 --> 00:09:19.570
But it just listens and it waits.

189
00:09:19.570 --> 00:09:22.220
And as soon as it hears the line is empty,
it says,

190
00:09:22.220 --> 00:09:24.840
whoa, nobody's talking, then it talks.

191
00:09:24.840 --> 00:09:26.180
All right, that's CSMA.

192
00:09:27.440 --> 00:09:29.910
Once you talk though it's not over.

193
00:09:29.910 --> 00:09:35.040
What if my laptop and Daniel's laptop
is listening at the same time?

194
00:09:35.040 --> 00:09:37.220
We both listen and
we hear the network is quiet.

195
00:09:37.220 --> 00:09:39.710
So we both talk at the same time right.

196
00:09:39.710 --> 00:09:42.140
We send out the communication and
a collision happens.

197
00:09:42.140 --> 00:09:43.560
Now, what is a collision?

198
00:09:43.560 --> 00:09:47.250
Well, I've got ones and zeroes coming
out of my computer and ones and

199
00:09:47.250 --> 00:09:49.100
zeroes coming out of Daniel's computer.

200
00:09:49.100 --> 00:09:52.430
And when the ones and zeroes which are
really like positive and negative charges

201
00:09:52.430 --> 00:09:56.790
on the line when those impact,
the charges get all screwed up, right?

202
00:09:56.790 --> 00:10:00.990
It gets all messed and
then it comes back to us.

203
00:10:00.990 --> 00:10:04.240
And so I'm gonna see that mass on
the network coming back to me and

204
00:10:04.240 --> 00:10:05.620
I know a collision happen.

205
00:10:05.620 --> 00:10:08.500
So your system can do collision detection.

206
00:10:08.500 --> 00:10:11.670
It sends and then it listens for
the collision.

207
00:10:11.670 --> 00:10:14.510
And when it sees it Daniels
laptop will see it.

208
00:10:14.510 --> 00:10:15.980
My laptop will see it.

209
00:10:15.980 --> 00:10:21.910
We both generate a random number and I say
I'm gonna wait nine tenths of a second.

210
00:10:21.910 --> 00:10:25.432
And his laptop says it's gonna wait
seven tenths of a second and then retry.

211
00:10:25.432 --> 00:10:29.485
And because we pick different numbers,
when he retries he doesn't hit me,

212
00:10:29.485 --> 00:10:31.955
when I retry I don't hit him and
now we talk, right.

213
00:10:31.955 --> 00:10:34.455
So that's why we have that random
stand off that's generated.

214
00:10:34.455 --> 00:10:38.815
>> Now Don, when this happens, well
obviously this is a awesome technology.

215
00:10:38.815 --> 00:10:40.895
Detect the collision,
lets our computers know, and

216
00:10:40.895 --> 00:10:44.825
then they do their little random business,
then they're off to the races.

217
00:10:44.825 --> 00:10:46.175
But what happened before that?

218
00:10:46.175 --> 00:10:48.375
Did the information just get garbled up,

219
00:10:48.375 --> 00:10:51.550
and there was just crazy
random network chatter?

220
00:10:51.550 --> 00:10:54.090
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] basically.

221
00:10:54.090 --> 00:10:56.900
So modern networks run what's
called ethernet, right?

222
00:10:56.900 --> 00:10:59.910
And ethernet defines exactly how
a lot of this stuff works and

223
00:10:59.910 --> 00:11:02.630
it defines how to use CSMA/CD, right?

224
00:11:02.630 --> 00:11:06.050
On the ring based networks, you didn't
have collisions, cause you had to wait for

225
00:11:06.050 --> 00:11:08.790
the token to come around, so you didn't
need to listen for the collision.

226
00:11:08.790 --> 00:11:11.090
If you had the token,
you were allowed to talk, and

227
00:11:11.090 --> 00:11:14.346
if a collision happened that date was
just lost and that was that, right?

228
00:11:14.346 --> 00:11:18.040
On a bus-bassed network, they were small.

229
00:11:18.040 --> 00:11:20.160
And so you would just listen and
talk when you had a chance.

230
00:11:20.160 --> 00:11:21.890
And, again, you didn't listen for
the collisions.

231
00:11:21.890 --> 00:11:23.040
They can happen.

232
00:11:23.040 --> 00:11:24.770
And then the data was just lost, right?

233
00:11:24.770 --> 00:11:30.710
So ethernet introduced this CSMACD, this
recovery method, and that's what we had.

234
00:11:30.710 --> 00:11:32.500
There is some problems with this though,
right?

235
00:11:32.500 --> 00:11:34.480
This works great on cabled connections.

236
00:11:34.480 --> 00:11:38.220
If you have a physical cable plugged
into a network, it works wonderfully.

237
00:11:38.220 --> 00:11:39.200
Right?

238
00:11:39.200 --> 00:11:40.740
But what about a wireless network?

239
00:11:40.740 --> 00:11:43.344
Okay, wireless networks have a little
bit of a problem, all right.

240
00:11:43.344 --> 00:11:44.130
If you have just one antenna.

241
00:11:44.130 --> 00:11:48.300
If you have one wireless antenna.

242
00:11:49.330 --> 00:11:52.770
A wireless antenna can only send or
receive.

243
00:11:52.770 --> 00:11:55.400
It can't do both at the same time,
all right.

244
00:11:55.400 --> 00:11:57.810
So I might send for a second,
receive for a second.

245
00:11:57.810 --> 00:11:59.610
Send for a second, receive for a second.

246
00:11:59.610 --> 00:12:02.210
Well I might just be sending for
five seconds, but

247
00:12:02.210 --> 00:12:04.020
I can't do both on that one antenna.

248
00:12:04.020 --> 00:12:06.280
So, in your laptop, in your desktop,

249
00:12:06.280 --> 00:12:09.700
whatever device it is that you have that's
wireless, they typically put two antennas,

250
00:12:09.700 --> 00:12:13.450
two antennas so you can send and
receive at the same time, all right.

251
00:12:13.450 --> 00:12:19.340
But, when you're sending, you're
receiving antenna actually gets weaker.

252
00:12:19.340 --> 00:12:21.910
The signal from the send and
the receive, it's on the same frequency,

253
00:12:21.910 --> 00:12:24.030
they actually interfere with each other.

254
00:12:24.030 --> 00:12:28.640
And so your send gets a little
more precedence over the receive.

255
00:12:28.640 --> 00:12:32.220
And as a result, if you're sending on
the wireless network at the same time as

256
00:12:32.220 --> 00:12:36.990
somebody else, you can have a collision
and your receive is not gonna see it.

257
00:12:36.990 --> 00:12:40.010
Or if it sees it, it's really faint and
it might not pick it up, right?

258
00:12:40.010 --> 00:12:43.090
So wireless networks can't
play well with CSMACD, so

259
00:12:43.090 --> 00:12:45.010
instead they used something different.

260
00:12:45.010 --> 00:12:48.610
They used what's called CSMA/CA,
all right?

261
00:12:48.610 --> 00:12:50.700
Carrier sense multiple access.

262
00:12:50.700 --> 00:12:53.510
If they're gonna talk, they listen to
see if somebody else is talking, and

263
00:12:53.510 --> 00:12:54.616
if nobody's talking, then they send.

264
00:12:54.616 --> 00:12:58.560
And then collision avoidance.

265
00:12:58.560 --> 00:13:00.910
How does collision avoidance work?

266
00:13:00.910 --> 00:13:04.100
Well, the way it works is,
before you send,

267
00:13:04.100 --> 00:13:09.370
you actually send out a message saying,
hey everybody, I'm about to talk, right?

268
00:13:09.370 --> 00:13:13.710
And that way, everybody else knows,
hey, this guy's about to talk, and so

269
00:13:13.710 --> 00:13:16.510
they all shut up for
a minute and they let you talk.

270
00:13:16.510 --> 00:13:19.740
We avoid the collision by
giving everybody a head's up.

271
00:13:19.740 --> 00:13:23.360
Now if we give everybody a heads up and

272
00:13:23.360 --> 00:13:28.130
the heads up, that request to communicate,
if that's blocked,

273
00:13:28.130 --> 00:13:32.610
if that gets a collision, I don't hear
anything back from the other people.

274
00:13:32.610 --> 00:13:33.990
But if it's successful and

275
00:13:33.990 --> 00:13:38.720
it gets through, the other people send me
what's called a clear to send, or CTS.

276
00:13:38.720 --> 00:13:41.850
And that clear to send says,
all right I'm gonna stop talking for

277
00:13:41.850 --> 00:13:42.670
a minute while you talk.

278
00:13:43.700 --> 00:13:47.360
Now this is happening in nanoseconds, this
is happening super fast on the network, so

279
00:13:47.360 --> 00:13:50.300
I know it sounds slow, but
it's actually a pretty good system.

280
00:13:50.300 --> 00:13:53.280
And that way I don't have to listen for
collisions, on a wireless network you

281
00:13:53.280 --> 00:13:56.840
don't listen for collision because it's
just RF waves going through the air.

282
00:13:56.840 --> 00:14:00.200
You don't see that screwed up
electric signal on a wire,

283
00:14:00.200 --> 00:14:02.080
you don't see that on the wireless side.

284
00:14:02.080 --> 00:14:03.570
So CSNACA,

285
00:14:03.570 --> 00:14:07.490
collision avoidance, helps us to just
dodge the collisions before it happens.

286
00:14:07.490 --> 00:14:10.550
>> Kind of reminds me of the token
system to be honest with you.

287
00:14:10.550 --> 00:14:11.710
Instead of having the token, and

288
00:14:11.710 --> 00:14:16.030
say I'm the only one that can talk, I
just say, I'm the only one that can talk.

289
00:14:16.030 --> 00:14:17.830
And everybody else just goes, yes.

290
00:14:17.830 --> 00:14:19.360
Apparently you are the only
one who can talk.

291
00:14:19.360 --> 00:14:20.489
I will settle down.

292
00:14:20.489 --> 00:14:23.530
[LAUGH]
>> It's a little more like requesting it.

293
00:14:23.530 --> 00:14:25.820
Can I please have the talking stick?

294
00:14:25.820 --> 00:14:27.890
But you had to talk to say that, right.

295
00:14:27.890 --> 00:14:30.590
Gotta be nice,
can I please have the talking stick?

296
00:14:30.590 --> 00:14:34.610
They can say no, I'm busy talking,
shut up about your talking stick.

297
00:14:34.610 --> 00:14:35.610
They can say that, right.

298
00:14:35.610 --> 00:14:38.260
But if you don't have it, you're not
gonna talk, you kind of request it.

299
00:14:38.260 --> 00:14:41.300
The cool part here over a ring
is you can go out of order.

300
00:14:41.300 --> 00:14:43.880
In a ring, you have to go in order.

301
00:14:43.880 --> 00:14:46.830
If you're computer five, and
you just handed off the toke.

302
00:14:46.830 --> 00:14:50.200
It's gotta go to computers one two three
and four before it comes back to you.

303
00:14:50.200 --> 00:14:54.840
But with CSNCA, you can be computer five,
computer four could be talking,

304
00:14:54.840 --> 00:14:56.020
or computer one could be talking,

305
00:14:56.020 --> 00:14:58.600
and you could just immediately
request from there and it would jump.

306
00:14:58.600 --> 00:15:00.590
So it can go out of order, and
that makes it pretty efficient.

307
00:15:00.590 --> 00:15:02.990
Now you might ask yourself if that's so
efficient,

308
00:15:02.990 --> 00:15:04.980
why don't we use that on
the wired networks now?

309
00:15:04.980 --> 00:15:09.000
And the reason is that most wired
networks use switches instead of hubs.

310
00:15:09.000 --> 00:15:12.340
In the old days, when you used hubs,
collisions were a big deal.

311
00:15:12.340 --> 00:15:13.640
You could collide all the time.

312
00:15:13.640 --> 00:15:16.390
When you talked on a port,
everybody else saw it.

313
00:15:16.390 --> 00:15:18.030
But on a switch, when you go to talk,

314
00:15:18.030 --> 00:15:20.700
you actually don't talk to
the whole network any more.

315
00:15:20.700 --> 00:15:22.280
You talk to the switch.

316
00:15:22.280 --> 00:15:25.030
And the switch has a little bit of
memory available for each port and

317
00:15:25.030 --> 00:15:27.130
it's receiving your communication and
storing it there.

318
00:15:27.130 --> 00:15:29.390
And the switch thing goes to transmit it.

319
00:15:29.390 --> 00:15:32.430
So the switch can have collisions but
you can't.

320
00:15:32.430 --> 00:15:35.200
So, if your laptop or
your desktop is plugged into a switch,

321
00:15:35.200 --> 00:15:39.710
unless something goes horribly wrong,
hardware failure, then you're not gonna

322
00:15:39.710 --> 00:15:42.480
have collisions plugged into a switch,
but the switch itself might.

323
00:15:42.480 --> 00:15:44.730
And so the switch is dealing
with all that forest.

324
00:15:44.730 --> 00:15:48.660
And so that's why we don't switch
to CMSACA on a wired network and

325
00:15:48.660 --> 00:15:50.340
we stay with CMSACD.

326
00:15:50.340 --> 00:15:53.200
Because the collisions just
don't happen anymore, right.

327
00:15:53.200 --> 00:15:54.530
But on a wireless network they do.

328
00:15:54.530 --> 00:15:56.711
And so they have to have
a different technology for that.

329
00:15:56.711 --> 00:15:57.789
>> Very, very cool stuff.

330
00:15:57.789 --> 00:16:00.840
Now, I love switch networks,
I love wired networks.

331
00:16:00.840 --> 00:16:04.870
And I'm glad we get to take advantage of
all the technologies that they give us.

332
00:16:04.870 --> 00:16:06.900
To make sure that those
things run efficiently.

333

else that we need to go over?

334

sure that you've got that foundational

knowledge, that base information.

343

The kind of quick and

how these technologies work and
